title: Here in the Dark
author: Soloski, Alexis
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Zowza! Outlier indeed. In all the senses I can evaluate too. But the genre is more horror, psychological style than it is detecting in any genre form.Zowza! Outlier indeed. In all the senses I can evaluate too. But the genre is more horror, psychological style than it is detecting in any genre form. It was taken totally unknown from the "New" shelf. Probably one of the only times my outcome is a 5 star read experience after such a simple "like the cover" gambit.But few readers will like this one as much as I did. EXCELLENT vocabulary. Anhedonic or ultramimetic? This author is a woman after my heart. Would Mylifeisart ever be a service website?This is REAL New York City. So I warn. And warn again. Because there ARE many there like Vivian who reside in Manhattan. Ones who also have all the answers yet not a morsel of their own core self-identity and/or self worth to surround. Sorrowfully true. Because they are always acting and 90% disconnected from "other". And purposely keep that so.I won't go long although I could. But this is very dark and centered on a mentally ill/ personality disordered woman. Who also happens to be an excellent live theater/ stage performances critic. It's written for Arts majors and those who have MFA's etc. Not practical applications people like I am. So I am shocked by my own appreciation. This novel is cruel and coarse. And very real. Think quite opposite of any type of cozy.Warning: foul and excelling language. Both. Dark and darkness uses of alcohol and other addictions. Pleasure gotten through pain. Escape from singular life and the personal by living as an actor or in make believe worlds. But all done in reverse. Or looking in instead of out? Or not? It IS in chronological order.I could NOT put it down. And the ending I only guessed about 10 pages before the end of the book.I sure wonder if this author will ever do other novels? IMHO, this perhaps is highly autobiographical. By a very, very brilliant woman. Hope she is not as sick as Vivian seems. But I'll not forget the name Soloski. Let's all pretend!"My body feels like a dress bought on clearance, one that never really fit."...more

author: Keahey, John*

review: This is interesting but not at all enthralling. For me, anyway. I enjoy most travelogues more, although I loved the places featured in this one.The auThis is interesting but not at all enthralling. For me, anyway. I enjoy most travelogues more, although I loved the places featured in this one.The author may be a great traveler but not a writer up to that equal. He rather tells more about the help he engenders along the way and the search questions to natives of these places than he does re the places themselves. It seems he wants to stress his own serendipity type of long term and slow (months given to this) type of travel. Other than the planned, appointed, scheduled type of travel most humans are able to complete presently.The areas of core interest re former Roman Empire roads was an excellent tale and observation onus for the book. But the telling got much off subject into tangent and sometimes rambling. But I did enjoy it, although I could speed read parts as they were so dry.The other ers note no photos. The photos in my hardcover were SUPERB. Excellent- 6 stars. They were the best part of the book. To view the layers and the top stones of the various Via! Such a legacy- leaving this for us to see 2000 plus years "after". The engineering was fabulous and the idea and outcome changed the world. Not only for trade either....more

review: The Hanna story becomes so overblown and juvenile that it seems ridiculous to me. With a sister like Lydia supplying you such a life of top notch lodgThe Hanna story becomes so overblown and juvenile that it seems ridiculous to me. I totally understand why #3 never made the cut after this drawn out crazy pastor etc. mess.Plot here is abysmal. And 90% of the humans act like they are 13 rather than 30 plus. Complaint is the coming summer's sport. 12 to a side.Daniel is also ridiculous as are the so called hours of acceptable work etc. You can take your paternity leave in the summer and fall because there are so few cases then? Rolling down the alley laughing!Since when do people who move in with others for 3 or 5 years. with no marriage and with the original owner staying there after the move in person leaves; how can they deserve (or even begin to think) that they have earned a percentage of home ownership equity paid to them? Disgusting and just wrong. Just because they paid some small portion of a utility or other bills. Who has the mortgage and the name on the purchase! Nearly as bad as squatters thinking their presence equates to ownership. And with such high property taxes too. I doubt this author knows any law. She also thinks taking care of a baby is responsibility beyond bearing. She turns to reciting this for 10 pages out of each 100.This author truly wrecked the progression. The locale didn't deserve it....more

title: Hidden in Snow        (The Åre Murders, #1)
author: Sten, Viveca
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This is her other series start (Are #1). I've read one of the beginning novels for her other/ alternate Swedish isle locale series. This one is locateThis is her other series start (Are #1). I've read one of the beginning novels for her other/ alternate Swedish isle locale series. This one is located in Are which is a very outlier rural mountain village part of Sweden. (Glorious mansions have just been built. Think Aspen category residents in part.) The ski lifts park/ venues are gearing up within the treacherous beginning of a winter blizzard period. Weather is key here throughout- it is focus. Deep snow and more and more. I will remind that this is for a length of daylight (well sort of) of no more than 5-1/2 hours total length of sunlight (murky too) daily. So darkness to search? Nearly a constant factor as well.Missing Amanda (just 18 years old) cores. And also Hanna finding herself after a turn of events which in some ways just dismissed her inclusion in the Stockholm police force. So the beginning itself was done quite well. With Hanna in turmoil and out of her city, urban reality completely. And this is the core problem with all her books that I've read so far and with this one too. Good beginning and more than adequate going to excellent endings. All. But scattered progressions, at best- and way, way too much repetitive filler in between. Sten does that the most in her introduction books to a series. It makes them overlong and at points hard to come back to with enthusiasm. So most of the book read feels like a 3 star. Also, I am always flabbergasted by the Swedish law procedures and in/out (ok let's just go in here again now or switch jurisdictions etc.) ploys. Which would never, ever be allowed in so many other countries.Yes, we know Hanna has poor self-esteem and is a mess up. Over and over we need to read chapter after chapter of her self-defeating thoughts? More than 100 pages of that onus with breaks of minute inquiry in this book. But that is how Sten gets any character depth? Not a fan.Also her characters, almost all of them. And especially all the primes. Why are they so always with tempers or wanting instant revenge. They act more Sicilian than they do Swedish? Beats me. But for this book especially- that almost made it a 3 star. I only rounded it up for the spectacular locale feel and accurate death. Well done. I don't think I have approached the slow freeze done as well and it is rarely, rarely attempted. Not even in the Nordic noir or any genre on the whole. With that weather you would think it is as common as the strangling has become.Well- even her main men characters all have a screw loose and snap. And the women are 90% juvenile (tearing apart clothing or wrecking with vandalism every time a "hurt" or rejection comes home to register). At 30 or 40 something? Sounds like teenager moronic reaction to me. Adults I know are not so universally triggered so fast. Is she (Sten) doing that as a habit to make the "morose" Scandinavian in most other writers' of this genre dissolve? Regardless- not everyone is perfect (like Lydia in this tale) but people in such jobs (law/copper/lab etc.) are just not as apt to be so over the top emotional. I have known many and I can't think of a one who is. Maybe also a warning for the animal lovers because a dog suffers retribution in this one. Another emotional snapper character- UGH!Overlong in repetition, but a writer of place and season that is memorable. 3 stars for all else- but 4 for that alone. I didn't completely guess the correct perp as I did in her others. Everything is more complex in this one so the social onus stance (trafficking, migration etc.) becomes much wider. Overall this is extremely sad too. Even having a 3 month old baby is made to seem too much for any adult to overcome. I hated that. Also she gets in her usual Mother or Mother-in-Law despicable older woman in there as usual. Drinking is more than featured by all as well....more

title: Still Waters        (Sandhamn Murders, #1)
author: Sten, Viveca
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: It is closer to 3.5 stars in total. But I did round it up for the locale feel of Sandhamn Island and the isles around it. Also for Nora's story- as thIt is closer to 3.5 stars in total. But I did round it up for the locale feel of Sandhamn Island and the isles around it. Also for Nora's story- as that one was highly pertinent to the modern era.But it was overlong and at least 1/2 of the middle portions needed less telling. Most especially within the 4 or 5 paragraph description of each place using nearly identical words to do so too. And also for Thomas's long winded surrounds or ferry or boating or walking portions to get to an inquiry or office space. But his workplace and associates were NOT overdone either, so the balance was off, IMHO. All else was (I cannot relate how many times the archipelago word in several forms or the same house flowers were again described and praised or at least noted) using page after page of little else but the very much alike description. And even after the third death a decent edit count and task could have scoured out at least 25 pages of the last third and it would have been a better book.Yet the ending made up for it. The last 40-50 pages were the full 4 stars. The stone tower and much else of the juxtapositions were done well.I will go on to book #2 and hope that the repetition habit becomes more cured as she publishes. And that she has better continuity- as this one had some points of huge jumpiness. And I did guess the correct murderer too just at about the half way point because of how that omitting "jumping" to others or Thomas's hierarchy was progressing.But I really do think she did Nora to a full 4 star level. Her thoughts, her activity, her sleep etc. with the 2 boys. That was very close to real life for this type of fiction genre. I'm a big fan of that aspect. Hope in book #2 that she does take the job in Malmo.It seems like nearly every one of these Scandinavian writers have characters that are orphans, family bereft, singles of dire happenstance etc. in majority. At least this one holds some people who have living parents, siblings who didn't all go to another continent or kids that are alive and/or at least talking to them. That was a plus for Still Waters. And the food was nearly minimal but they all DID at least eat something other than toast too. ...more

title: Sito: An American Teenager and the City that Failed Him
author: Ralph, Laurence*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: One of thousands of heart breaking stories of teen gang banger death. The copy talked AT you. Like a lecture. There was hardly enough Sito biographicaOne of thousands of heart breaking stories of teen gang banger death. The copy talked AT you. Like a lecture. There was hardly enough Sito biographical or personal information to be the core of the title. Most of the book was about himself and the Black teenagers in various other cities. Not only San Francisco. Not only now either; then or always. And the title is not "answered" at all within specifics but with more theory, IMHO.He uses this terrible outcome for page after page of his own former publications as advertisement and also in repeated copy stats. And one of them is filled with what is called in tech social media sites "misinformation". Because I was there in Chicago during the "glory days" of his associates. This interpretation of the Weathermen and Black Rangers/ Black Panthers Nation etc. etc. is highly inaccurate. Murderers and terrorists all. Some were jailed for life. Some lead rolls now as if they hadn't killed 3 or up to a dozen innocent people each. When that is only the tip of the iceberg for their depth of horrific deeds, at that.People who read this type of highly educated theory posited as if most of it IS biography or is true? Well, I wish I would have had a cell phone camera about 10 times in my life before I was 30. Because almost the entire Chicago portion was like Pontius Pilate relating the events of Jesus of Nazareth's Palm Sunday parade.At points he says teenagers of this placement and time period is like being a leopard. They have "leopards" inside them and they cannot help many emotional actions of various terrible results. When emotional actions lead to vast destruction, murders, life long disabilities from assaults, destruction of property to where it can never recover- or just plain evil outcomes when victims can no longer hold any trust- than I believe it IS the fault of the person who committed the act. Never explained as "normal" either.Here, once again, the option of little to no consequence is posited as the answer for these acts? With all police as the tyrants? Oh, of course.What is hardest to swallow is the educational levels of these parental or step-father etc. relations as they ARE described. Where were they when the kid was growing up? Oh, probably seeking fulfillment or in schools of renown. The mother AND the father - he was NO priority.The writing itself- the form is just terrible. Vastly without continuity or order. Going on tangents of lecture or aside consistently....more

title: Agrippina: Empress, Exile, Hustler, Whore
author: Southon, Emma
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: You can give this anything across the boards and make valid arguments for your rating. If you have no tolerance for gross, foul, and crass language anYou can give this anything across the boards and make valid arguments for your rating. If you have no tolerance for gross, foul, and crass language and/or comparisons to judgments made here that don't translate well after 2000 years? Well, you see what I mean? I bet there were more street words for sexual intercourse in this book than any other I've read. Well, I read in quantity- but not ones like those using such gutter language much. So anyone who had to listen to this (audio)? Bonking in 100 forms. F words used in/as every part of speech. Then why the rating?Well, I almost gave it a 5 star rating. Because she gets you into the times of Agrippina. The razor's edge that being a great-granddaughter of Augustus gets you. Among a place, culture, time that was intensely rule bound and hierarchy dictated. Southon uses modern media and entertainment "knowns" (by her generation raised in England anyway)- to exactly differentiate. And it is like the layers of an onion. Everything small? Not really, as it gets peeled back to reveal more. You do "get it". This was a time of such power and in /for women- not at all the same as the present. Even 200 years ago women were NOT so lawfully restricted to their own singular existences. They in the Roman Empire did not even hold a lawful voice at all- only a male relative could own, speak, decide for them.The critics of Southon are so turned about by the constant "I" talk in this book coupled with feminist modern observations that they fail to see the lack within the historic record. This is an excellence that Southon notes and displays well. Or do most ers of this truly grasp the entire manner of writing and record that was done in the centuries after Agrippina's life which required it. And not just about her or any Empress or power female figurer either- but about the base mindset of the historic writer himself or the common person of those times beliefs/truths re women and authority. Common beliefs often became truth for the long term. They do now too. When truth is the farthest reach (opposite) of what WAS or IS.Some of the political "sides" are just as projecting today (accusing deeds which they themselves do continually) as they were in Agrippina's life span. So many of those events or outcomes were distorted too by the recorders afterwards. The Roman cognition/emotion/definition being that men and women could never be associates or friends in purposes (both good and bad purposes) without sex being involved between them. Coming from an Italian culture which still sits there- I do understand. Other cultures are worse. That's true. Still is.Read the other s for this too. It IS (her life and her actions) much more complex than Game of Thrones. If you ever watched I, Claudius on PBS (ancient now- probably most of you were not even born then)- you might understand this better. What you saw is not always what you got. Also I think this gives you a taste of the real religious sense of that era. Omens, tradition, clothing to reflect etc. Excellent- 5 stars. If anything she underestimates the superstition of curses, spells, sacrifices etc. The numbers of executions and annihilating entire populations went way down during Agrippina's run as Empress and in her persuasions overall too. The numbers recorded were an excellent window seldom exposed. I've read tomes of Rome for 60 plus years. Never saw that before.If you do nothing and detest flippant and crass historic details? Although most certainly close to truth- at least read page 141 in the hard cover. It's a masterful reciting of what Roman Empire DID to the provinces. It tells you much. How Roman Empire and colonization methods HAVE/DID advance the world. Because the message in education now is totally the opposite. Roads and peace were the least of it. Longevity, shelter, trade, engineering (I could get verbose) etc. The part about the draining of the lake festival! OMG, this was 2000 years ago and they DID that without any heavy equipment or mechanical power machines. Just passing the bath habit and places was a millennia of progress in health/ disease etc. Agrippina was smart and many will like her. I did not. But I do think she walked such an edge that she lived up to being Germanicus's daughter. Having her entire birth family but 1 sister (9 or 10 people depending on the historian) killed or dead before she herself was in her 20's? Well, I wonder who of us could have done better. I differ from Southon in several opinions and have read Roman history. Too much is unknown- especially upon what happened right before Claudius was poisoned. If you love Roman power reads- this is one of the best. Nearly a 5 star read but not, IMHO, because of the style of telling; it becomes abhorrent at points. Although the similes to similar modern tv or brands etc. comparisons make it much easier to absorb than most dry history relating. Why it loses the one star, maybe more- is that she at points does as Zinn did in his history "telling". Slant the "eyes" to make modern values apply or omits things that don't "fit" for personal/ individual appraisals. Not as horribly off as Zinn because at least she does (not all the time but most times) state the opposing theory/ events which may have happened/ alliances/ REAL outcomes that do not jibe etc. Zinn never does. Also she left out no time periods in Agrippina's life. Not even the ones of near silence or exile.I read her second book. It was not as good as this one centered on Agrippina. But I still can see SOME of the lower star ratings for this tone. Of course, only men ever wrote the history and it was only within eyes of their own social constructs. Some people now NEVER get that at all....more

title: Sarum: The Novel of England
author: Rutherfurd, Edward*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I read this before when it was new. And honestly I think similarly in reaction. Usually tomes I have not read in 4 decades or more? Those I most usualI read this before when it was new. And honestly I think similarly in reaction. Usually tomes I have not read in 4 decades or more? Those I most usually respond to in more altered thoughts or insights. Not Sarum.The first half is quite easier to connect with/ embed. After about 1100 AD, you cannot really trace families nor the complexities of most of the circuit relationships. You do partially with some but overall there is just too much tangent and historical process telling. Amid immense description of nature and structures? Too much telling- so much legal or invasion change that most of the individuality and human family concepts of continuity gets lost. It is a story of invasion overall. And one group grabbing what was produced by others first. Or authority used as cudgel or prize. Primarily of conquests by force and invasions for the finite goods and locations that optimize them.Overall this barely makes 3 stars for periods from 1348 (Plague) onwards. Study of island history (almost any that become nations) is top-notch interesting to me. Therefore the reread but overall I do not recommend this one.Regardless this is the same invasion process observable in North America during this century. Not really migration as the attitudes and manner are entirely different. Holding different outcomes, as well. But always within huge declines for native populations....more

title: A Rome of One's Own: The Forgotten Women of the Roman Empire
author: Southon, Emma
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Quite interesting book. I read it slowly after reading Sarum by Rutherfurd which gives nearly the opposite views re the periods of the conquest of theQuite interesting book. I read it slowly after reading Sarum by Rutherfurd which gives nearly the opposite views re the periods of the conquest of the English isle by the Romans. With oppressors being received more than the eyes of the elites themselves who conquer as here in A Rome of One's Own.Southon sure knows her history. And her best first sources too. But why she diverts into paragraph after paragraph to do stand up material? A reference to pop culture of more modern eras (almost exclusively her own, btw) in contrast or to equivocate is useful. Also fine when done cleverly and witty as she surely is. But not constantly and consistently. Most especially with huge blasts of foul verbiage and real attitude of ire thrown in. Not once, not twice, but often.So I was disappointed and did not enjoy the read very much. I can listen to cable tv drek and hear nearly the same phrasing. Women had different rules. That's a surety. Southon gives you every angle when they worked the least for the women themselves or were part of a whole world view of rules considered by current terms, despicable. Regardless of another truth rarely, rarely implied here. The advantages of being a Roman woman despite lacks. Mostly, the great health and longevity advantages re human antiquity states which she hardly at all addresses. Not just within the richest or more powerful women either, but for ALL the women of these Roman worlds' periods. In comparison to periods just before Rome conquered? These were eras and places of very short and brutal lives all around. All humans and on every continent. And animals had it worse. In some places and on some continents approaching or reaching the age of 40 was still rare. And all infant mortality was HUGE and continual. So I DID appreciate the detail of their lives to the intrinsic and important minutia that she included. All of the periods she covered. I've been to Pompey and the digs there myself and can vouch for the murals and the mosaics. They ARE lewd. Not all, but a number of them. She doesn't mention the huge enclosures with locks and traps that were used as safes. Still cleverly operational. Some of these houses supported 50 to 100 people within a well fed and fairly happy (defined completely differently then too, btw) lifestyle as opposed to starving half the year on a farm and dying before 30. The Roman world in all its conquests, terrible deeds, and uses for women that would never be their druthers- it also held advances in almost every field of human knowledge and skill that would not be gained again for nearly a millennia after they were lost. And women and men that DID live to 60 or 70 years. In this entire area of the world, that is true. You never get those comparison points of HUGE improvements much from a person who knows the Romans as much as this historian does. Only a much greater sense and use of ire and anger reactions for women's legal and individual perimeters. Not at all untrue- but in proportion to the author's attitude! It was definitely worth the read, this book. Despite having to pick my way through the excess slanted bilge. But I just abhor her constant crass attempts at continual humor. Some subjects are not apt for it. This is one. Looking at women of Rome's Empire through the judgment eyes of perceptions of 2000 AD plus that they would never have? Power of every sort was also operational in quite a different sense/way/method than in the post-industrial world. I'll try one more of hers but that will probably be it. Too much Emma Southon despite the excellent historic detail....more

review: This was a 5 star read for me. I read it in one sit down going slower toward the ending. To make it last?This will not be a 5 star for the great majorThis was a 5 star read for me. I read it in one sit down going slower toward the ending. To make it last?This will not be a 5 star for the great majority of readers. Because it cores on a deep seated feeling. A premonition that seems a certainty. The entire occurs in a mood. It's more a piece set in thinking/emotion, more than it is in group activity. And also that thinking quotient dwells at the precise core about her own self-identity for a 19 year old woman. There are some portions, even in luscious description that display essence of core Japanese sensibilities and mores. But everything in these 130 some pages is the living state of premonition. A mood within a knowledge. With a definitive ending on top of it. Masterful. These aftermaths of knowledge may hold various subjective values than a 10 Commandments type of mindset may not comprehend in a similar tone/way. Another reason many on other continents may see this finale scenario as off. This is the first I've read of hers and I will read others. 100% sure. The translation held well the tone of Japanese declarative speech and was top notch excellent for conveying the ponderance, as well.Her style is carved cutting for locales too. There are 3 places in Japan here and you are on the bullet trains repeatedly. For some reason dozing within travel and sleep spells also comes across in this one to a 5 star depth. Not very long though, is my thinking.The Butterfly herself wasn't as interesting as an individual than I thought she would be. The Jazz Age ending that came so swiftly was the best point of clarity in this book. Clearly shown why. It doesn't happen now in the 21st century at all in this manner. Entire middle class or working group points of economy collapse (store owners, restaurants etc.) in vast numbers and the top elites of coastal views still seem to play on and on without a pause. Massive industries leave the continent and not a whimper recorded? Within the same dance moves as the crooks did then, as well. review: It's 3.5 stars to be fair. I almost awarded a 4 star. But the ending just didn't equate to that for me. YET, it kept my interest throughout. This is nIt's 3.5 stars to be fair. I almost awarded a 4 star. But the ending just didn't equate to that for me. YET, it kept my interest throughout. This is not a fast read. Nor one with endless what is now called "action". It was much enjoyed because it is in the style of depth to character and carving of the locale. Also in chronological order and through one narrator's eyes. That made it a full 4 star throughout the first half.And as I rather disliked the narrator and most of the primes- this is unusual. For me, anyone with her snark and separateness quotient (BOTH) the character never gets me to embed much at all. But I did in The Busy Body. I was thoroughly abiding within the Crystal Palace's glass walls.It was the ending that restricted my rating. Too much tell and not any show whatsoever. And motive as it played? Hmmm! Not impossible but highly unlikely in such sequences of using serendipity. But I have to add too, Poirot meet up with such combos in two or three places. Yes, this is reflective of Agatha's works. Very much so.Another aspect did bother me a bit. It's more than fine to refer to other works (books, tv) etc. but it gets over the top when that is done too many times. This narrator did those comparisons as reference ambiance at 3 or 5 per 10 pages of copy. And some were extremely clever. And real in scope too. But STILL- it just doesn't fly within the "in" crowds now. I don't know why- but it just doesn't seem to for me. Especially within the age of this protagonist (almost 40 years age) portrayed here. Also her endless descriptions of the Bodyguard! And her availability factor in eventuality? I'm sure it occurs, but for me as displayed- that is hard to believe. THAT was written by a man- it had too many visual tells. But then again- I never understand women who become that pouncing aggressive. Nor did I know any. Truthfully.Well, you see- it did make me think a bit. That's more than most in this genre. Give it 4 stars for a first published effort....more

review: Woah- this at points knocked my socks off- and I almost gave it a 5 stars. But I can't because of its length and its immense verbosity. Verbosity not Woah- this at points knocked my socks off- and I almost gave it a 5 stars. But I can't because of its length and its immense verbosity. Verbosity not in a negative way- but in a style that tended to traits of repeating emotional explanations. This would have been 5 star spectacular with an 100 page edit, IMHO. It is really 3 different books. Or at least 2 separate books and a novella. Rebecka's story is one. Bjorn's story (and his boxing career itself) is another whole book. And the story of Pohjanen and all the other individuals within the workplace setting are at least a novella length tale. Ragahild and all the village posits/ oldsters is at least another novella. So you end up with 3 entire book lengths- I was wrong. And the 606 pages does NOT read succinct and fast (for any straight or chronological cognitive connection) in any sense either. This is the only fiction book I can remember in the last 5 years that took me an entire week to read. With only an hour or two at the most on any other perusals of print at all. HEW!Every time it went back to the 1960's and 1970's boxing career I sighed and took a break. What you get here is NOT what is focus of the trailer for this book at all. Do be aware that this is complex and not only cored on a mystery or copper case. It is far more an introspection to characters during their immense mood or life changes as those crisis times occur. For about 6 to 8 characters too- more than I named in this reaction.It's the end book of a series. Rebecka finishes at a completely different place than at the start of the series. Not only with job or relationships either. Kiruna (far North sticks Sweden) is actually the star of this whole kit and gaboodle. I enjoyed portions of this to a 6 star. Especially the skiing portions and the dogs' stories. Oh yes, that is another whole book. We have a new one too- named Villa. Tintin and the Brat are entirely themselves. My favorite character from before mid-series has always been Anne-Marie. She is done superbly here- 5 stars for all of her home placed parts especially.Absolutely my favorite Swedish writer. It was worth the wait. But STILL- I wish you would have broken this one down to 3 tomes instead of combining them all into #6. Rebecka Martinsson is NOT the prime character by the ending. IMHO, not even from the beginning of this one. The older people took over. And the mood spells of descriptive words in individuals' perceptions. Kiruna! And the snow mounds (not even in the mountain parts) are within blizzards of early May. It made Chicago seem like Miami in comparison. LOL!Loved those folks. 4.5 stars - fully. And that is outlier on any over 600 page book for me in living memory. In any decade of ing too- I do not think LONG is ever optimal. Not even within lovemaking at over 70/ 75 years old here too- as is chapter length described. Those pages really did make me laugh....more

title: The Orange Man and Other Narratives of Medical Detection
author: Roueché, Berton
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: OMG, did this bring my childhood back to me. And also my teens too. Because I can remember many doctor sessions that went along the lines of these exaOMG, did this bring my childhood back to me. And also my teens too. Because I can remember many doctor sessions that went along the lines of these exact types of inquiries. Trying to reach a prognosis for conditions that were not "named" or were too rare to be seen by the average family doctor. They happened to me consistently until I was about 6 or 7. Then less frequently but still a couple of times a year. I weighed 29 lbs in 3rd grade and was ALWAYS anemic. You'd never know it now. LOL! Genetic condition people still have this happen to them all the time.The writing is closer to 3 stars, but it is SO of its time that I forgive some jumpiness. Excellent window into the state of medicine, when many life situations or medicines or new chemicals or products became part of a health mix which perplexed the most medical savvy. The title orange man I knew what it was immediately because I knew someone who had that occur. It's also a pleasure to know how far medicine has come in the last 80 or 90 years. No more so than in epidemics. YET, a single sentence in this book- which is STILL accurate (except for omitting ebola) does SO convey how absolutely wrong decisions were made during Covid 19 lock down path.Cholera, Smallpox, Plague, Yellow Fever, Diptheria - diseases of spread that demand quarantine. The chapter on epidemics was 5 stars. I learned much about sweating sickness and others that were pervasive and then just disappeared entirely.The chapter on the women with such spasms that broke her hips! OMG -I still do not understand how Valium helped it....more

title: The Ballad of the Sad Café and Other Stories
author: McCullers, Carson
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: The title tale is 4.5 stars. The collection as a whole is a delight.Does this just nail the place, time, characters, town and does it through the eyesThe title tale is 4.5 stars. The collection as a whole is a delight.Does this just nail the place, time, characters, town and does it through the eyes of obsession. And in the most highly nuanced descriptions possible. SO realistically, and not in a fawning way. Dialect and flow of language is 5 stars completely. All of the stories - even the three page ones are about OBSESSION. Obsession in love or skills or some aspect to achieve connection with the "loved". Musician obsession I have seen. Spot on.Does love and attraction to constant presence always occur in this fashion. NO. That is why it is not 5 stars for me but 4. This pattern she constructs (and explains at length) is a anomaly. With "lover" and "loved" as precisely fixated quantities and in virtually unchanged/virtual states. In real life, I have seen this occur. But love is FAR more often in prime display with a balance between who is the lover and who is the loved, IMHO. Not totally fixed and immutable at all, but in couples of long loving duration those positions shifting. Nor do obsessions always last lifetimes or decades, either.But not in the life of this cafe' and with this situation. This is the/an everlasting triangle. Super glad I read it! She sure could write a world of personality volcanic. High likes and dislikes abounding. And always the obsession. Oh with that obsession core and carving McCullers' writing (yet of an entirely different time and placement) DOES SO remind me of W. Somerset Maugham. He did that same exact patterning. Most often in his short stories too but also throughout a long, long writing career....more

author: Simsion, Graeme*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This is well written. Better writing and dialogue than in most humorous chick lit fare. That's what it is. This could be a long running sit. com. formThis is well written. Better writing and dialogue than in most humorous chick lit fare. That's what it is. This could be a long running sit. com. formula, as well. It would need the correctly chosen set of main characters as actors/ actresses though. Which could easily go wrong.Like most tales (books especially) of high humor treatments for prime characters who are different in some way- this one also- it gets rather stale quickly. Because the same types of misperceptions form over and over again. This is the 3rd book or film type that I have seen/ read which features an "on the spectrum" individual who is literal and organized and neat and precise to an nth and exact degree. Professor T series comes to mind. Or Prose's Molly the Maid. Regardless, there IS so much to confront, contort, misdirect, fail in emotional response or reaction etc. etc. etc. I could go on and on with that phrase. And it is super entertaining for both the Wife Project and the Father Project in this particular novel. BUT, but, but- it is still rather a one trick pony overdriving condition, approach, plotting. So much one thing that it gets repetitious and at times exhausting. You, the reader, DOES know which way it will go. I do in these- all the time.Reading a few s for this book, AFTER I read the book- there is a reaction I must not fail to address. The point that some posters seem offended by using a person with OCD or autism or any human syndrome as a topic for a humor tract. That's ridiculous, IMHO- to be offended by the very real aspects of such conditions because there is laughter. It is a laughing with and not at that I see here in the Rosie Project. Never bullying either. And the association people/characters are almost every one- decent and good intent. Not all, but most. I would probably read #2 but doubt I would go beyond that point if this was a longer series. I don't at all relish watching sit. com. material on TV either. All except for Seinfeld. His varied and was almost always humor done perfectly on the edge between funny and deeply homo sapiens....more

title: Goodbye, Eastern Europe: An Intimate History of a Divided Land
author: Mikanowski, Jacob
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This is a book to own and to read in 20 or 30 page increments at a time. It is too much to take in and process reading it whole piece.Fabulous eyes toThis is a book to own and to read in 20 or 30 page increments at a time. It is too much to take in and process reading it whole piece.Fabulous eyes to millennia of this geographic region. Taken in combo with Prisoners of Geography by Tim Marshall and you'll have a much more solid understanding of everlasting invasion and dominion by Russian or European or Islamic empires. Plus how the old mountain ranges have stamped a tremulous fate as the Appalachians have in North America.The s here do not do this book justice.Even the concept of nation state STILL remains murkier than nearly anywhere else on Earth. Mixed tribes, mixed languages, always diverse and mixed major religions. Cultural mores closer to the Vikings than to the Romans. A mix of climate and also the traipse spaces of almost every past supply / trade route. Divided and sub-divided and divided inside the divides.Knowing so many from Poland, Lithuania, Latvia, Croatia, Ukraine and in every age of my life. Not only 1st generation but original immigrants. Most of them original immigrants in either youth or middle aged. Many middle aged. And they all did it the correct and lawful ways. Even now in this tawdry and lawless time. This made me understand somewhat. Only somewhat of their "eyes". The last 100 years in Eastern Europe has been a type of everlasting square dance for survival. Hopefully landing on the right square at the right time.Now? That's probably another whole book to be yet written. Looking from the outside in will be even murkier for some parts of this world NOW than it was 50 years ago....more

title: While Idaho Slept: The Hunt for Answers in the Murders of Four College Students
author: Appelman, J. Reuben*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This title tells you exactly what is inside the copy. It's fully 3.5 stars and quite worth the read. It taught me details about Idaho's courts and jusThis title tells you exactly what is inside the copy. It's fully 3.5 stars and quite worth the read. It taught me details about Idaho's courts and justice system too. Death penalty does exist- even to the point of firing squad for specific last choice reasonings. The case is truly horrendous. 4 killed within probably less than 20 minutes in the wee small hours of the morning- after 4 am. Winter already come to Northern Idaho in Nov. Knifed with enough bloodletting to actually drain through the floorboard and cement to the outside. The entire 3 story subdivision has recently been leveled for a memorial site.You won't get a lot of answers spelled out- only the hunt for them. And the life stories and tangents of the police officers, other sleeping residents, neighbors, families of victims- all get as much coverage as the lives of the victims do. Which is not necessarily a bad thing but for my read the balance is far off here. To motives? To why they were "chosen"? To when it happened? Very outlier and really nearly unanswerable. Also the author makes what I judge as rather unethical statements about crime in general. Drug crimes ARE major crimes. They kill all the time.So the copy does do a lot of suppositional parsing instead. But it gives you minute and second info for the Greek strip college lifestyle. UGH! Wouldn't be my kid under the most or any scholarship etc. circumstances. 3-4 am Jack in the Box grub hub deliveries just part of the "usual". DNA and cell phone records! Where would ANY of this justice scenario be without them. Similar to many of the worst group kill stranger murder spree examples I have read- unsolved. In the past, these were nearly never solved. Nor were many missing forever humans found for outcomes or answered for "where/why?"Is he still in a 6" x 6" metal room in a facility of just 37 inmates? I will have to read about that and the trial within elsewhere reporting. No final answers to eventual outcomes here beyond the mourning by all. Perhaps he is awaiting a 5 month delay? Idaho holds rules for media quite, quite beyond the "free" visibility and inclusions within some other states.Too long by about 1/3rd of it's length- this book. Giving everyone a separate chapter/ part within 20 plus people? Not a fan.I never heard of the "snowfall" vision syndrome before. That was the least of this murderer's problems. Once again, and sorry for the generalization- because I have made it. Watch all those Phd candidates without adequate social skills. Photos are 4 star quality but not inclusive at all. I'm guessing he got no permissions from the deceased victims' families? Or they rejected having their loved ones' so pictured. Even in past portraits? Only bar pictures of the girls at a distance are included. Police and locales have numerous photos....more

review: 2023 was an exceptional year for finding 5 star gems from the past. More than in most years by far. I started the year 2023 with a 5 star  and m2023 was an exceptional year for finding 5 star gems from the past. More than in most years by far. I started the year 2023 with a 5 star  and might end with one as well. Very much outlier.It was a year of vast changes in my life. Some of them hard but all of them lucky. September and October and well into November rather a blur because my oldest son was close to death's door with a brain aneurysm. My girlfriend from youth who moved to Kentucky had most of the Midwest and all of that state praying for him on prayer trees. And he after two brain surgeries and 4 coils has been cleared with NO exceptions to normal life activities. He's 55 now and we didn't think he'd get there. Hope he takes the hint for an early retirement as I did. Earlier, perhaps. Over the years all the books I read on my deck in MI! That's now past too. Everything changes. Even the most willful and energetic decline with age. Do I admit it. But will I miss that view. Not only in summer either.Thanks to all the Goodreads friends who lead me to books from long ago that would/ should never deserve to become unread in any age. Few are the people still reading many of them. A Grazia Deledda or Mitford or Lofts or Maugham. Authors I would probably never have found any other way.So thank you to the Goodreads people and the University of Chicago Hospital for a 2023 not forgotten. Happy Reading and make your challenges MORE than you should realistically.J...more

Or young adult.This is not a book to read for much inspirational energy or enthusiasm. Quite the opposite. In fact it could go quite solidly with little commenting or exceptions into my "Life is shit and then you die" category of books. As the author consistently self notes his own inability to love, it is doubly so in that category. Even at times, himself. A very good writer (4 star prose), and also quite fully a philosophical thinking/ mode personality depressant. On a great day, he would be up to half spirit for seeing the quiet moments of any joy AS joy. Or to be "in the moment" enough to live the positive attributes of that particular moment.It also is representative of a clear window of/to his own thoughts. He is always trying to use his real life for applications to screenwriter work. He copies and posits imitation. To be his wife had to be EXHAUSTING.The duo stories of length are well chosen but center on death. Death in different types of guises but more closely on human reactions in our most dire situational times. It does absolutely make strangers come together. review: This is going to be hard to beat for non-fiction that I read in 2024. It isn't just the precise nature of the subject matter to detail and research anThis is going to be hard to beat for non-fiction that I read in 2024. It isn't just the precise nature of the subject matter to detail and research and demographics and stats either. It's the tone of his discourse and the entire PART II of what to do for changing the current reality. Specific courses for cures to this immense disrespect and lack of strengths and self-control in our industrialized cultures' current children. And they aren't as hard to do as most parents think right now, IMHO. It's just the way and method of love supported, love in action, and love in response to peers- how that is learned/ role modeled too- needs to change.I completely and totally disagree that this author lacks in compassion. In fact, I really think in his multiple cultural examples and role modeling courses observed alone- he is of a kind and ultimately compassionate nature. Letting those whose brains have not matured decide what reaction "can" be and how to treat others and also learn, excel, move, eat etc. That is the opposite of compassion. Because self-control and entire consciousness (self-consciousness to mood and activity as well) are essentially scarred when children decide. Loved, loved the scales of adolescence and childhoods in regard to other species and to hunter-gatherer and other vastly different cultures. And the essence of parenting also strongly differing from those druthers we hold as "true" or "good" parenting in the West. And the differences by continent / country and so much else that reflects in what is being learned in formal education, as well.That entire listing of core values (set into listed points- precise goals re their relative importances) in Japan vs U. S. was 6 stars. Letting people become self destroying loose cannons with huge medication habits their entire lives is NOT being compassionate. I've seen far too many adults who have lived that entire (and also quite shortened) reality. That's only one of the core issues examined in this terrific non-fiction treatise that enumerates EXACTLY what it is the title.Tech use vs going to play. Not the only issue but a HUGE one....more

They are carved characters when with the two primes in association.This is 5 star life onus and core (nuance incredible) for the actor prime himself. For the actress who became his wife- it is 4 star, IMHO. But extremely deep and intrepid for her core self love consistency. One of his best woman to/in relationships or as an individual that Maugham wrote, as well. But Julia is acting at all times, and that also seems, to me, Maugham's summation of female nature itself as he observed it. I enjoyed it to a 4.5 stars level. Dialogue is fabulous and this is tops in class savvy and intrinsic understanding of that firm grasp and hold upon the arts which was the fairly owned onus for this time/ society by the class of gentlemen and their ladies.I think its flaw is that there is so much heavy handed theatre play and manners of development for production in detail for the time that it gets super difficult to follow for those who are not versed in the material and subject matters of the popular productions. Shakespeare is the exception, but most readers will not know plots or scripts, nor the leading writers/stars in performance of that day. So some minor context to minutia (or humor?)may get missed.No more of the plot or of course, the obsessions- but read it. The final thought I almost always have after reading Maugham is that he puts his "elderly women" of travails at about 43-48 years old and ends their appeal and sexual lives at that point, almost universally. title: Chicago: City on the Make
author: Algren, Nelson
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Some of what he says here is accurate and vital. It's still corrupt and it's eternally backwards for supporting evil perps and making the victims of tSome of what he says here is accurate and vital. It's still corrupt and it's eternally backwards for supporting evil perps and making the victims of them the truly punished. But I knew GIANTS and saw much 1950's-1980's (those years especially) which make this poetry rant extremely flawed. As well as being bitter. Owned too maybe on a wide scale, but not for the life he had. Wanting more. Growth and success beyond scopes of many living now in any part of the USA-beyond their imaginings- I have seen. And it wasn't just the lucky or correct demographic either. Many related to me built the very towers. (Plaster in 100 floors to Palmer House artistry).Being born at 5602 S. Racine in 1948- neither my love or disdain is anywhere near Algren's. Not even after 75 plus years. And I am the one behind the corner store (different kind all the time) in most every generation since. The ones he said had not a chance within fine and abusive poetry.It IS a vast plain of grey with humongous suburbs of green around it. And always spreading. But the city itself is on decline and this is accelerating now after at least 30 years of solid downhill. Still as fiddled and still as intrepid yet. Both.Because I disliked the corny (self considered swank) style of this author and era so much- I often failed to see the relevance overall for the gushing aspects. He misses some extremes in the events he cores of the earliest 20th century at that. And nearly everything but the constant strong oppositional attitudes. Well, I would make this far too long if I got into details. But Algren was truthful in the fact and reality that it holds crux very unlike most other American cities. And the neighborhoods' cultures also hold wider dimensions of both greater acting love and deserved animosities. Holding maybe 15 to 20 great jobs from 1965 to 1975 alone? Algren had SO little window into opportunity for the 20 to 30 years AFTER this was written. He was bitter. Probably justifiably. But ranting in prose poetry often made that fact even less pretty than that condition becomes.This made me think. Especially the Afterword. I have 5 dearest (maybe 6 depending upon how you judge locale by "from away" or by home people) being spit in and out every single day. Not only weekdays. Every grown grandchild but one, in fact. All medical (who could have guessed)! And a child of my own who had his own life saved this very September by medical technique probably available only 3 places on the Earth. So when humans reach for stars or don't listen to the naysayers and whiners- yes, you may make a mess along the way. For sure.Studs Terkel:The Pottawattomies were much too square. They left  nothing behindbut their dirty river.While we shall leave, for remembrance, one rusty iron heart.The city's rusty heart, that holdsboth the hustler and the square.Takes them both and holds them there.For keeps and a single day.(Read Studs Terkel's Working- much better.)...more

title: A Painted House
author: Grisham, John*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This was just a smidgeon away from 5 stars. At times the baseball (which I love and can hear about with pleasure) sequences went too long and became tThis was just a smidgeon away from 5 stars. At times the baseball (which I love and can hear about with pleasure) sequences went too long and became too front loaded with sentimentality. Nevertheless hating the Yankees is always real, that's true.Plot, characters and intense melodramas all over. Loved it. And Luke is memorial. Many kids of that era (I am one)- were years and years above their physical ages. Mainly due to both roaming and responsibility in huge proportions. Most of which since about 1990 or so- is generally now ruled as factors of child abuse. Working cotton or cloth bolts, in stores of nearly every nature, small machines like blenders churns/ pumps, stocking shelves, unloading trucks, garden (hours and hours just like Luke) all part of the normal kids' lives. It was for me. I also worked Pearl's counter before I was 8.This setting and the economics of that system in Arkansas cotton farming in 1950's! It really comes home even now- why migration North happened in droves. Not at all only from Arkansas.Loved the prose flow and it was a pleasure to read this book. And I can't say that is true for at least 10 books out of the last 20 I've read. No switching, no era jumps, no context discontinuity here. YES! I'm a fan.But what I loved the very most was the family, religion, community feel. Do I miss it. Totally gone in almost all places but the smallest towns now, and at times not even there. Too much about "identity" division is just the tip of the iceberg to all that. No manners in even asking- now you are literally invaded or robbed. It was a really good tale to read in late Fall, early Winter too- in the rain. Picking cotton is awful. So is picking blueberries. I've done both. A day or two is doable but after that it just gets to be torture in the postures needed....more

title: Reeds in the Wind
author: Deledda, Grazia
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Nearing the very end of 2023, I fine this read to be one of the top 5 most authentic voices for the books I've read during this year. Other than W. SoNearing the very end of 2023, I fine this read to be one of the top 5 most authentic voices for the books I've read during this year. Other than W. Somerset Maugham-I can't think of any author who represents the individual "eyes" of where, when it "was" as well as this Grazia Deledda does. Her characters here- especially Efix! They are what they believe and what they represent. Almost purely themselves. Others call it a "carried guilt"- but it is more than just knowing one's own essence beyond guilt or joys or history. It is completely of its own time and place. Sardinia during the earliest years of the 1900's. It happens to be completely contemporary to the lives my Grandparents lived in Sicily as children or as teens at the turn of the 20th century. It's onus -the core of this entire place and the tale's message is obscure but it is THIS. It is a long term conspiracy (by only 1 individual? or by 50)for keeping the young (young is often relative too) and the families who exist where they are "now". And not join the lost- which are those who have left. Or if by some impossible circumstance, to contain and keep the ones who were "left" and have returned to their proper farm and village. And proper role for the order of this culture beyond just the "staying". Nobles and their houses lost! Or just for now sleeping!The tale is difficult to read. It almost reads like magical realism. But it could not be more real or more representative of the times of mass emigration. Because the spiritual, the myths, the nature, and the sprites are constantly present in the strictures of Italian country culture. And acting daily for their roles and retributions. The dialogue is difficult for 21st century minds to grasp. You almost need to interpret the gist and the discussed reality of the speakers as if you were translating a language base. Be aware, this does not have great length- but the depth is so immense that it will take much time to read. I would probably have given this excellent work a 5, if I knew less about the whys and wherefores and reality of why the young planned their escapes and then just did it. And almost all were never seen by their families again. My Sicilian grandparents never saw any of their birth families (individuals/ siblings/ parents) who didn't leave or ANY in the older generations left behind. Not once. Nor their country again. Nor their birth continent again. And just like here, there were terrible sicknesses, poverty to leave behind as well.This is a book that I absolutely believe very few readers of our current period would like for several reasons. You need to "get" the undercurrent of the restrictions for female and also even more-the entire established senses of places and honor. It is almost entirely dominated by the cultural mores which put the average human's belief system of what IS corporal or REAL in an entirely separate sphere from what the 21st century mindset now sets as "the real" or "true". Or even perhaps of the entire last century before that for some readers' "knowing". Because here the spiritual, the mental, the moral AND the physical "rules" are far, far more absolutes. Never subjective, always fixed. Some of you may understand this difference between objective and subjective core belief....more

But still, the fence of believability? I couldn't jump over it and thus it lost a star. Not even for the present state of 2024 levels trashy urban thriller narcissism. For one thing people of such lacks to morality and able to perform such vile actions as these crimes were- DO (DID in pairs here all the time) talk among themselves (and also with wider audience of characters too) WAY too much not to give huge hints or observations or facts of adjacent reality away. In some cases, the hired P. I. would be no necessity whatsoever.Actually, this one- I don't really recommend as much as others have here. I have too many Goodreads friends who don't like reading about evil perps enough to plow through the 400 plus pages. As good as Ellis writes- I did think the flow was choppy in this one. Time frames are often not at all noted or established until you are into the 3rd page of an intervening section. The Before Halloween or After Halloween only helped me for specific time sequence after I was 1/2 way through the entire book. Plus you doubt who the narrator is until you read the 2nd or 3rd page of their phone call or in person interchange etc. Purposely keeping you in question for the context of the two or three speakers. And if you don't like to read porn situations? If it had not been as clever in plotting as it was, I would have given this a 3. So many sex encounters in verbosity style- and the dialogue? Meh! Outlander this was not.I did like the placements. Not reality Chicago- but he still did a good job. Well, others will give you more details. But I do not feel this was a full 4 stars for me. Closer to a 3.5 stars rounded up for the depths of insincerity and backstabbing accomplished....more

review: So good that gushing won't convey. They WILL take you to another time and place. Islands and heat to soggy chill of a raining empire.Melodramas, soap So good that gushing won't convey. They WILL take you to another time and place. Islands and heat to soggy chill of a raining empire.Melodramas, soap operas, context of relationships re class or situational path! All superlative. And yes they are very much each of those things. This is THEATRE in print before film was in any way digital or began to grab an ion of the color scheme. This book needs to be owned. If you have read his novels or at least a goodly portion of them, you will meet some of the same characters in the short stories. Many lengths here, and that NEEDS to be mentioned. Some are quite short, mere pages- The Bum, for instance. Obsessions (not just of love interest or sexual consort) but miniscule nuance of purpose are sliced thin and seasoned for ultimate flavors. Super savvy eyes from one who is primarily looking from the outside/in. To nearly everything too of "norm" convections. Art, marriage, music, poetry, English words! And the only true sin is putting up with boredom.The English men of a certain class in this period of the earliest years of the 20th century until WWII- you might never know their souls' crux until you read Maugham. And his short stories cut closest to the bone at that.Only my opinion, but in English- probably the best flow and context to core motives/ character identities of any short stories collection. title: Cakes and Ale
author: Maugham, W. Somerset
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: With every novel or collection I read of Maugham I think it is "the best". And then I read the next one.This one is perfection despite the beginning fWith every novel or collection I read of Maugham I think it is "the best". And then I read the next one.This one is perfection despite the beginning feeling and continuation for some time as tell rather than show. But I LOVE the way Maugham looks back and yet HE is ever the person he was then as much as he is in his NOW. Both being quite unlike but also just as immensely savvy.There is a priceless section of about 10 pages in the middle of the 100's (by count pages in my paperback edition) that does the best critique of fiction writers for his age or any other. And this is coming from a person who 90% of the time LOATHES writers trilling on about writing itself. This is entirely outlier to that usual discourse this takes for the 100 years since, as well. I did laugh out loud. Bad writing is just now in English- more than identical in comparisons for the level of BAD. Worse for the word and prose flow habits he describes exquisitely.It was called satire in the trailer here. No. Nothing like satire as it is defined in the 21st century presently. Now satire contains 75% snot and snark. Also anger at points. This doesn't hold 1% of that element. Maugham at 16 to 21 (as he is here in much of this tale- and telling it 25 years plus later) is a snob of his class that wouldn't KNOW unkind or raw comment to other males, let alone a female. His manners are THAT embedded.Rosie is one of those characters you will NEVER forget if you read this. For some reason I was brought to mind of Alfred Hitchcock or writers like Dickens who have wild and loose women with hearts of gold. Women who are unable to pass a negative word about others, least of all their comrades. In the American South they would be comparable to the "Bless your heart" women. You also get here the man-who this author truly was. He knows schmooze to the max and has perfected it over a lifetime. ALL THE CONNECTIONS he needs, plus all the associations he wants. And he doesn't need to do it much by praise either. Or flawed fawning. But by ultimate best placements and availabilities whenever his own druthers of vast travel or possible intrepid adventures do not raise their heads. And does he know where to cut and balk at the same time.One of the best reflections of these earliest years of the 20th century that I have ever read for this particular class and placement. Absolutely. Cakes and Ale can hardly be appreciated within the times we hold though. I don't think present young or general populations of English readers at all appreciate this language depth or form of conversational patterns. Or even understand the nuance of a good portion of it. English has lost its vast vocabulary by 1000's of words as well since Maugham's youth and prime of life era. So sad.If he was alive today he would be a better screenwriter than Horowitz....more

review: For me this was a one sit down read which was 3.5 stars. I rounded it to 4 for the before and after author's comments, especially those after the end.For me this was a one sit down read which was 3.5 stars. I rounded it to 4 for the before and after author's comments, especially those after the end. Explaining why and how he chose to do this novella. Fully half of the book is in italics as it is a written diary or papers being read by the author or by others at a latter time than when they were written. It nearly made me drop it to a 3, as I cannot stand that print form at length and actually cannot read it well anymore. Slows me down considerably. But to be fair- it was a good premise and he did this entire scenario quite well. And most are underrating it, IMHO. Yes, it's simplified. But actually it is NOT unrealistic or as over the top as 4 out of 5 horrendous dysfunction family and mystery stuff is presently (2023). Many times I questioned Ashley's responses or reactions to being left by Emma in her own house or town as much as she clearly was doing. So I knew from nearly the get-go that so much was off. Far beyond what Ashley perceived.Perfect for a sit down in front of a fireplace or after 30 people leave (a huge holiday party and most of the cleanup is done). Not a feel good in anyway- which is also quite outlier for Christmas. But I'm glad the author took the chance to do something outside of his particular length and success box. Don't recommend for those who love Hallmark Christmas movies, or any of the classics of film fare with bell ringing endings. This is quite another animal....more

title: The Romanov Brides
author: McHugh, Clare*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This I enjoyed to a 4 star level as well as finding the prose flow better than average- 4 stars.It's not an easy tale to tell. Set into the world of tThis I enjoyed to a 4 star level as well as finding the prose flow better than average- 4 stars.It's not an easy tale to tell. Set into the world of the second half of Queen Victoria's reign, but far from only in England. This is the tale of the last Tsars of Russia and also of the many German principalities and nobles within Europe of those times. Especially to the grandchildren of Queen Victoria herself. So the more you know about the Victorian era reigning families on the whole- the more you will probably like this informative tale. Most especially about, but not excluding numerous cousins, the children of Queen Victoria's daughter, Alice. Alice who died young. Her daughters Ella and Alix (Elisabeth and Alexandra) are featured in particular.I was enthralled during the first half. Became much more patient and could leave this and yet always return- during the 2nd half. Because it does NOT become a simple tell tale whatsoever. Always more tangled and complex as religious strictures, family loyalties, distances of contact and also intense (in many cases) personal relationships beyond just the duty measured by blood decree or birth culture as they strongly occur. Most stridently of all for those of Alice's children who looked East to marry into Russia as a Romanov Bride. Something their Grandmother, the English Queen does not at all desire nor does she approve.It is entirely of its own time in the telling. Personalities differ in the many characters, of course, but the cultural mores, tenets, boundaries, moral value senses- are all deeply seated in the 19th century. So much so, that the realities to reign/rule of the 20th century scurry too far away for even imaging. No more so than for those who will be most highly effected.You will need to peruse the relationship graphs at the beginning. And some readers will use them during the read itself. Large families for the great majority of ruling class itself and Victoria's offspring in particular. And you might also see the path of the inherited genetic blood disease as well. It's main negative as a novel is that the last marriage is SO difficult in happening and takes years of contriving to achieve. In real time it did. It cannot be manufactured otherwise for print. But reading years of this courting dance are SLOW going- reflected in others' eyes. Hard to make it otherwise. But not as easy to read. That gets to be tell, tell, tell, and gossip cabals on overrun.Because I know the history, I knew what was coming- but for those who don't this may be another type of experience in the slower portions. But I still very much enjoyed the length of forming and connection to Nicholas and Alexandra themselves as s couple.. Alix was a whole lot tougher than I thought. She had to have been....more

review: Superb time and place character carving. And the English prose, the flow to melodious English clause sequencing, is even better. This author can writeSuperb time and place character carving. And the English prose, the flow to melodious English clause sequencing, is even better. This author can write rings around most others of his century, and so far I have not found one from this current century that comes close. And that doesn't suggest that the pace of the novel is similar in part to part (chapters) at all. Here he even suggests you might want to skip the one near the ending which topic covers humans and their God sense to "what's it all about, Alfie" psychology/philosophy/structural religious belief spectrum.6 or 7 exquisitely defined characters which are often most revealed in their dialogues. Often with each other or with the narrator who is the author. Although in this particular Maugham novel I feel that the author was also intrinsic and autobiographical in stances to /with his character Eliot. This is a read that is deep. Covers continents and places extremely varied, and is cored on the character of Larry. And read it when you have time to think and not while multi-tasking. Most of us never schedule such a time. Do, if you can.Once again, I do think Maugham does the men to perfection while never quite getting to that pinnacle with the women. 90% of the time they radiate only from men's aspects to and with them. Within millennia of human word recording, language- it possibly may be true that much of the time too that onus was closer to true? I do not know but it may have been.It's not a perfect book. At times he jumps and it gets a trifle choppy. But he tells you when it is out of sequence of time- also to the precise message that he has tried to relay so the READER can incur the reality in chronological order of their occurrence and fall outs. This was taken within 2 days in two long sit down reads. I would never do it truly piecemeal.Reading a book and author in this splendid melodrama heights and luscious mode of words like this one- and in a direct to reader style? It makes me smile but then I am reminded that I have little hope of outliving the atrocious endemic styles of hopping, switching, duo or triple regurgitating forms of the current fiction. Even some of the better carved to character.Well worth doing a trio of movies, let alone two. But not with Bill Murray as Larry. That has got to be one of the most miscast roles of all time. Almost as bad as Tom Cruise being Reacher.Strongly recommend this read if you have never read it. I am rereading most of Maugham that I had read before too. He's best with the knowledge of age added. This one was written in age too- you sure can tell. Brilliant!Also I find I have to add this- you will get synopsis up the kudzu on this one. If you are the kind of person who loves knowledge seeking (returns to school or classes on skills to attain too) many times over a lifetime or seeks change and variety in work endlessly- you will ADORE this novel. There aren't a lot of us- but reading about them is easier than living most of it. Both within family, economics, experiences allowed and also pure risk. Because he was raised only by his father who was intrepid and just let him loose. It forms self-identity and independence way, way before any norm of "now-a-days" does. And was even more "different" then.His father's story is also enthralling. Dick Carlson was sure a pistol. Moore did this superbly to Tucker's core self-identity judgments of importance and various directions he has taken. His personality is not that of an elite, nor even of any norm for 2023. His value system is much simpler.The pure evil of violence in groups that have physically and verbally attacked all of them (friends and relatives too) at his home! With wife and his 4 children (daughter in college story made my blood boil)- if anything is understated here. I very much disagree with posters who say this was rushed and doesn't cover intrinsic biography. Quite the opposite. Because he is not a joiner. Not a conformist to party. It shows, and doesn't have to just tell.Kudos to Moore. Very difficult job. Tucker Carson is not a person I thought was omnipotent or was a subject of nearly adoration as some of the ers here display at all. But I understand Tucker. He is not a bs pretty language lover. He was always bored and broke rules because of it. He is truthful for observing outcomes nearly completely. And he doesn't groupthink. I don't either. I really have an inkling that people who live groupthink core concepts as "true" will always have a hard time and hatred for a word smith like Tucker.It was fun to learn he reads constantly as I always have. But he was terrible in school- with his experiences allowed he probably outgrew it by 12....more

review: 3.5 stars rounded up for the research, graphics and detail. This also had the best politico context and maps for several situations (both during/ after 1871 and also latter fires)- that I have seen. And I have seen what is in Regenstein (U. of Chicago).But it was not easy to read- it is text book accuracy and pace. But also with so many name drops and situational momentary or month long at a time stances- hard to digest. 100's of characters and yet you did get the blame games and other nuances of both short and long term. Some in court case judgments. Mrs. O'Leary was the typical scrape goat. What is best about this telling is the approaching and true relevance (example times 100's) of the energy and general mania of that time period in Chicago. And also much later- well into the 1960's at least. Not entirely gone now but so much reduced in the 21st century- that it is not the same core quantity or strength of/for conceptual direction. Dirty politics, corruption or directionless rhetoric of ever evolving blame games- it did go from to eternal "we can do" (populace and leaderships of all types) to vast areas of "we can take or grab" endlessly as a common core mantra. I call it the "be the least you can be" individual commodity held in vast Chicago areas now. Both visually and with intersecting conversations all around now for most any Chicago location practical outing or intersect.Loved the photos and graphics quite beyond some of the generalizations which do not always surround them in the copy. And are just that, generalizations for what was then extremely small locales.The energy and pure power of optimism and cutting through bs and bureaucracy to fulfill all the physical doing and the people who work process of such in Chicago still does exist. But not even in a one to ten ratio to what it was. The book does rather imply a similar path overall to that direction, but also has vast areas of void, IMHO. Like how the immense areas of decline occurred within great geographic realities during migrations in this and latter periods (which he covers somewhat for other factions) is not adequately (or even correctly) detailed by Berg. Also I think the book did way too much on the politico cabals and people who left Chicago and should have done a bit more about fallout from the fire to latter excellence in 100 different forms. How it acted upon innovation instead of doing the opposite after disaster as it has elsewhere. (Like within architecture or myriad of industries such as candy or meat.)...more
