title: Reef Road
author: Royce, Deborah Goodrich*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: It is 2.5 stars for the character development. It is 1.5 stars for the continuity and wholeness as a novel. So I can't round it up to 3. My enjoyment It is 2.5 stars for the character development. It is 1.5 stars for the continuity and wholeness as a novel. So I can't round it up to 3. My enjoyment was 3 stars until I hit into the page 90's plus and thereafter it was a 2. Picked up the read at least 3 to 4 times after the half and almost made it a DNF. There was a point around page 220 that I considered skipping all the "Writer's Thoughts" sections, but I did not. I was too mesmerized by then to believe she was on repeat, rinse, repeat AGAIN. And despite all that verbiage you didn't get connection between characters in most time or locale or relationship context at all. It felt like studying details for a test?The only reason I DID finish was because I had not read this author before and wondered how the heck she was going to pull in so many wandering story lines over a period of century's worth eras. Not to speak of the "Writer's" named sections which could have gone anywhere. Teaching or preaching or repeated theorizing about past wars etc. It was almost like a grade school history teacher or hippie activist (is there such a thing?- probably in 2020 plus there is) gone rouge. Truly, I can't remember a book in the last 10 years that I've read that has gone "off subject" as much as this one did. And she would repeat entire sequences of "butterfly effect" on emotions for the same exact person within the nearly identical wording over and over. Was this edited? I doubt it.In conclusion, I will never read another of hers. Every character over 6 years old was despicable on top of it. And also rather stupid at that. The locale was rather icky too- as I got sick of hearing about bugs.It is shocking to me that so many have given this high star ratings when it has such POOR prose wording. It reads in flow and in English words usage like the rambling diary of a below average student who is a Junior in high school. This person never met a Thesaurus....more

title: Fatal Legacy        (Flavia Albia #11)
author: Davis, Lindsey
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This is quite outlier to the series Flavia Albia in its depth. Not that the humor isn't still there- but it is more a sit. com. type of humor with mosThis is quite outlier to the series Flavia Albia in its depth. Not that the humor isn't still there- but it is more a sit. com. type of humor with mostly one liners. Because the case directions themselves are buried in various and at times nearly oppositional interpretations of laws. Roman laws.So you have a treatise on minutia of manumission status interpretations rather than a case of criminal deed as the central focus. And this is so true. An informer is not always going about because of a body or missing goods or some other dire assault factor solutions for retributions etc.For me this just dragged. And I am one who on the whole likes to ponder or list or number note the various declensions of formal governmental laws. But in this case? Too many characters to keep track of and I felt the eruditeness of the whole didn't not meld well with the usual Tiberius and Flavia humor. I did like that she got Flavia's sisters in the act for awhile.So for me the pace flow just seemed stymied with dozens of asides. I would rather have heard more about what was going to be done with the usable bricks taken from Fountain Court. Davis's knowledge of the Roman Law and the various curlicues of sidestepping it are more than impressive. Like another current situation I can think of- the downfall and failure of any good system is met with ever increasing corruption, mostly embedded within cronyism. It WAS a hard job that Flavia took on this time. Just not one that is linear in any way to read about. So despite the credible ending, most of this read just dragged. It felt like a much longer book than what it actually was. Never a good sign. One of my 3 least favorite Flavia for sure....more

Kathleen Stock defines and explains in philosophy the works of so many previous theories and feminist wave or gender treatises of the past. And their following to law etc. Excellent book. Academia spread and wholly swallowed by many non-doctors and governmental entities in the UK. Over a fairly short period of time, as well. Kudos for the REAL numbers in UK etc. that she has tried to determine, as well. Because in my courses of study the percentages in many fields of these identity self-namings and/or conditions have been way, way off for any count / treat/ or report studies done here (USA) as well. As have the suicide stats I have heard in many media venues. Reality done very well. Simple language but very difficult to approach the concepts defined in some of the former heralded works. Women need to be protected not only in sports either. XX and XY DNA does matter. And some of the practices for underage? A real medical rethink is needed.The best chapter was on the problems of real medical people trying to treat some of the victims of disease who have conditions or outcomes from conditions of gender reassignment etc. Harm with no idea of long term outcomes are despicable, IMHO.Once again a subject matter that consistently gets ad hominem or just plain vitriol in response if not swallowed and regurgitated in the matter that the woke determine is the correct mantra. review: Since it is a flashback to the Reacher who in 1992 is still in the Army after the demotion- some of the prime Reacher "facts" have not yet happened. NSince it is a flashback to the Reacher who in 1992 is still in the Army after the demotion- some of the prime Reacher "facts" have not yet happened. Nor the constantly moving individual lifestyle the key.But overall, considering the writing by the duo and several other factors of doing this after 27 or so other Reacher, it isn't as bad as it might have been.STILL- it barely got to 3. The writing is brisk and fast moving. Nothing at all to truly contemplate, IMHO- because repetition of the "knowns" in the team set up to stop the killings is nearly constant. And because I remember those years well, it could have gotten much more time savvy specific.It has the Reacher base thought/ responses that ARE Reacher. (The last one or two in the series of aging Reacher I thought were not on that track at all- Reacher did not own the same set of moral codes nor did he estimate/contemplate adversary in a Reacher sense). So therefore, I did think this one was better overall then those last few. BUT- still never beyond a 2.5 stars in plot, nor in overall executions. Not for lack of the Reacher fisticuffs etc. per se, but for the murderers' deeds and continual successes. Yes, these were not at all believable. These (murdered) were people who had dense past lives and all 6 or 7 of them would never have been as stupid to fall for the set ups as posited. Most especially for the one who tried to rescue himself just because he saw this woman laying on a ledge. Never happen. Also the Denver one on the lake. NOPE!Well, it was entertaining to about a 3 also. But not at all on the intellectual nor nuance of emotion that many of the former Reacher owned in spades. I did not mind the plot diversions. The super high body count and several of the serendipity messes Reacher did encounter did NOT raise the entire platform for me at all though. When it gets to such flashback stages, it may be time to end the series. This makes me appreciate those who can get past #30 and have them GET BETTER. Like Donna Leon with Brunetti in Venice....more

review: It's a fun read despite the time period because of her voice and pace. Her narrator voice throughout sounds and feels like a valley of interruptions bIt's a fun read despite the time period because of her voice and pace. Her narrator voice throughout sounds and feels like a valley of interruptions between exclamation points. So much information being shared over the top enthusiasm style. Her Dad and Mom stories both- 4 star enjoyable and so very real. And Italian cultural.But having liked her other stuff I've read better, I get the idea of a hyper teenager effusing in this one.The second half I felt was jumpy in a way that for me made it hard to follow. (I had to reread because she does time warps and skips and returns?) I did love the moving and the views of different Italian cities and especially in those times of ever changing logistics. Before, during and after several decades she describes, I thought it was truly an accurate picture that the Socialist, Communist true believers activists so clearly portrayed in most cases (having 5 kids, 2 kids, 8 kids etc.) didn't seem to work jobs or have much of any understanding for how or what or when their money came in or out. Idea people with heavy goods supplied pasts.Sad, and fearful times indeed. And yet she states on repeats that they just carried on before/ during/ after occupations in the same, nearly identical ways. Almost, as the usual.Her humor is embedded despite the memoir holding some of the true evil essences of the times and places. Too many characters and too rushed a voice for me to grasp the types of depth she was attempting....more

At page 90, I hope the rest is as good. Making me laugh. I wish I could operate tracking or studies on DSM 5 characteristics honed in the Psych. doctors themselves. Well worth doing.Review/reaction after the read was completed:Well, the rest was nearly as good. And at points, for me, funnier too. Every doc gets their flaw and crime history outed! Classic closed room mystery and it followed most of the 10 rules Agatha's club put into writing way back in 1929. EXCEPT one of the red flags was so flagrant of a tell that I knew who the perp was at page 120. So I have read way too many of these. I do know it.There was a little too much over the top too, too at the ending. Embellishments that would be good for film though. Especially with Alana's outcome and also the shooting in the leg. (NEVER, NEVER, NEVER purposely done like that in the real world- EVER under those circumstances most particularly.) But it is fiction. Another thing that truly bugged me all the way through was King's role. Campus guards and police do NOT work hand in hand as they did here for intermixed jurisdiction for/with community police in any level- not even with Feds inputs if it occurs. Can North Carolina be that outlier? Nope.Fiction is fun. And this one was fun. Almost old school in its literal takes for the 7 main characters under suspicion, as well. review: Well, it isn't perfect. In fact, it took me some time to embed. For my read the first quarter was slow to snail-like and way too mundane to strike anyWell, it isn't perfect. In fact, it took me some time to embed. For my read the first quarter was slow to snail-like and way too mundane to strike any deep interest. In fact, I nearly dropped it and made it a DNF. 4 stars for most of the read but the hauntings approached THIS well make it 5 stars. Understanding the year /era differences from the get-go still kept some of the middle portion murky. But the switching didn't much change the tone of the nuance or conversations. You are plotted clearly in baby and kiddy years momma's territory with all the associations inherent.But the MOOD! Outlandishly 5 stars all the way. Only a few books (out of 100's I've read in this genre) even come close. Haunting of Hill House or We Have Always Lived in the Castle territory good.Please, please forgive me. I could go very long but I will not. But if there is a movie producer out there with some true instincts- grab this one. Collins did this in print- but the visuals would be 5 times better in film. At least! I can see the mistletoe entrapping and entrapping. Because I am so hard to spook I wonder how this one got to me? I do. It's written as if it were published in about 1980 or so. The people are not heavily amoral narcissists or selfish manipulator emoting drama stars as in the present modern. The kids are kids. Babies are like babies. Motherhood somewhat stretched but almost missing the joy. Sucked up by this house?If this is debut? I'll read hers. It is NOT going to be attractive to the modern gothic or horror or domestic angle genre reader of 2023 at all. Because it is about when task, work, routine, schedule and how all those "least interesting" become turned on their heads. Slowly.I do recommend for Mothers most especially....more

author: Methos, Victor*

review: This is almost exactly a 3.5 star read but I rounded it up for the character development and the law/court portions.It's too long. Very long. ActuallyThis is almost exactly a 3.5 star read but I rounded it up for the character development and the law/court portions.It's too long. Very long. Actually this could have been two books. I detest when the first few pages have almost no connection at all to any person or event of the next 300 pages. That happens here. I will try to be succinct and it is difficult. I could go too long too on this one. Methos knows more than the average writer of this current genre. Yet, does he need to tell and tell all of it repeatedly. Especially with personality or dysfunction features or classifications- we get it. The readers get it already. And within his dialogue especially (not a fan) this overkill (a pun intended) is at a 2 star level. Within mostly otherwise decent prose flow- it jars. There are writers who write brilliant character speak dialogue (Horowitz is one, Julian Fellowes is another) and then there are those who don't. Methos has this considerable weak point. His people talk like melodrama of the 1920's or people in analysis under hypnosis. Or just not par with their character context or placements.Juxtaposition of players oddity was beyond believability for me too. But that I could swallow more than Tara talking like special needs 12 years old one minute and then a 50 year old tenured PhD the next. Jessica is a font of seething reactions and then? Yes, depth in developments but at the same time proportionally skewed almost to a cartoonish level. Over the top and I was not able to swallow such phenomenal changes depicted in this book. Nor the Yardley acceptances of Wesley either that occurred in the first 150 pages. Nor the mixture of Jessica being so savvy in the workplace and almost nothing but a emotionally collapsed wreck in the personal self-identity out of work life. This is found in many female leads of this genre currently. And it is in real life nearly absurd. I wonder if the authors have ever talked to these women in their real life balances.Then why did I give it 4 stars? Because with all the repetition, I still wanted to read on. Often I don't. It was not as good as his stand alone and it was also way too brutal, chewy, gory and yet still I wanted to continue. Although putting it down 4 or 5 times between other books.I will read #2 but then I will be done with this level of gore, despite the law side savvy. He does courts better than most any current fiction author. If I read that he has court stand alone fare- that would work though.This is the absolute truth. Do I read too much! I looked at the page number and wrote it down. Because on page 116 out of nearly 500 (large print copy)- I knew who the murderer of the couples copycat killer was for sure. All kinds of reasons and Jessica Yardley did not have a clue?Do not read these if you have high aversion for guts and torture description. On repeat....more

my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Excellent debut. Better than 4 stars at points. Yet I think the ghost narration, which at points was beautifully done- also detracted a bit for the prExcellent debut. Better than 4 stars at points. Yet I think the ghost narration, which at points was beautifully done- also detracted a bit for the present and alive narrators, Jean and Laura. Hard to say how it did, but for me, it blunted the intensity of both alive women's travails and decisions. And they were core to the book.This was a deep dive into the reality of fighting cancer as it often plays out. Three women close friends and my sister (this year for the 3rd time in her life) could tell nearly identical tales. It's worth reading for Laura's voice alone despite that not being the definitive core event. (She is a genealogy search librarian.) Because the murder of one young woman and two little girls WAS. To be KNOWN and to be remembered properly the goal of their legacies. Please!Because I read non-fiction true crime, I knew exactly which serial killer and all the outcomes before I was on page 30. And also of the identity searches in real time / life scenarios as they occurred. But nevertheless, it did not at all take away from the reading experience. That was nearly 5 stars as it was so encompassing to wider themes and life/death struggles as humans experience. Often they do.This was a once a month serendipity read knowing nothing at all of subject matter or genre. I picked it from the NEW shelf for its exquisite cover. And exactly at this time I was also putting up a set of moonflower vines to replant in new spaces. Often I get a 2 star out of that practice and yet this time was nearly a 5. I would absolutely read more of hers. Jean, the police officer was also done well- retirement at young ages being a very often and current reality in this less than optimal for lawful times.For those of you who don't know. That serial killer did it multiple times after various different years of living with them as families. And he died in prison in 2010. But Herchenroether did an excellent fictional work of how it all could have happened. And actually did for 90% of the nuance and placements. He left bodies in drums in New England area as well as other locations. This one was in New Mexico's Gila Forest. And also how police work is done extremely poorly for a dozen different reasons. So much more core than just putting up the tape and pressuring witness statements inquiry sessions. And never forget that this is also 1991 when forensics was so much less the starring role. Fantastic personality studies on at least 8 or 9 primes. Plus the ending chapters which really don't connect to the Lisa P. case- STILL. SO APPRECIATED. Well, read it with patience.Was justice done? No. Hardly. But we sure do know the possibilities / real life punishments and also the outcomes. And I rather do not agree with the author. I think a whole lot more was parallel in timing that never came out and which was ALSO happening within Lisa's own home. These people were atypical for the period, I believe. Especially for Cleveland as a whole. Far more wealthy and of almost no meaningful or core religious or moral fixture beliefs in utopian formed Shaker Heights. And lacking quite a bit of role modeling in the adult crowd as well, for sure. In 1981, 1991, 2001 or any other time, I would never have allowed all the night traipsing as these parents seemingly turned their backs to confront. UGH! And the victim's parents donate all funds to the Girl Scouts? Had to put this book down for several reasons in real current life- but this is quite a window. I recommend. No photos included. This could go long as I have tracking and psychology practice in a decade or more of my past. This Daphne was a true parallel to several (more than a few) seeking grad or PhD school level (students) courses, IMHO. Self-centric of intense degree, not as cored as Daphne with negativity, but close. Bea Setton knows how to tell constant mundane daily reaction from the most inside/ out eyes. Pathological lying being only the tip of the iceberg. It's not pleasant to read of such mental illness without giving it a name or category, IMHO. I went into this book as a serendipity read just from the cover and in paperback form (library new shelf pick). So had not an iota of category age group or subject matter I was getting. Only knowing it was IN Berlin. The only European city l have experienced being quite like my own. (Chicago) Not only in appearances, either. But it is NOT a fun read. Just pathetic, actually. Living for a reaction or to maintain some facade. Because the self worth for goals of economics or job/ work love or any deep ideal of spirit in any way is not at all present. Sick. I knew she was anorexic from the beginning- BUT. Well, it is not a book that most will want to read- but I am glad I did. Some quotes almost made me give this book 5 stars. She is an excellent writer. Mostly, IMHO, Setton hit a key reason why some humans use others so much and do not at all consider most of the baggage they have left with others behind in hurt or worse damage. Because their perceptions and selfishness (from sickness or insanity or just plain insular habits of being pleased continually- are that far off).Quotes (only a few out of 100 that would make a great philosophy course):"He thought, as many intellectual men do, that ceaselessly pointing everything out that is bad in the world was enough to make him good.""This probably says something about me- I've never been very good at 'going with it.' I don't think I ever fully immerse myself in anything. My body is in the stream, true, but I've always got my head a little above the water. I'm always looking down at myself, watching how my legs thrash about, and how the fish and weeds flow all around me."She puts the German men into 7 or 8 categories. I won't tell you anything else about her- but the entire book happens in her head. Terrible person, but fantastic writing....more

Chicago for much of her life, yet born and raised in a much earlier and nearly rural described San Francisco. No bridge. LOL! But I have a granddaughter who went to Loyola during the Final Four basketball events that made Sister Jean so media known and popular. This was written when she was 103. My granddaughter worked and had lots of photos with her about 3 to 4 years ago when she was a Nursing student undergrad at Loyola. She is now a traveling Nurse and as Sister Jean states multiple times (an email frenzy person)- she sure does keep in touch.Regardless, it is well worth the read. Just to contemplate her directness, faith incredible, and undiminished mix of wanting and being embedded with people. Usually the young, but not always at any level of her roles. I remember Mundelein well- and had friends (lucky them) get to go there back in the day. It eventually got embedded and taken over by Loyola University. Sister Jean lives there now, in downtown Chicago. A few people she mentions from her past associates I do know. She is an accurate accessor to character. That's a 5 star.Do I agree with all her asides. Nope! But I do with her methods. And her optimism. And her good intent that is almost entirely universal. Her order has the motherhouse in Dubuque Iowa but she has been in Chicago for a majority of her life- yet at very different times. All in safer places that I was. LOL! And I do laugh at her Northside descriptions for the same eras. So much easier to assume and define perimeters for attitudes or "best" when you are physically in cozy places. It is.She has been a BVM sister (really not a nun because nuns are contemplative) and an active dynamo since she was 18 years old. She went to Iowa as a postulant days after her 18th birthday. Much schooling over different periods of her life too -but still active in her office location. She STILL is. But I don't think she is the basketball chaplain as she was. She does KNOW basketball with past coaching roles....more

title: Generations: The Real Differences Between Gen Z, Millennials, Gen X, Boomers, and Silents―and What They Mean for America's Future
author: Twenge, Jean M.
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Interesting stats. This read is in great proportion demographics. I do not agree with other posters' definitions of individualism in their interpretatInteresting stats. This read is in great proportion demographics. I do not agree with other posters' definitions of individualism in their interpretations of what they read here re hers. If they did read it all. But I do not agree with the author's either. It's giving the abstraction way too much inertia/ purpose etc. Most especially for her/their interpretations of Twenge's mentions for individualism's roles. At points Twenge's posits for individualism? Either as traits or as action habits? It is NOT giving identity labels. It is NOT a part of cancel culture rote mode or group think collective "must" feel either.The historic record definition of individualism cores on self-sufficiency. It was often paired with the word "rugged" for intrinsic reasons. It is NOT self-labeling as a member of a group, nor in a self-identity sense of category for human or some type of being gypped victimhood identity. Quite the opposite. It stands alone and may not recognize group think authority or classifications at all. Or if partially, only because it originates within the individuals' rights and responsibilities for THEMSELVES. BOTH! This is not a receiving end or identity labeling function but a positive originating onus. Totally the opposite.I actually think it is humorous that so many quite young believe they can redefine English words or abstractions/ concepts to mean the opposite of their original core meanings. Being anti-authority doesn't mean the same as individualism AT ALL either. In fact, the strongest individualism cares little for authority and wants at best, the smallest amount possible. Government or otherwise. Because it stands in a place where the single person is sufficient to deal with the values and actions of themselves and their surroundings.This book was a fair and exhaustive survey and was NOT middle right wing as judged by . AT ALL. If that were the case for definitions alone- than JFK must have been a far right wing Fascist (as labels have progressed to that!). He wasn't. What I do ponder after some contemplation is that it seems I may have learned almost as much from reading s for this as I did from the book. Because the realities of process, self-perception, and outcomes (economic especially) are not what some people want to hear for their tech relying or any economic or strength against adversity aspect advantage position-so they seem to vilify the messenger in/for reactions. Or they do not want to begin to compare to the world before vast tech and work life (in and out of the home) changes. They don't care to. Ever. I lived without air conditioning for weeks over 90 degrees more than a few times when they picked up bodies in the morning. Child and adult both, I did. Also remember friends in iron lungs and paralyzed and being witness to death 3 times before I was 10. (Rare as hen's teeth for decades now and none of them were anywhere near a hospital room.) And physical safety became far, far away impossible dozens of times a year within logistics or geographic dire conditions. No cells- no phone-and group contact zero. Very different than now in the whole sense of what "safety" comprises.It loses a star in generalizations. OF COURSE, not all people fit like a puzzle piece in the category of their named generation. And some of us are complete outlier. For instance, I am nearly the opposite of my group in a few characteristics (revolt against authority/ sexual mores etc.) and was nearly for my entire life a minority ethnic too for nearly every living group or residence. When this book puts me in vast majority status by USA demographics. So the stats for me, were almost completely opposite in numerous categories for the USA as a whole as what I lived. But there are always quite a few that don't fit into their category generation much at all in every group. One of my sons doesn't. He could have been a Silent. Grabbed more responsibility at 12 than some do at 26 now.I read this to learn about the "polars" because all my grandchildren are Generation Z except for a 2 year old who will be post-Covid born "Polar". I like the other designation (A) she gave to it about starting over with the alphabet better than the Polar tag. I think they will need to be really far more tough than Millenials or Z....more

title: Please Join Us
author: McKenzie, Catherine*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: OK, 90% of the time I am basically outlier on NOT scoring 5 stars or for the usual 3 star when others are majority 5 star raves. This will be the compOK, 90% of the time I am basically outlier on NOT scoring 5 stars or for the usual 3 star when others are majority 5 star raves. This will be the complete opposite situation to that common one.Because I thought this book was terrific. Did I believe at any point that it was 5 star literary marvel or that it was one out of 500 in best plotting. NO! But it was clever, timely, and also instructive to a 5 star level. And it didn't suffer fools. You did NOT get over and over explanations to the thought patterns of the primes. But you did get their actions and words (McKenzie's dialogues are 5 star in nearly all her books). MUCH appreciated, in this particular era of tell and tell and tell. This book was the show, not the tell. I enjoyed this book to a 5 star level. There were times in Chicago (former century) that this brought to memory. Not at all that varied either from these scenarios at all.Because most humans are not toward the upper levels of commerce, politics, marketing, entertainment just "there" because they excelled. Nope. Which will seem not an intuitive approachable reality for many readers for this genre or time either. Women readers, most especially. Because you have heard endlessly such a different message for at least 20 years now. Essentially nearly an opposite one to the one this book demonstrates. But one that is nevertheless more actual in participation of experiences for the period of 40 or 50 years ago. Many women's experiences of excelling or "doing it all". Both. Because women ARE visible and exactly like these women in "Please Join Us". More so too, on the other sides of the glass ceilings. Now and then. Never saints, and always savvy. Nicole's voice was also excellent. And not angry. KUDOS. She actually loved her husband and respected him. Which at times makes many aspects of her workplace or success situations at that level HARDER, not easier. Loved the plot. And won't tell you a thing about it. But as a life long non-joiner of sorority to PTO or children activity hierarchies- this book was hugely appreciated. I've found that almost all group think mantra or loyalty is festered within these exact types of under pining agendas. In education or corporation or "fellow workmate well met"- regardless there is the "must do" attitude or politico best. And if you are not on the slate with that, you become less- sometimes rather quickly. Group think today is the worst I have seen in 75 years at that. It's almost to a point now of you not being able to think or decide at all (right, wrong, appropriate, respect worthy) individually but being told what to think from childhood to grave. Altogether the most unputdownable read so far this summer out of many. I would never have accepted that invitation but I loved Nicole's "out" when she woke up. NYC for sure. And believe it or not Chicago at high levels of nearly every enterprise (business, altruistic, boards, LLC's, Unions, Education) has women that OUTDO men in these types of long term planning of the nefarious nature. Both good (legal) and bad (illegal) ones, at that. It is not a "flip" or swearing world either. It's a "downtown" world that is not at all that far fetched here. Lived it and see it now in my kids and grandkids. Go along or get along (elsewhere)!...more

title: The Good Liar
author: McKenzie, Catherine*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: It's a 3.5 star book but I rounded it up for the placements and the characters. The characters are chiseled down to the immense minutia of their livesIt's a 3.5 star book but I rounded it up for the placements and the characters. The characters are chiseled down to the immense minutia of their lives. And that's what this author does the best, IMHO- she knows how to define the ordinary day into miniscule irritation or streaming ordinary functions to the point that you often see the visual in your head as if you are watching a top notch actor in film.Yet- she goes very long and often wordy to do so. And so much of her "action" in plotting forms and pace too; they are around hear-say, gossip, friend or peer or work mate ambiance slips etc. So truthfully as MY reaction, there are NO people in any of her books I have read so far that seem close to reliable or good intent prime or not narrators. There is always (even the good intent) some double face frontage in comparison to the inner voice. But she can create them. And in believable absurdities too. They aren't too far fetched which is a mercy for the bilge in this general genre category. That being the domestic or modern relationship/crisis type of psychological thriller. Be it action prone or not.But it takes me TOO long to read them because of her verbosity. So I will space a few out this year. But she HAS talent and they are really worth it if you are a young Mom, any aged striving to find places of both interest and/or monetary in real world work, know disappointments in many middle life crisis or husband/ teen ager woes. Does she know them!At page 76 I knew all the connections between the characters for the affair, death aftermath etc. and about 1/2 of them for Franny. So reading some s now? It seems many were totally confused. Oh McKenzie left huge clues all over the place- but the very last turnaround information did surprise. Not entirely, but somewhat. Accident? Oh, yeah- in a book like this? Come on.But regardless, all the time and person switching does leave tons of voids in her works too. Another skill she has, she can write around voids with a minimum of repetition. But this time the redundancy was more evident that the last book of hers. She did both Chicago and Montreal well. Kudos!This could be called "Real Housewives of Evanston,IL" without it being much off. And the given title is apt because they ALL are better liars than just GOOD....more

review: No rating for a book that gets many stars for the majority of readers. It's just not for me. I'm not at all embedded in the writing style after 20% reNo rating for a book that gets many stars for the majority of readers. It's just not for me. I'm not at all embedded in the writing style after 20% read- and am truly tired of the lectures. Charlie is interesting and worth a read. But much more so for those who were never there. Because many of us who have lived through "interesting" times, KNOW it doesn't tell like a history book filled with aftermath platitudes. Being old, it has its drawbacks and also has some joys. Even for those of us in more than average good health. But most of the advice and preaching going on here is valid at any age. That's true. But I don't believe it is perpetually possible to live in the moment. If you ALWAYS do, you do NOT get to over 100- that's for sure. Sort of ironic that all of the emotive and effusive seem to adore the philosophy of stoics within this book. While the few of us that ARE stoic are continually disdained and abused for not emoting continually and visibly. Just happened this week at a granddaughter's wedding. No Kleenex for me.So far this year, I think I have tried "old" people book characters a few times too many. Some are actually realistic and interesting. This would be a worthwhile read for most people, especially those who don't know any real history. What they are teaching in many schools, is not much of it at all. History is a piece of its own times and mores and opinions in their proper context and not filled with omissions. And for the last century, also held huge positive advancements in nearly everything physical or mental. Not only for humans. Some of us do remember the days when the ice man came for our ice boxes. Or having no flush anything.DNF...more

It is about the scientists who study them and how as much as about the birds themselves.Actually it is more than I wanted to know about these wolves of the sky. Owls are mainly night active but there are exceptions to almost every owl "norm" as there are sub species. And they have HUGE appetites.Loving parrots and other birds- some of these scenarios! Individual pellets with 11 birds encapsulated - all swallowed within a couple hours? That's just snacking. The process of expelling the pellets too! Owls are master designs of hearing skills and stealth quiet. One of my sons has hated owls and/or any depiction of owls since birth. Literally screamed until he was 5. I was going to buy this for him as a joke. But I will refrain. His brother and sister will NEVER forget those owl terror years either.Very scientific study of dozens of species. Picking "Our Town" for theater minutia repetition on top of it. UGH! You need to feel books that are in this novel's line rather than use any minute intellectual portion to appreciate them. Not a whiff of head here at all. And much of the emotions were like deflated balloons lying on the lawn after their party use display.Each daughter's intact history/story might have been more interesting in past druthers than the mother's, IMHO. But no character except for the father (UNDER developed) deserved the amount of physical, emotional or mental descriptions (really short on the last two) of the 3 siblings. I could NOT get interested although I read happily until the midst of the book. After that I could hardly come back to it. Theater and acting stories just do not do it for me. Science exactness in some parts. And yet other parts of this book don't deserve a 2 star. He tries to make this "funny light" or "savvy humor" stand up comedy quip in lengthy portions. Which for me at points (maybe 20 in all) almost made the top of my head come off. Not funny as I am used to funny! It's sarcasm and ridicule cored and NOT of the raw real either (like a George Carlin, for example)- but what passes for humor since about 2015 or so. It laughs AT, not with. And that was a 1 or 2 star habit for me, especially in the light of long ago biography or most other aspects of innovators etc. Who is he to judge? The author, I'd guess- omnipotent Kean.BUT, the tales here! AND also the science! The reality of life's journey in many inventors, innovators, investigation prone humans- it TRULY is stranger than fiction. And most suffered immensely for their core investigations, hobbies, life's work in a lab or back room etc. So that was 4.5 stars and some of that was 5 stars. Yet at the same time, IMHO, there was an entire chapter or two, maybe three- that didn't belong at all. The title intersect is also fairly inexact? For instance, the entire Art World section, which had zero to do with DNA beyond a shape of a helix? And the Art masters cored are not anywhere near helix drawing prone types of any study relationship! In fact, I don't see any investigation into their brains in autopsy or any other faction of comparison to DNA code much either. Well that's just a minor irk but it is only 1 of 4 or 5 strange inclusions- in the way he "relates" subjects to each other. And non-withstanding that there were strong portions of history for two bright stars of past intense advancement in this field that were Church clergy- he still never passes a chance to dig any intellectual heel in the gut of the Catholic Church either. Mendel and Sister Miriam merely two of many. It is very WELL worth the read. I recommend it. But understand the vast coverage and know you will read, see much of dire human past and individual sufferings. I never knew how sick Darwin was all his days, for instance. But for me, the real star was lost in some of the assumptions of past judgment AND future projections that the author makes too. author: Leon, Donna
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: 4.5 stars and one of the best. Also with the least plotting re the usual police procedural which is most often the Guido Brunetti fare. And this I als4.5 stars and one of the best. Also with the least plotting re the usual police procedural which is most often the Guido Brunetti fare. And this I also loved. As it is jammed to the top with memory. Not only Guido's but his brother's. And also the loyalties, memories of some well known (after 30 other books) and also new characters. But not too many- maybe 5 individuals total.People from Guido's youth- neighbors. And the Countess, his mother-in-law has a large role, as well. Memories all entwined and much philosophical thought as the pandemic and so much void, isolation or failures in business and the courses they have lain, are more fully revealed.Venice, her buildings and artifacts shone here too. Many walks and rides with Foa. Plus there were Paola and Chiara deep conversations at several points in this particular novel. Wistful and exactly of this period of time. Superb.Yet, with all the deep carves of characters, she did manage to get in her hits. Vitriol to sarcasm- the whole template of dissing is here. Against the Church first. And not as well done against corruption and the insidious reality of government or charity or societal on the whole; the process of tax or donated with the clever "accounting" of money just flittering away. Where? And not a sure tale in any sense of where it has gone either. Since the purposes for it are still more needing than ever. But Leon sure does make her point. My city and state (USA) is much worse for this. Do I understand the processes used here. Perfectly. And the group at the Questura that we love the most (his 4 officers and secretary of most intimate cases experience) all contrive to do much of the same. Because they aren't playing by the "rules" either. So Italian. So Venetian! And yet near the end she has some paragraphs to posit about the voids left after God belief is gone. Missing it. And the measures of memory in which it was so whole and operative and busy with purpose. LOL! At 80 plus, I do think Leon has begun to protest too much for quite deep reasons.And Elettra is also here in key power. Her little response of "me"! I won't forget that at all. Nor the dementia ridden Admiral who is so loyal and so very decimated by media. So unfairly, and so common in this exact period and for over a decade already. Leon hasn't lost a single brain cell there either. She has noticed.Well, I missed this Give Unto Others when it was new and read #32 first. (Looking at the dates, I was super busy with so many changes then.) Just saying this as advice- I would never start the series with either of those (#31 or 32). Character and past history is nearly essential to understand how well these characters are aged and how much they fit the times. Without that you are left half out of the emotion or the baggage.Lastly- hardly the least food reveals or delights of any Brunetti. Just a risotto. Bummer. Memories sided with current nasty attack have left who is a friend and who is NOT a friend- very core during the mask removals of after Covid. Something ALL of us just old or very old humans consider almost frequently, IMHO. You've had a long time to decide.Probably one of the worst generalization and most unfair paragraphs about Roman Catholic education that I have ever read. Just full of the spite that comes from projection. As I seldom do quotes and she may not be writing much longer- I can't resist this one. I do love a good hater when they are consistent. LOL!"It was Griffoni who reacted first. She set down her pen on her open notebook and said softly, 'You must be very proud of him, Signora. Or both of them.' Hearing her and seeing the sincerity of her smile, Brunetti was certain she had gone to Catholic schools: it was only there that children mastered the alchemical formula of untruth and hypocrisy that was sure to persuade even the most sceptical listener."...more

title: Zig-Zag Boy: A Memoir of Madness and Motherhood
author: Frank, Tanya
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: It's between 3 stars and 4 stars. This is the third book this week I've read which has mental illness of grave dimensions as the core. And in all threIt's between 3 stars and 4 stars. This is the third book this week I've read which has mental illness of grave dimensions as the core. And in all three cases, they are written by a friend, family member, witness in the trenches- and not at all by the DSM5 diagnosis individual.There DOES inlay a specific problem. Using association and/or extreme closeness of relationship to publish another's story. In most cases, the world being what it is- I feel this can almost always be justified- despite some sufferers themselves saying it is unfair. This time, as his Mother, most certainly the biggest "well, ok" of the 3. Best Minds and The Elissas: Three Girls -it isn't even a family member. Well, only a few posters seem to see this book too, in that slant of witness- not schizophrenia sufferer. Regardless, that can be as terrible as the perceptions and the disease fallouts themselves. Many times individuals cannot make rational decisions for themselves. Can you guess which day they can and which they can't? But some demand an almost strictly critical and measured decision EVERY TIME and EVERY DAY. If you have not walked in their shoes- I don't understand the immense critical nature of judgments from the outside.Saying all that, this particular book was the Mother's story. Terribly sad, and filled with all types of personal information. Some was better than most. Some not. I think she communicated how blindsided they all became. That's the most horrendous aspect, to me, that the onset of this is so often from 18-24 and just as expectations become decimated.I learned a little about meds and their extreme inconsistencies and terrible (common) side effects.Most of her emotional battles had to do with family relationships and much else that I really didn't want to know SO much about. Seeing that housing and much else of monetary situations was WAY above average for this situation in any country or location? And other factors too, made it a slog at points. Sad and very difficult regardless. Yet, hard to embed at the same time. Lots of times it is apples compared to oranges and not apple/apple comparisons. At least this book told and shown (both) much of the reality of daily perceptions for a person with this form of schizophrenic illness. I also learned about that group of doctors that don't even believe it is an illness or disease. And the quacks with all types of food or mental exercises remedies. Oh if it were only so easy. Danger and violence can ALWAYS be a product of terrified perceptions. This book didn't convey that much at all....more

title: Treasure State        (Cassie Dewell, #5; Highway Quartet, #6)
author: Box, C.J.
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This was good. Actually Very Good. I wonder if any of you remember when they used to give VG's as B grades.The protagonist detective, Cassie, is so muThis was good. Actually Very Good. I wonder if any of you remember when they used to give VG's as B grades.The protagonist detective, Cassie, is so much a real possible person. That's becoming rarer in this genre all the time. But Montana itself is also the STAR of her setting. It taught me several geographic and demographic facts too. Butte, Bozeman, Anaconda- they come alive. And different from each other. The copper mining of the early last century key too. This wasn't just surface stuff either, it was deeper.There are 3 plots going on and two of them related and they meet close to the end. The last much minor one has to do with a Treasure Hunt scenario and it is resolved a bit after the more dire criminal circumstances. There is gunfire and also subterfuge. Big time and small time evil, as well. I thought the various levels of "bad" truly delightful. Not at all always "what you see is what you get" either. But of those of you averse, there is murder done to a higher body count than just 2. All by others, not Cassie. And only 1 is self-defense.Of course, the timing switches nearly a dozen times. (Three days before, a month before, two months after etc.) and because of how it was done, it did work. Very little redundancy and yet it was not complex all that much either. Everyone who can read will figure out who and where quite easily.But the mix was above average and the people more actual/ real possibles than any of the last 10 I've read in this genre. There is one extremely bad, bad individual. But he sure doesn't work his way in voids. The distances driven too are as wide as the views are awesome of the mountains. It's so pleasurable to read about a detective that isn't drop dead gorgeous, isn't a police authority's daughter, or doesn't have huge baggage of bad choices behind her. I will read more of Box's Dewell for sure....more

title: The House of Doors
author: Tan Twan Eng
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This is in the top 3 enjoyed reads in 2023 for me. Actually, only Circe would be the other one that might outrank it out of the 300 plus total (fictioThis is in the top 3 enjoyed reads in 2023 for me. Actually, only Circe would be the other one that might outrank it out of the 300 plus total (fiction portion) books. Is it perfect? No, it is not. At certain points it was history or info drops with so much description impaled within that style of sphere that tell, tell raises its head. You get intense mood regardless, but not at all the intricate points of "show" flows throughout. Only in portions of the two different "now" do you get fiction show. Bud DID it work here within House of Doors. It worked for tale tension, progression, and especially to core the 4 or 5 superbly carved core characters (intellectually as much as emotionally) and their spouses or companions. Not only the two narrators either. Not at all. Onus within all company spread widely.Loved the Malaysia Straits intrinsic meshes of mixes| Such a land/island and point of hodgepodge intersects for everything. Not only ethnic or languages or cultures or weathers either. It is just mixtures of nearly everything. Economics, geographic nature, animals, birds, familial bases- all are so majorly mixtures. Variety Asiatic times 100's in majority of the population too. Then AND now. Loved his other works but I really think this one is the best. Terrific tale of the periods traipsed, as well as the placements in locale. 1910 before and 1921 after and yet all the mores are clearly tipping over into the largest changes seen in millennia (entire decade of 1920's absolutely).This also reminds me HUGELY (Tan Twan Eng's prose style- and most particularly in his glorious moments like that nude swimming sequence within the illuminating algae night) of former past times' styles of writing. The writing of the past century much more than that of the present one. Human 1900-1969 status quo style of writing a tale (manners /structures). Not framed within overt obnoxiousness or never looked upon or implied as any kind of victim type righteousness, anger to hold or maintain as a positive virtue. This author is truly worth waiting for- and doesn't put out novels willy-nilly in numbers. KUDOS!This would make a marvelous film project. The visuals! I want to see Lesley in that kayba ensemble and the final appearance of the House of Doors outside panels. And of course, to read or reread Somerset Maugham. Some might find fault with the tied up late 1940's ending outcome add portion. I loved it. Also loved that during the trial -you were not given spoilers. Fabulous tale of Penang Malaysia all around....more

review: Most of this prose was smooth and with this much travel and eyes to description, just scrumptious. Yes, even some of his assumptions and conclusions wMost of this prose was smooth and with this much travel and eyes to description, just scrumptious. Yes, even some of his assumptions and conclusions were interesting, even when they were context "off". This type of personal history and background too. It lends itself to many moments for pondering, and a few times for some powerful aspiration core possibilities. Yet, as a practicing Catholic and one who worked within Roman Catholic education for at least 20 years of my life? At points I was appalled. Well, some of this belief definition or generalizations, they are just wrong. Also put into context of mind-boggling misinformation with generalizations. And no more so than his Pope Francis summations and interpretations. And also at the same time he puts much more emphasis on (for 2023 or any time IN my lifetime and I'm 75) things like indulgences or 1000 year old past human failures. And negativity/ failures of current times too.This could get very long, and I will try to be as brief as I am capable of being when this is so core. But his mindset, from the beginning, was NOT in pilgrimage notch. It wasn't. Timothy Egan is primarily and always through this entire journey, about Timothy Egan. Which puts the emphasis and the openness almost entirely backwards for a pilgrimage of spiritual growth. It's far simpler than he makes it out to be, too. What he believes he is seeking? Faith is not ONLY faith (so that the intellect is pacified?) or as other agnostics would define either. And Catholics believe in acts MATTER beyond their faith alone, regardless. He gets the appearances of religious core practice and little else to its FAITH components from the get go. Faith is something you live by obeying the 10 commandments and loving your neighbor. Actually, I've been many of the places he trod. And this made me sad overall. Because it is rather obnoxious too when someone pretends to this extent that they hold understanding and knowledge, when they don't. His mother's experience is common. Our intellects and emotions gave/give a "dark night of the soul" to many saints. They LIVED their faith, that is what mattered. And will in the end. Emotions are like bodies- merely temporary. Egan misses the boat on the core of spirituality nearly completely, while giving huge copy to all atrocities and almost entirely leaving out the good. 1000's of hospitals, schools, and libraries merely the tip of the iceberg for charity over 2000 years. And in some ages, it was the only home of recorded knowledge and refuge for women, as well.It somewhat reminds me of revisionist history which neglects ever aspect of positive change and lists every negative as if they all existed in a vacuum. He was not in search of a Faith but of a book to express his intellect and ego....more

title: A Woman of Influence: The Spectacular Rise of Alice Spencer in Tudor England
author: Wilkie, Vanessa
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This book is absolutely in my top 5 non-fiction for the last 5 t0 10 years. Because it is seated in the 16th century- it is hard to compare to contempThis book is absolutely in my top 5 non-fiction for the last 5 t0 10 years. Because it is seated in the 16th century- it is hard to compare to contemporary placed (post 1900 say) non-fiction? No, not really. It's better.This is the biography of the woman in the title. And it is NOT all about corsets, silk, satin, and flowers. But about power and influence and money, the same if not more. All the very singular paths that the top 1 or 2% of "celebs" care about NOW. Or did. Or will. And what has truly changed in law and access since Alice did all her negotiations and suits against/ within the dual court systems of her day? (Ingenious system by the way- and that is why English law is so often copied in types.) If you believe that women were voiceless before their first emancipations or votes in the last century- you NEED to read this book. Wealth was only a meager start to the climb. And you absolutely cored the whole journey on having the mind of a lawyer, financial entrepreneur savvy coupled with the arts of guile AND complete objectivity (not subjective feelings of like/dislike much either). And mates/ spouses not at all chosen by attraction but by realities.I do NOT recommend this book to those who only want to hear about the plays, the music, the progress (Elizabeth I) parties etc. You need to know that entire chapters are given to jointure rights and how they were obtained. And how 2nd and 3rd marriages spliced into the inheritance law and custom. Plus why the money and value WERE what they WERE. This is the only book in at least 3 dozen categories that gives you the present day pound and dollar value for goods, servants, dowries, tenant rents, vast estate maintenance etc. etc. Your mind will be boggled. During the last year of Elizabeth I's life they (Alice and her second husband) spent more than 5.5 million dollars on a 3 day party for Queen Elizabeth's visit to their place. And it was not at all unusual to have more than 48 servants for Alice and her three daughters alone- on other such estate visits when they were all still "at home" status before their own marriages. How could a wool farmer's daughter have done such a thing as live this life? Read this book. From the highest realms of art, literature, music, playwrights and poets' patronage as just an aside or two. I would LOVE to see her tomb. Designed and contracted by herself. Be warned that the associates of their (the 4 Spencer women) different ages are not all kindly Earls, Counts or Knights. Woman had their VOICES heard but in very different ways then they do now. And some of the time- the advantages were to THEM in comparison to the women alive presently, IMHO. Medicine being what it was- the fall outs for multi, successive marriages were vastly different too. Kudos to this author. She has to be a top notch detective just to get the meaning out of the verses that have been kept. Or letters, or law documents or church records etc. Endless footnotes/ references. I wouldn't mind meeting her at all either. Masterful eyes. As good as the one on Philby- Spy among Friends (Ben Macintrye) And I found this book entirely serendipity too while waiting for the other Mah Jongg players to show up. Best unknown to me find of the year for sure. I could NOT put this book down. If you are interested in James I or Charles, his son- their different styles of reign? This is also the book for you....more

For me, it was done just as well as Haunting of Hill House or a few others of solid classic fame. And I didn't have a stop at any point of need to jump over a believability barricade either. SO rare in overall mood sustaining as well. I would have liked to know a little more about the 4 or 5 main "patient" characters, but what was done was done superbly. Matron, Nina, Martha- they were 5 star portraits.I have read maybe 50 novels with "aftermath" mental states of WWI (really the worst and most horrible war) within all the labeling of "coward", as well. author: McFarlane, Fiona
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: It is fully 3.5 stars. And unusual too for 2023. Better than most of the "new" fiction. The core chapter about 2/3rds of the way through when Denny beIt is fully 3.5 stars. And unusual too for 2023. Better than most of the "new" fiction. The core chapter about 2/3rds of the way through when Denny becomes and self realizes that he is "not the before Denny" but instead full of knowledge to humans situation/ death/ reality beyond his 6 years. That was the 5 star part of this book. Well done. The Catholic Church puts that at 7 years of age and calls it reaching "the age of reason". But this book for a 6 year old- connoted it superbly.Yet I can't round it up. It's overlong and with considerable repetitions, especially re Cissy. She's outlier, we get it- already. But that can be forgiven too- because the tone, pace, depths of trying to wheat farm or ranch within detail minutia in desert South Australia during this period was constant. The locale and the core dozen folks never being obscured or leaving the whole locale or period as a one piece tale.And that's a difficult thing to achieve with these many folks and so wide a place for natural consequence AND adventure. Depending upon how you define adventure. Some of the aspects (Minna was one) seemed to be added just for the steamy scenes. But still overall the time, place, and natives to settlers- all well embedded/ entwined and just a good tale.Sharpness of the writing without constant circular placement or descriptive introductions to switching eye narrators or locations could be honed better by this author. I do hope she improves. Denny, Tai and Mary were all 3 done to 4 star levels. Brava! And she also kept the entire huge stage setting all of one piece to time and place. She didn't give them revisionist agendas or attitudes or dialogues. With these many characters, that is not a given either. But the prose flow doesn't reach past 3.5 stars, IMHO. This could have been vastly improved by a good edit. Give yourself some time to read this one. It's also fairly tense- but not at all over the top considering the subject matter. I just read some lengthy pieces on Australian geography. This is NOT where people live now. Almost the entire population is on the Coasts, but easily the Eastern coast side. I enjoyed it to a 3.5 stars too- some parts of it re Grandma or Arthur etc. etc. - put me to sleep. They sure didn't seem to EVER appreciate any old people. Or the author didn't. Hard to tell....more

author: Krueger, William Kent*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: 3.5 stars and I rounded it up for the depth he reaches here with the post-WWII aftermath for the men who survived combat. And especially the survival 3.5 stars and I rounded it up for the depth he reaches here with the post-WWII aftermath for the men who survived combat. And especially the survival reactions of such things as a cultural habit or movement which can carry the reaction completely unmeant as it did here with that bow to Brody. For many of us who have had dire, dire times of stranger assault or worse (war is worse)- many people have no conception how that visceral reaction becomes immediate for pure survival reasons but much more. Krueger gets it. But he doesn't get many other realities enough, IMHO. Especially with anything at all that has to do with Catholicism or other religions either. Nor their tenets. But he must truly think he does.Well, I could go long in why this was not anywhere in the neighborhood of This Tender Land or Ordinary Grace (5 star reads) but it was masterly and comes from a top notch writer. Who knows men deeply, much more than he knows women. But his women become developed too, at the same time. Primarily because his prose flow and dialogues are done so well. They did here.This Jewel, MN is rather different town/feel than in former MN books of his- but I liked the town development direction here too. Yet it is much closer to WI core norm, IMHO than it is to MN. The river area and the love of water/ lakes comes full blown. I have not seen that happen with more than a handful of writers. That was a 5 star element of personal connections to their river. Very much part of that place and life. Depicted in The River We Remember as strongly as it occurs in real life. 1958 or 2028. Overall, some of the characters (stereotypes) and the ending disappointed me. It took much longer to read than the average fiction of a serious genre. Lots of repetition and emotional effusive over almost the same exact quotients (trauma aftermath and loneliness here) was core. I loved the character of Angie or any person who holds happy continually because they truly know how blessed they are and how worse it could have been. Few authors express those kinds of realizations in their characters. Krueger does it full blown and he does that well here. That's the second reason why I rounded it up to 4....more

title: Woman, Captain, Rebel: The Extraordinary True Story of a Daring Icelandic Sea Captain
author: Willson, Margaret
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This is fully 3.5 stars, the first half is 4 stars. But I can't round it up because of the flow. And the last 30 years of her long life were hard to fThis is fully 3.5 stars, the first half is 4 stars. But I can't round it up because of the flow. And the last 30 years of her long life were hard to follow and held immense introductory name links/associations and the context of everything became nearly impossible to decipher. You will need immense patience to get through all of this, but for most of the history and content it is a full four stars. The Intro. was so harsh, I almost didn't read the book. She ranted, straight out ranted in that Intro. Very strange. But then I started the body of the non-fiction and was mesmerized until well past the half way point. It is well researched to depth, but at the same time the continuity and flow lacks. It jumps and it is also redundant. At points it sounds more like an oral repeating tale than a print discourse.It's impossible to even begin to portray in this short  the cultural context/ mores / reality of this 18th to 19th century life in Iceland. Harsh is not the English word that can BEGIN to relate. And the laws both by authority IN Iceland and from Denmark- BOTH! Insane control and immense usage of the fodder (Iceland born almost ALL) that were paupers, peasants, or most any human being that lived beyond the age of 5. Read this if and when you believe elite run authoritarian "know better" and organized dictate government coupled with a state religion or not- would EVER be a good idea. Please! Not only for all the minutia decree of this one either. This woman, Thuridur, was almost beyond sainthood and invincible physicality combined. And did it all within a system that has to be one of the worse in both expectations and living conditions (both) that I have ever read. Not at all only for the women either. Kids? Much worse.These people make the Vikings throughout most of Scandinavia from the millennia before this one look kind by comparison. Not just some either, almost every one of them for this period in Iceland. Plus the enemy was not only your own neighbors (or your own relatives with those marriage /leasehold laws etc.) for food quantity or seaweed to burn for warmth at all. It was also heavily seen and accepted demons, or ghosts, or a "Mori" or his kin who would (not might) mix up any positive you had/ held for more than 3 days in a row. Mostly too coupled or embedded within a demon heritage curse now and again. Plus this was a time of HUMONGOUS natural disasters too. Both by volcano and by flood. Not to speak of the usual fishing/ drownings. The language is abrupt, direct- short sentenced but with entwined, sinuous group knowledge/embedding factors. Like their lives....more

review: This is highly unusual fiction. I am giving it 4 stars for the conceptual density filled with core dichotomies. Yet the form itself, for me, was closeThis is highly unusual fiction. title: The Power of Geography: Ten Maps That Reveal the Future of Our World
author: Marshall, Tim

review: This is one of those books you almost need to own, not borrow. It's history over millennia for ten maps past- with many cultural/ mores or governmentaThis is one of those books you almost need to own, not borrow. It's history over millennia for ten maps past- with many cultural/ mores or governmental power entities of conquest/war or other changes- all in relationship to their geography. The titles isn't exactly accurate, IMHO. "Future of Our World" is too wide a slice for what was cut.Loved the depth of knowledge and the choices he made. Tim Marshall's own experiences in some of these places! Those reports were 5 star. Especially in Iran and Saudi Arabia. Yes, it is dry. This type of massive view to particular places cannot be filled with tra-la-la melodies or effusive lyrical passages. Nope, it can't. There are too many invasions, genocides, cultural revolutions of economic trading purposes or religions to be any type of easy read flow. I didn't expect it would be.This took weeks to read- with each section taking days. I gave gap times between to digest what was written, as well. I only thought it lacked a star in omission. I would wont to ask why these certain maps were picked over others. UK and Spain I can see mostly because of the empires during and after high waters of colonialism. And Turkey, for other reasons, I can see. Just curious.He interprets far less than some of these other s assume or suggest. He usually has excellent posits to support any stated position. Very little is theory of agenda slant. Most of it is logic, cultural thought to traditional mores/ placements, patterns of the past still working or not- and portents of same or not in aptitudes for that physical reality.Geography matters. I was especially enthralled by his Iran, Greece, Ethiopia discourses. Because there is SO much there I didn't fully know or realize for past realities. Or factual placement stances now, as well. What choices are there? Saudi Arabia length floored me the most. Such a tribal past! Lastly, for this one I read others s just before I finished the SPACE last portion. And I disagree with many posters who didn't like what they heard/ read. And interpreted most of it as Marshall's opinion or summation quirks. Facts remain. Physical remains. Natural world possibilities or IMPOSSIBILITIES remain. Agendas of theory or economic balances by power governments can and do continually posture, push, and explain the group think that enables them, regardless. But some of it will always be to no avail to any true "better". Especially if you measure better by longevity norm or innovation aptitude results....more

If she had been more independent (she was a mommy's girl and super sweet but awfully naive in self-identity spirit) holding more action in her own nature and not a girl who was so interdependent with her mother and sister, I bet the entire outcome would have been vastly different. No more "car" or "breakfast" arguments going on and on and crying continually, that's for sure. She would/should have left. Even the house was not worth fighting for under those economic and spousal conditions as so thoroughly documented. But she didn't. And we see this pattern over and over when you visit any large courthouse murder trial presently too with these similar circumstances. Or have ever worked at safety houses and have seen the flip returns of the habitually optimistic. I have.Well, the book is divided into parts and the last 2 are extensive. No spoilers. But my heart went out to all those people, at least 10 others beyond her mother and sister-for having years, years, years of trials and custody battles. Criminal and civil both. Actually, I am surprised he is where he belongs at all. College "fun" or not, I cannot imagine dating or thinking any of those gags Jason pulled were funny at any age. And I can't imagine a world where dating and hooking up "friend" circles are anything like this one is portrayed. And what that speaks to the many involved within it. To me it is soul/spirit, body, and mind- all three- just disgusting. The opposite of fully human too. Not to speak of the disregard for offspring, small children in all of this.Epstein does a top job of not judging as I just did. Donna Leon is one of my most favorite series writers. And I enjoy her Guido/ Paola books overall to react in dozens of paragraphs. Venice itself usually gets at least 10. Leon is 80. I sure hope this isn't her last one. You never want to end in a dud.Not this time. This  will be shorter. Because the enjoyment was nearly nil in reading. In fact, it took me a week with at least a dozen "come back to its" for me to finish it. It holds some of the most superb metaphor comparisons of paragraphs lengths though. The one in which Paola's facials are the Cobra and Guido's mind/ response expression is the Mongoose. 6 stars. That is EXACTLY the reality of the social warrior physicality in action.But the tone here and the plot? And the amount of dissing the church, nunneries, democracy, capitalism. I won't list all her usual rant targets. But my guess is that she let herself screed repeatedly about anything more conservative than Marx to make up for having the need in plot for Guido to indict a mover and shaker of the Red Brigades. Separating herself (author and Brunetti's both) from the actual Left of murder and destruction? (Not to speak of the 100's of millions killed by 20th century authoritarian Communism.) For all of them (all the Brunetti's), and especially for Paola- that is laughable. So elite brand hypocritical too. And by Italian political "standards" of ridiculous dichotomy in this one! Kidnapping being just one Italian specialty. Guido is sad. The kids are stereotyped again. (One the vegetarian, the other the mass eater.) And this is the first Leon book that has truly disappointed me. No less so than in the family interactions at that. This book was like a series of check offs for virtue signaling that Leon could include from a list. Not at all up to the par of family and friends at dinner either. Far more insular than that.Please, get off of the politics, Donna. Please! In Italy yet. You don't need to go back to the 1980's either. And if you need to do your usual multi-page Catholic Church snark and run- at least remain an equal opportunity religion hater while you are at it. The Buddha has had his difficulties too, you know.But overall, this #32 was the least of the last 20. Not just in plot, but in tone and energy. Both. Meanders too and if you have not read this series? Please, do NOT start here with this one. Two big disappointments too. Mentioning the Conte early in the book and he never shows. (Love him.) And Elettra shows up SO late. And then when she mentions the triangulation method, it isn't the MCA (Most Common Ancestor- DNA base) one that is right now turning Cold Cases upside down. It's a composite within a social media parlance to do similar cross overs, but not at all the supreme "seeker" for identity. I expect she will figure the rest (MCA of DNA databases triangulation) out by herself.PLEASE- give Guido other than the social welfare warrior fare that YOU want to rant over repeatedly yourself, Donna. The almost 12 year old and his cousin were both nailed. And fairly quickly too. Heavy, heavy issues but treated in mood and compliances with light and gentle hands. Plus you got a distinctive taste of the locale, the class divisions, the tribal and the familial. That was excellent.But the plot and the last 1/3rd of the book? Confusing and for some reason, just not there. Concept, nor expressed. Either way. It just circles so many aspects for both the real or the now connections. With all the length and wordy descriptions of "before", it also felt rushed or incomplete too. So the pacing of the entire novel truly felt off to me.Overall 3.5 stars, IMHO, but I cannot round it up because of the last quarter. I had to actually do some rereading. It didn't seem to "fit". Also it is sad. Too sad for me to want to give this 4 stars....more

title: Prom Mom
author: Lippman, Laura*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Disappointed at the plotting and the characters she carved. Lippman is a favored author and I've read many of hers. Stands alone especially, as I am nDisappointed at the plotting and the characters she carved. Lippman is a favored author and I've read many of hers. Stands alone especially, as I am not that big on Tess. When I was in Baltimore back in the day I even went to the dive/ coffee house where she was said to sit and write (Spoons). This one didn't fly and tried to be too many books in one. A semi-who dun it but beyond that a domestic thriller or a modern "what's going on" piece? Well, for me, it didn't succeed to a full extent in any of those. It's a 2.5 stars novel made slightly better by the back knowledge level of Baltimore, New Orleans- those two locales especially. IMHO, they were done much better than the people were.There is so much repetition upon Meredith that I got fed up enough to speed read in her sections. It's hard to believe a doctor, even a plastic surgeon, could be that shallow. And I knew from before the half that she was hiding all her own cards and playing as much a role as Joe. Every person of major paragraph after paragraph of their thoughts, labels, car trips, and restaurant foraging- all of them- TOTALLY SOULESS. From Lippman? Is she gone as faithless as I think she has?Regardless, the ending did NOT shock me as it did others from their reactions. And just from the main pivots of what they THOUGHT WAS IMPORTANT here? Purely existing for prestige scales and pleasure and facade- every single one. But even more disappointing was the level of category for Lipmann's opinion being trotted out time and again for a 4 or 5 page soliloquy upon various opinionated politico, decore trends, $1000 pairs of shoes, age appearance, etc. etc. etc. (I could go on and on and on too with categories alone.) And in doing so she also makes VAST generalizations. Re workers, Boomers, parents, having kids or extra anything- even down to having a character vote for anything that doesn't make him a result of the aftermath. Selfish and self-serving only apply. And every single one was an elitist view as IF they were working class. LOL! From blue collar Baltimore background too! She has DEFINITELY experienced a values scale switch.Too long of a reaction, I know. But REALLY, such a good writer wasting all that time on these people without souls or even consciences? COVID must have really done a job on her. To write an entire novel only filled with total users! Laura Lippman yet!And she didn't even begin to address the pack of lies told in every phase of COVID either! She skirted the tip of that control (and then change the "truth" story) iceberg only once or twice. And yet raised a few poignant crux posits for the period merely in passing. (But didn't at all even mention the lock downs much worse in other states- like not even being able to go out on a boat alone in Mi- or having the seed aisle crossed with tape barriers. LOL.) Only a few real glitch crossovers for present group think madness were included, and they WERE barely there. (Like the one on the Mardi Gras character design in N. O. with Rex etc.- how come the "woke" didn't yet get to that?) This aspect of minimal bravery and the excellent locales minutia is why I rounded it up....more
