review: Yes, I gave this book 5 stars. And it has little to do with it being the first  of the year OR that I enjoyed it IMMENSELY within a holiday hiatYes, I gave this book 5 stars. And it has little to do with it being the first  of the year OR that I enjoyed it IMMENSELY within a holiday hiatus. Because it is GOOD and because it is one of the best family dynamics/ sculpted to era and personality vibes examples still out there. Any class, any gender- regardless- pure REAL 1930's- 1940's England. Oh, the English prose skills of the early 20th century! When beautiful prose was "run of the mill" cliched to hold vocabulary and flow that strongly approached beauty AND knowledge for words in their particular parts of speech. Each to its proper place. And the carved "being" and "eyes"- from 9 or 10 "sides" here. Lots of names, but you do NOT confuse them. These are all specific and particular INDIVIDUALS beyond their pattern of connections. Despite some being classified "hon" or "non-hon" within the hidden "hon closet". Radlett family! Will I ever forget Uncle Matthew and Aunt Sadie? Nope. I read this the first time probably 4 plus decades ago and still remember the trenching tool on display and the foundation of their directions to their girls. Mitford was a gem. Her people were 1920's originals from youths of war, to "bolters" who ran their lives with their hearts and with almost nothing coming from their heads, to the ones who threw it all off and went to other continents on a lifelong whim. Not all of the primes- but in this one- more than a couple. Women who were provided FOR and had men who also could do nothing with them to the 110% degrees. While doing it rigorously (all) without the word work being within their cognition or even within the shared vocabulary. But it isn't just themselves. Or the "hon" class either. EVER.People in 2023 might scorn or read with dubious sneers. Yet do understand that for many millennia recorded, the biggest changes in mores in human industrialized civilizations DID occur in the 1920's - 1930's. Some of those also happened without continual fear, disillusionment, angry retribution, or even in a "poor me" bad mood spirit of behaviors or declaring of victimhood. Incredible. They label this sarcasm/ satire? It's fun, flippant and actual. Exaggerated yes, but so very real. I do remember just a decade later than the period of the blitz when joy was not a dirty word. And the tone, demeanor of the general WWII crew too. Ready for a instant party. Not only aristocracy in any measure. If you want to read WWII- please do read the stuff from the actuals. And in their periods of memory and of the time when one would instinctively run more TOWARD the danger than ever conceive of running away from it. Caution, self-isolating, insular? Ha! Authoritative fear mongering. Double ha!Linda was a piece of work. And entirely of her era.Now on to #2. Could it be better?...more

review: A worthy continuation to Franny's narration of Linda's story "The Pursuit of Love". But I did not like it as much. The form was ok but not as perfect A worthy continuation to Franny's narration of Linda's story "The Pursuit of Love". But I did not like it as much. The form was ok but not as perfect as the Hampton Court's family #1. I thought the last 60 pages of the book dropped to more trivia than the storyline could support. Not that this group of social society isn't minutia structured to detail from the get-go. This one also at points jumped the fence to farce. But not in a bad way either. The characters are extremely drawn within daily, lengthy and exact descriptions. So all the peculiarities are center stage core. It's enjoyable to read and as much celebration as it is cutting. Rather like the "Odd couple" dynamic. But this one isn't just about order or neatness.People with family history entry (hon's) and their 1930's society and lives within countryside England are put into almost judicial exposure through Franny's eyes. Uncle Matthew, Aunts Sadie and Emily and especially Davey are all strong actors again. This book should be read only after #1 so the stage is truly set for Polly's or Franny's stories in this #2. All will be revealed.There are no cliff hangers between the trio of Radletts' books, but development and deep progression result. So I do not recommend reading them out of order.I had never read this #2 and was shocked at Polly's choice. The rest of the outcomes did not surprise me at all. Especially for our dominant societal queen Sonia.There will be excess style, clothing, art and object criteria pages in this one for some people. No one mentions the townie horse lady at Oxford- another don's wife who attempts befriending Franny. Excellent under character development in a succinct and exact prose bullseye there. Mitford was superb at that kind of shot. She would have been a great comedic tv show editor or sit. com. writer. Even outside of her own social "hon" class. Absolutely. I'm SICK of 30 somethings in any national/ politic/ any continent location within sculpted scenarios of acting and using the logic and emotion of 16 to 19 year olds. Fiction presently is rife with emotional cretins who never grow up, it seems to me. Not only about commitment at all either. Or sexual behavior. Or work and advocation motives. All of the above.Some do (writing form) a book within a book better but not as quickly and succinctly in flow as this one was. That was way above average to masterful. Horowitz does but this was even cleaner. Plus it included all of the poetry escapes. Way over my head, but most will love them.Personal note: I saw way worse in my baby youth, pre-adolescent period, extreme youth of adulthood (repeatedly and one was beyond horrific) and still have optimism and trust. You need to work at it- and not be pushovers (self convincing "me, me, me") as these characters. Terrible times and views make many people stronger, not victims forever. This one nearly lost a star because of the selfish factors that seem to became praised here as a end stage "worthy" state of being. (As is the comment on all things terrible are justified within revolution.) Claudia was a jerk. Both of them were 30 and 33 going on 18 (if they were lucky).For all that energy he had as a kid? title: The Twist of a Knife        (Hawthorne & Horowitz, #4)
author: Horowitz, Anthony*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Entertaining to a 5 star degree. This one is entirely in the narrator Horowitz voice. Which through association, location, and especially knowledge ofEntertaining to a 5 star degree. This one is entirely in the narrator Horowitz voice. Which through association, location, and especially knowledge of present day culture becomes way above average.The case is good and has an exactly like Agatha end piece. (All gathered in one place while the sleuth defines the perp, crime and process.) And Horowitz notes that it does too. This one is neither too long (a couple were) nor as complicated as his book in a book former Hawthorne formats. This one is a play in a book. The play is his own (Horowitz writer) Mindgame. Reading it was delightful. Like London neighborhood candy with a side of popcorn for viewing live drama experience. NOT a musical, but beyond neighborhood theater group territory. More experimental than that and far more savvy. It IS Horowitz.I did not guess the perp. Although I did perceive other connections and motives in the reveal very early on. I actually wanted to give this 5 stars just for his dishing of current subjects by the primes in this one. Some are Horowitz himself, but not all. Like the belief that cultural appropriation makes it impossible for authors to write about anything but their own narrow specific identity category in any depth. Kudos, kudos Anthony. What judgment and superficial nonsense that is carried within groupthink during this decade is beyond imbecility.He also includes many theater and film references of the past. Far past and more recent as well. And trend of "label" and other values that may be less crossed in the last 10 years. This novel is all happening in 2018 while he is writing Moonflower, by the way. The entire book happens within just a few weeks of real time. Mostly in the rain. There WAS an essential detail I couldn't swallow. The fact that Horowitz couldn't recall within one day if he had carried that first night present package home with him on his walk back to his flat. In the rain and that late at night? You WOULD remember everything you had to hold. It's possible even a dementia individual would. Horowitz is early 50's. Come on! But it's fiction. I was just surprised that smarty pants left such an obvious void as acceptable questioning territory. I know he loses his phone, or his ticket etc. often. But you remember having to carry something when it is that bulky. Not pocket stuffer or coat breast material size at all.#4 is fun. It includes some small trips to the country and other offices. This one has TONS of London background building and neighborhood description. Makes you want to take a trip!Anyway, read it. Easier and more fun than the others. And of course, it also is a milestone. Because we finally find out more about Hawthorne and his background. Hawthorne still never eats and smokes continually. The two ridiculous police officers of the other books are prime in this one too. And just as obnoxious. Horowitz knows the law but in his book he acts and proceeds in copy like some of them don't exist, IMHO. But he makes every book hold a couple of outside the box characters beyond just the two inspectors and being truly procedural would ruin the fun. This one had at least 4 more of these and also his dog Lucky is a moving part.This one is not hard work to read like the others. I read it all within 1 day in just a couple of hours. And good news for more Hawthorne/Horowitz is on the horizon. Keep it up until #8. For sure....more

author: Eskens, Allen*

review: This one had a near perfect balance for my taste in this genre. Here is a good writer coming up to his better marks in #3. And within this one Joe himThis one had a near perfect balance for my taste in this genre. Here is a good writer coming up to his better marks in #3. And within this one Joe himself is nearly "out"- away on an assignment. And he needed to be. Lila was starving for development from the whining victim mess up of 3/4ths of her copy up until now. In the last book she was also "turned over a new leaf" saintly. And few things are more insufferable than a formerly hedonist self dramatic addicted neurotic who becomes the preach and teach straight laced role model. Yes, it's more than the smug and suffering quotients too. Lila had to step up and out. And in this one she finally did. By facing her insecurity and past guilts, but far more than that, by structuring her own core strength. Always "there" but formerly buried in self-pity and accepted mood of powerlessness. And I was super glad she did it ALONE without her Joe emotional crutches. Kudos, Eskens.Allen Eskens did a great job with Lila. Despite the rock climbing episode to get her there. Anything that works. But I did think that rather simplistic and over the top for Andi to contrive. It could have gone far wrong. And honestly, that is the only way to face down a Dovey. And you absolutely do need the "right" audience.But this is a duo narrator roller coaster beyond the Lila core. Gavin became carved as well. And you never lost the Minneapolis stream/ vibe. Not once. Summer on walkways high or river viewed are special. He didn't even leave out the bike rental stands. Are they still there? Chicago's lasted weeks before most were scavenged or stolen. Mostly scavenged.Good job. 4.5 stars and the ending was a double punch. Although I can very much "get" it could be possible. Some of these in this genre are just not believable at all for any forms of urban or country reality. And so satisfying to me was the "just desserts" - so appropriate. So many rules that the worst of the worst get out to do it again and again and again. Not just killing, but maiming and lifelong disability. Not for themselves by upon others.It was a bit too long with all the Lila past "replays" and cutting repeats etc.- and with all her same/same Mom interludes. Even the last one. That was a bit round the bend for a Mom who wrote that category of letter to Lila's therapist. The one aspect I did not find believable in this novel. But there are lots of readers out there who will eat up that portion. Other posters state they found this slow? I didn't. I always felt tension and progress to a speed pace, even during the first half.The short sequence within the prison dynamic was also good. True. For me his work has always been 3 stars and decent. But I thought this Lila and Vang duo one was the best of Talbert and also one of his best all told. I'll always try a Eskens. He knows lawyers and he knows coppers....more

review: Closer to a 3.5 star read but rounded up for the detail accuracy. Lisa See did some research for this one.Loving her first two novels and hardly enjoying many of the latter ones, this one was an excellent surprise. Here she returns to the 15th century and highlights a real life historic individual who was female, highborn and against all odds- developed the skills and recorded her courses of medical practices. But the highlight to me, and also See's greatest skill in prose was the female, female friendship and hierarchal female structures in family and seclusions under that period's mores / culture. And this one is absolutely focused and cored on this particular aspect. Not only with a woman from another class as friend either. Beware that many people will be appalled at this book's descriptions and detailing. Food binding process and other justice penalties being only the top of the nasty included. This is about female life in a secluded and entirely insular to view existence for the most part. Girls never see the outside of their own courts or rooms in that court until they are married away at 15 or 16. And some never after that either. It's not the only aspect here that modern readers will have issue or trouble with full cognition. It was a fast read up until the middle. The last parts just dragged for me. Having a son being the whole purpose of existence became exhausting.Much better than her moderns, and also has some good quotes that are as relative today....more

my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This one was a full 3.5 stars but I can't round it up or get anywhere close to 5 stars. Shifty's Boys might be in the running for most overrated book This one was a full 3.5 stars but I can't round it up or get anywhere close to 5 stars. Shifty's Boys might be in the running for most overrated book of 2022, IMHO.Don't misunderstand. The premise, plot, characters are nearly excellent- above average well done in detail and some of their quotes are too. BUT, this one held a thought pattern and a mood onus type of "directive" in Mick's judgment, personality, motives- that for me just did not fit. It did in Killing Hills. His prose flow in narration to mindset, thoughts etc. held preach/teach, and more than just a handful of strong social justice warrior type crux posits. Never, ever meet a person of his place, history in the Army, or any associated type of work within death scenes major that held such. It grated in me from just after the beginning 80 pages. Which until then was a full 4 stars. Loved the character of Shifty and as another er noted I thought of the same actress in Justified too.But it just doesn't work to have coastal elite prime "should this and should that" within the cultural mores of Kentucky. Not a fan. Panders to the readers and the author to himself (putting major cultural road blocks in the way of his writing) and doesn't meld. It's phony. And neither the electioneering Sheriff nor her brother would ply them. He also uses some Army language and technical aspects incorrectly and doesn't know what he doesn't know about that area of expertise, as well. He doesn't do research on this? Fiction IS fiction, but come on. USA Afghanistan loss of a more than another country's entire GDP in equipment, transport, arms, tech- just occurred. You need to be far more exact to name what you name accurately for a vet just after and during recovery for IED experience. How do you think HE feels about that? Talk to any. You'll find out.I was super disappointed that the author took that easy pleasy route and skirted reality there for Mick's history of knowledge and the language used in several different references. Mistake as bad as having the Pope overlook Good Friday and going to a brisket smoke bbq instead. Ok and fast read. Some fun and some thinking. But not anywhere in the territory of Killing Hills. And certainly not half as embedded in the mores of Kentucky itself as Killing HIlls was. Despite the dialect or quotes that did fit....more

title: Saturday Night at the Lakeside Supper Club
author: Stradal, J. Ryan*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: 3.5 stars accurately. Review tomorrow. Could have been immensely better without all the time switching. This lost 2 full stars for out of order guessi3.5 stars accurately. Review tomorrow. Could have been immensely better without all the time switching. This lost 2 full stars for out of order guessing gimmick used. 5 stars in entity of place/ locale feel/ content. The fixture of the title got battered through time chopping, but it did not get destroyed.Later with keyboard:Oh this deep carving for the Midwestern Supper Club during most of the last century was excellent. 4 stars plus. And so was my delight at reading about Prime Rib Night or Betty's Lemonade. BUT come on, did it need to switch 20 or 30 or 60 years back forth and then in the middle that many times? I didn't count but way more than a dozen. And often you knew more about the grandchild than you did the original owner or Floyd (without him none of it would have happened)or any grand parent or step-grand parent. And did that constant guessing game to naming or relationships keep the Supper Club or Jorby's in the shining lights they may have fully deserved? Nope- detracted from it. Not playing run around guess the connection either with Florence or Al or Betty or Mariel or Ned. Or Gustav or Julia either, at that. Or any of the staff that I would have wanted finer depth for this succinct nugget. Because some of the servers AND customers that flit through this EXPERIENCE, way too fast and unconnected! A travesty to fly their creativity and work habits right over the readers' heads.Because the Supper Club (and do I remember them well) was NOT a flit through fast or unconnected experience. AT ALL! Especially those that were connected to resort cabins or such. Like Sunnybrook Farm in SW MI. Here Minnesota was staged 5 star except no one was eating the rutabagas in Pasties which is NOT a heart healthy dish., btw. They would have been taking them on as fast as the ending Grasshoppers.But for those of you who don't know and love the 20th century supper club in the excellence that it was. (I can picture Jardine's relish dish as I type.) This may work for you better in such piecemeals bits. Yet happily, in fond memories of all the Betty bartenders and hostesses- 5 stars for the joy you brought the multitudes. This would have been SO much better in chronological order. Without changing the characters in any way one whit. There might have even been time for a singalong or two. But I still would have gotten at 7-7. We could have seen the excellent characters full bloom without all the switching nonsense redundancies. You might have begun to understand why Mariel waited two months to pick her mother up at church. Or why Betty thought she was in heaven....more

author: Turton, Stuart*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Enjoyable to read but closer to 3.5 stars. Reaction is mixed because the last 50 pages, IMHO, almost sunk the entire. Way too much, telling telling, tEnjoyable to read but closer to 3.5 stars. Reaction is mixed because the last 50 pages, IMHO, almost sunk the entire. Way too much, telling telling, telling. Explaining, explaining, explaining all the magic tricks and minutia of illusions. And that made the entire way, way too long. I did return to this novel after lengths of pausing for long intervals. There were reasons encased within the writing style itself and the wordy, wordy effusions etc. Too many reasons actually to list here and none of them are an overloading bother to most others so I will refrain. But this WAS a book that could have used an immense edit. And had the tension brought out, not drowned by the carved A personality level characters. Many of them.He has very excellent time/era feel (first half especially), plot, and subterfuge. But he lacks writing sharpness entirely. All the feelings, fears, dreads get buried in the "other stuff". Like directions, descriptions, tangents that are entire plots by themselves etc. And he especially does NOT do endings well. As much as I enjoyed the tale, I almost gave it 2.5 or 3 stars by the time it was finished. Because the "big scenes" of action were absolutely shipwrecked by the minutia of 100 trivia conversations. YOU KNEW their personalities enough. Plus he became entirely out of the time period itself in those conversations in the last half of the book. A book by itself, actually from the time of the last 3 tragedy events of Old Tom. Well I sure did like it far more than his other (7 Deaths etc. one) novel. But I will be dubious to take another of his on without a huge hole to put all that reading time in. He'd be much better if he knew how to get succinctly to the crux. And put his action cores (like the Aernt sword duel and the mutiny climax etc.) into the time they deserve. And not have them stuck anywhere. Nor leaving 60 pages to do all the explaining as a paste on.I didn't like Pipps. I don't know why. But Aernt was a terrific character. And I hope he writes one about Lia. That I might read....more

title: Miss Jane
author: Watson, Brad
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Review tomorrow. I had to look at the publishing date twice. Hard to believe it was written in 2016. 4.5 stars solid.Later: This was a poignant tale. Review tomorrow. I had to look at the publishing date twice. Hard to believe it was written in 2016. 4.5 stars solid.Later: This was a poignant tale. I read it within a day. It holds 3 of the most developed personality and carved characters that I've read in eons. Miss Jane, her father, and her doctor. And it is cored on the personal. As it occurred throughout great spans of history and until not that long ago. When dire or hard or hardest travail or life journey or condition or real placement was lived within the individual primarily. And not group shared so that every ill and/or condition became blame or voice toward advertised resounding negativity or retributions. Constantly and consistently visible too when it does absolutely no good, essentially the opposite. And Miss Jane also contains huge wisdom and grace within the personal cognition (self identity core itself) of being less or different or excluded or whatever else can happen. Because it surely does happen in human reality.The first half was good, but the second half was superb. I still can't believe it was written in this century. When everything that can be construed as bad has continual reaction of anger, blame and advertisement of the fact. Because I can remember decades that were quite like Jane's place and time for exactly the opposite. Excellent role models of how to accept adversity that can't be changed or limits beyond control of them.This so reminded me too of my friends who had polio when we were young and either never got old or lived for some years with constant handicap. One especially who I think of at least once a week and who lived until her 50's with immense grace. And those that ever after our peer play had their lives changed by violence at home or at war elsewhere. Most before we were grown. Some of us have huge handicaps (all types, some are not only physical) which others never see and have no conception at all to the recompense for them. And this book gives them the creds they so deserve and in beautiful flow of prose on top of it. Inspiration. There are so FEW books of inspiration for at least 3 decades now. Kudos to Watson....more

title: Song of the Dead        (DI Westphall #1)
author: Lindsay, Douglas*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Very smart prose with deep suppositions and psychic flirts. And complex. Review tomorrow.Later: This is procedural (heavy in various dictates/ associaVery smart prose with deep suppositions and psychic flirts. And complex. Review tomorrow.Later: This is procedural (heavy in various dictates/ associations too) but at the same time it is odd. Odd in a good way. Different. There are metaphysical implications. And the plot lines twist back upon each other. What happened 12 years ago in Estonia. Estonia today. The fallouts in Scotland from both periods. And the suppositions also include other "people met along the way" because of Westphall's plane phobia. And these became entwined. It was deeper in psychological aspects and in philosophical tend within the prose flow to be IN this procedural who-dun-it type of case/thriller. It was too long. Mainly because of all the drives and minutia of travel during stops between trains, ferries, rental cars etc. And IMHO, and probably only my own and not a majority opinion- I think the thought patterns for the plane fears and anxiety passages over future orders for time limits to get to the headquarters etc.- that became redundant/ repetitious. But Westphall's thoughts are of such depth to knowledge and experience that they were not impossible to swallow either. Not at all.PLUS- that is accurate for how phobia is and plays out. Not only flying in airplanes but within 90% of all phobias. Immense thought and anticipation fear proceeds for days or weeks. It's a hard read. It took twice as long to absorb as most books of this genre or series type. And if you don't have psych or even biologic background knowledge? This doesn't suffer fools in any sphere. Do you believe in a person splitting in two physically OR psychologically? Or is time travel mental side (not within physical body placements) actual/ possible and real? Lots of those types of conundrums here. As are many quotes put into forms that are true mind meals to digest. Some dozens I had to read twice or three times. And I won't add any here. Read them with patience. An exceptional writer will supply these to the reader on occasion. Lindsay does it nearly continually. It makes the copy exceptional in an exactness to mood/ nuance sense beyond just the intellectual high level. Coupled they are much above average. And I'm sure I'll read more of this series.But I will give myself time to fit these hard reads in also. They are not the type of book you can pick up and get right back in either. Too complicated to memory and to suggestions to do that easily or at all.Warning to those who dislike brutal in any form. Some of the information is beyond real for selling organs from kidnapped and imprisoned. title: The Boys from Biloxi
author: Grisham, John*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This for me was too long. Too much detail in 3rd person telling and not enough anything from within the prime characters' thoughts, "eyes". But that'sThis for me was too long. Too much detail in 3rd person telling and not enough anything from within the prime characters' thoughts, "eyes". But that's Grisham's style. As if a narrator outsider is telling you the tale. And for me they seemed real in their youths (baseball, sports, boxing etc.) but didn't work for me after adulthood.I know I am outlier about Grisham fiction. But I prefer a much more in head character development than a telling of their biography or job skills or actions more personal in nature etc. And that only occurs with Keith rarely here. Because I have visited Biloxi several times during the first decade of this century and 1 time for length at Gulf Shores in Alabama, not that far away. And because I did visit before and just after Katrina in that entire area- I knew much of the demographics and some of the places / structures. And know that his tale is not far from reality. Mary Mahoney's is the oldest restaurant in the USA proper. It was there before the Louisiana Purchase. He doesn't tell you of Beauvoir or any other places of greatest tourist or beach scenes. Beautiful beach.Hugh seemed so dark that the last 1/2 of the book became more like reading a court or grift, criminal cabal case. In an age where horrific was terrible but not on the scales it is now. Not with corrupt authority or with various treatments of reaction for the more special among us. Chicago has been worse for most of my lifetime. But I thought the periods of 1960's, 1970's was especially accurate for here and path progressions. Both.In Grisham writing I can never approach a 4 star rating. I've tried over many years and have omitted his works for eons. It is because you have very dry telling and hardly any knowing. For instance, in this book, you never once got to know Keith's wife. Actually none of the women were developed. They become a one or two syndrome name. Either angels or nasty crazies for the most part. But you never see "them" really, at all. Worse than Dickens- saints with halos or demons with purpose? I know others do not feel that way. But for me, that is fiction written for "knowing" at a grade school level. You may know the important soul aim or ambition or reaction but you NEVER know the person. All the law, court, punishment chapter lengths make it even more distant from any personality.Well, I have visited Biloxi and hope that the next hurricane doesn't wipe all the structures out again. Lots of history and interesting views there, regardless. In this one the background of Croatian immigrant experiences and the first 100 pages were far superior to the rest....more

Of any sort or origins. That she endured under those depths of torture. Believe me, they would never have gotten to pulling out the second toe nail for 99% of humans. Let alone all 10. This is not as good as his others. I think it is because you don't get enough of Odette "after". The same qualities that made her effective also make the longer later life hard to parse, methinks! title: Into The Lion's Mouth: The True Story of Dusko Popov: World War II Spy, Patriot, and the Real-Life Inspiration for James Bond
author: Loftis, Larry*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This is a super hard book to follow. Very complex, convoluted read. Much as the person Popov (Dusko) was. Intrepid and savvy brilliant of course, but This is a super hard book to follow. Very complex, convoluted read. Much as the person Popov (Dusko) was. Intrepid and savvy brilliant of course, but quite beyond that into 5 or 6 languages charming to mesmerizing at the same time. And despite months, years, decade more intimacies and friendships- little to almost nothing of a reveal about his own "identity" or onus or depth in background or family. Even to his most intimate youth to graduate student best friend. Johnny Jebsen who introduced him into the German intelligence portions of his long, long associations. Both in his life's "work" and in social spheres.The book is not as easy to read or to comprehend in continuity as his Odette and Alise spy biographies which were 4 or 5 star level. Those spy experts had a short run and it was a much later period of involvement and on a far smaller scale of intersects. But Popov! His started way before the war and some of the most intriguing microdot method reveals were prior to American entry into the war. Hoover knew about Pearl Harbor as a target. For sure. The documentation and massive lengths of pages of the documents themselves (at the end those and the sources are almost a third of the book length)! My Dad always said that Roosevelt knew too. Until his dying day he made it a habit to tell again and again. Most especially before each election day. And of his witness of information about Patton's assassination. He was in Trieste (1945-1947) after the European theater folded and headed a district for repatriating German or Axis soldiers back to their respective country entities or not (it depended on dozens of factors) from Italian prisoner of war camps. He said he saw proofs too in papers about speculation for the possible dates in these same circles of older documentations. Roosevelt and Hoover both had their reasons and the Depression was NOT getting better in USA, but worse in 1940 and 1941. Plus, the Allies side multitudes were imploring for the USA to get into the war. Quickly.This man Dusko Popov (Serbian core elite family, most of which were doctors or surgeons like his Father) was so multi sided that it is hard to keep all the code names and surnames straight. Yet to even get into all the vast distance interplays between them all. And try to understand where and how Dusko's family in Belgrade and Dubrovnik were fating at the same time and/or how he was trying to trade people out. (All moving pieces, endlessly- most especially with his brother Ivo.) (Ivo was either in the forest as an insurrectionist or in prisons. Ivo's wife and baby were scheduled to be shot or hung- three different times unless he gave up positions/ information.) There are 10 levels of intermix that you can't keep straight while reading. And Dusko is on 3 continents at various periods of 3 months to 4 months each for nearly 20 years. So how did he ply his conversations to all and in each of 20 different places? With at least a dozen to two dozen women girlfriends at the same time? Some of the same ones, in rotations. He loved it. The only time he was slow to leave was the year plus in the USA when he had the Hollywood actress Simon. But even in those months he was within at least 5 different cities by his own rotations within the USA alone. NYC, Hollywood were always two of them. In Europe he was anywhere from England to Egypt. Each place more than twice. Some within a 6 week period- 5 or 6 places. And the money to do this? That is a book alone. More than novel length to understand the money transfers and schemes. That was half of all spies subterfuge, IMHO- in man or woman hours. Does that give you pause to think about the downsides of digital currency and present tech? Or how authority can just "shut it off"- like they can fuel. But the best thing about this book and also the two others of his (Loftis) I have read are the Lisbon chapters (not all together whatsoever). (This is the place that is featured in the 007 movie Casino Royale). I can't imagine all those juxtapositions of intelligence and spycrafts or enemies from manufacture, to trade, to dangerous slip of the tongue, all in one place. On the ocean and within those sets of hotels and resorts. Paris and Rome, too. But always that Estoril, Portugal complex itself! The book is worth reading for those 1000's of particulars of Estoril and Lisbon in "neutrality" alone. All in one place. And the associations and visas exchanges to get there too. You get a tiny bit of Dusko's ending days after about 1960, but the majority of the copy is 1930-1950. The man lead at least 5 lifetimes in that one period alone. But you will need a brain like his to get through all the nuances and code names and codes to languages in this one. Quite beyond the personalities. I could have used more photos. Especially of Johnny and Dusko's brothers. Most of Johnny's course is still a mystery. Dusko, our James Bond, ended being naturalized as an English citizen. As did most of his birth family. More accurately, he was 003....more

review: No rating, but to be bottom line truthful if I had read the entire thing it would never go beyond a 2 star rating for my scales OR for my enjoyment.BeNo rating, but to be bottom line truthful if I had read the entire thing it would never go beyond a 2 star rating for my scales OR for my enjoyment.Because the base premise and the execution (pardon the slip of exactness) were both, for me, just awful. Awful in the tra-la-la voices and in the 4 women's relative nuance, mood, cognition and banter. Everything. When nothing could be further from a tra-la-la sense of either norms or any relative worth of what used to be called a conscience or respect for human life in anything of their ilk. Plus and this was the true stopper even with all the over the top stereotyping etc.- and that was the reality of those periods vs how they were contained as "real" here. These women were just a slight bit (4 or 5 years) younger than I was. Some of the time / era nuance (despite all the brand or fad or mod inserts of awareness like the L'eggs pantyhose reference)- was just ludicrous and sometimes jarring. Some authors know the culture / era feel from 1950's or 60's or 70's (American) enough to do that well (Horowitz, King). This one does not. At all. I'm shocked at how many readers gave this high marks. Probably the same people who liked Dexter? UGH! I have to have some window of belief possible? I did not here. At all. Got to 45% and threw in the towel....more

title: The Bottom of Your Heart: Inferno for Commissario Ricciardi        (Commissario Ricciardi #7)
author: de Giovanni, Maurizio
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This was 3.5 stars but I rounded up for the huge discourses that he did upon HEAT. I can't imagine living in Naples or Southern Italy in July without This was 3.5 stars but I rounded up for the huge discourses that he did upon HEAT. I can't imagine living in Naples or Southern Italy in July without air conditioning.But it was way too long with aside soliloquy for various aspects and side tangents. I know that it is unnecessary redundancy but here it bakes the whole. Its content of case or perceptions is closer to 3 stars. But I didn't skip or speed read as many Enrica moments of sections in this one. At least she is NOT sitting in her apartment window embroidering any more. But honestly, I can't read all of these many Ricciardi books for this very reason. The pace of years before you say an hello for courtship is just too much too long and too idiotic for me. And their acknowledging but NOT. Perverse and just does not interest me at all. He is hurting her MORE, not less as he believes.The case was much better than the last book and entails others and their work. Jeweler, doctor, cop.The Mother or the caretaker woman is so cored in these novels and in this culture. All the Ricciardi books especially. And yet, nearly no woman of any generation seems to have more than 1 or 2 at the most children. (Except for Rosa who is one of 11 and still lives in age as an aunt/ caretaker and little else.) If any kids at all. Many are completely childless. Children= starving in this series. Hmmmm? Italy now has the lowest birthrate in the world, I have read. Very understandable, actually. But in this book the gynecologist department head is the victim. And some babies ARE in the picture.The effusions of being "in love" with some of these de Giovanni men (all types and most men) is mindless and nearly nonsense in their actions and outcomes. And the jealousy factors? Women or men! Extreme. Almost completely lacking any thought of logic. Not a fan. The Bastards of Pizzofalcone series is much better for the balance of this and the humor alone. But I rounded this up because it does hold locale and progression. Well for both. And because it took huge passages for watching the emigrants depart for America and the ships/ docks. Interesting and filled with good-byes for which it is permanent break. And they know it. It was for my entire family that came the same exact way in the same time period. No one ever seeing the others again.First aboard at Rome, groups added at Naples to fill the below cabins, and you cram whatever room is left in Sicily at the bottom of the ship. True....more

title: Sometimes People Die
author: Stephenson, Simon*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Loved this read. For the first quarter I would have given it 5 stars. It got nihilistic during the last quarter which took it down about 1/2 star. ButLoved this read. For the first quarter I would have given it 5 stars. It got nihilistic during the last quarter which took it down about 1/2 star. But this book TRULY did make me laugh out loud about 7 or 8 times in a dreary fall gloom rainfall darkness. No small task.This is not for everyone. If you liked MASH (dark medical humor) you will like this one. Because its voice is BETTER than the dialogue of those doctor to doctor situations. Very sharp, crux, savvy writing. And he knows grief. From nearly all views, he does.I could list about 10 quotes, but I won't. Just one which gives you some idea of the pointedness of his phrasing. He doesn't need to tell and tell. For instance you get his first roommate within 3 paragraphs PERFECTLY. But here's a quote about structure surrounds:"It looked like an asylum that a distracted child had constructed from a half dozen unmatched Lego sets." (St. Luke's- the hospital where he is hired.)You can TRULY tell he does screen writer. And also that he is a doctor. An M.D.- for real.The perp and ending situations I half guessed. But they are unusual and I doubt others with get more than 30% of it, because the whole is outlier. But you might if you have a lot of Psych. training. Well, I recommend if you don't mind reading about addicts. That's embedded. But it is probably closest to the truth of some particular experiences that I have come across in out of 100's of these moderns. This one isn't obnoxious people either. You should know that. In fact, 75% of them are wonderful in the breech humans.Best book I have had recommended to me in about 6 months. I will read his others. For sure....more

title: The Godmother: Murder, Vengeance, and the Bloody Struggle of Mafia Women
author: Nadeau, Barbie Latza
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Horrific details. Truly, this was stomach turning. Not only the mores, but the practices (common) for revenge, they belong more in the late Middle AgeHorrific details. Truly, this was stomach turning. Not only the mores, but the practices (common) for revenge, they belong more in the late Middle Ages, then they do now. This is not only killing for payback or dominance, but tortures of the worse types and suffering intensified on purpose.For the women, and by the women. Just as well and double the volume. Down to killing the two year olds volume. Not always quickly.I don't recommend this book unless you have a high threshold for reality of some of the very darkest capabilities of humans. I'm serious. I knew it was bad, and that Naples is the USA Armed Forces Hazard Pay station for a reason. Thank God my grandparents left Italy when they were teenagers and never returned. This is endlessly embedded within every striation of the population and economy. Not only Sicily. Worse in Naples and Calabria as they are not consolidated into one head but are divided by clans. Women's "flying under the radar" or not? Their onus and outcomes are with higher levels of connection to the intiated, much the same. And cruelty even worse.The form is hard to read as most non-fiction becomes. Because Pupetta Maresca's long life story is told throughout others over the decades embedded within the other women of her era's competitions. Decades. And every day a certain death if loyalty to omerta and the sources are betrayed.The journalist Nadeau is intrepid. And when 20 to 30 years younger was quite beyond naive to traipse into those elevators, towers, warren paths of alleyways. The Le Vele stories today and most recent for the women from Nigeria? Well, I had to actually skip parts as the trafficking and treatments were so bad.As I said, do not read this just on a whim. It's heavier than North Korean or other genocide torture practices. And executions. Because it lives behind a more "normal" serene face.The opinion of woman on the whole! Even to picking their own spouse or path. Or having capability for authority or direction? It's not only in the Mafia/Camorra/'Ndrangherta at all. It is embedded within the entire culture and cognition.But Covid shut downs have made every branch bigger/ dominant stronger and more controlling of the economy than ever before. And male nuance for women's onus is little different. So if you want a REAL slice of how it works, read this entire. Now the small business is existing hugely upon Mafia loan and sufferance.The author lives in Rome and often is in France. But has lived a long walk with this for decades and knows Italy. Not every dialect, but close. I loved the quote from Pope Francis about women which personifies this cognition. Another cultural set of mores which holds concept of female gender as somewhere on a lower scale and other type of Earth than men's. The named and described organizations are more powerful and with stronger eventual outcome than the government of Italy OR the Church. The government may actually run third.It IS very much like the Middle Ages in other aspects as well. Often brothers, sons, daughters, uncles are destroyed for similar reasons than the "line to the throne" power grabs between nobles during the Renaissance. Pupetta's eldest son was killed by the father of her second born twins, for instance. Terrible, terrible lives. No peace....more

This one seemed to me, unrealistic. Possible? But not probable. There is so little joy in this place and time and so much literal starving that I find the entire series just gets set down an entire peg for eyes and perceptions. There is little humor and immense irony.Within this series I will space out various reads with much more joyful and simple. And maybe inspiration cored. Because these are the opposite. And might read them out of order too, as they are not all translated or easy to access. And I will definitely be speed reading or skipping Enrica views. That is entirely too much, too long for me. Not a fan. All the rest is excellent flow prose and a look into Naples and Southern Italy in general that is seldom so layered in depth....more

title: Everyone in Their Place: The Summer of Commissario Ricciardi        (Commissario Ricciardi, 3)
author: de Giovanni, Maurizio
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This embeds you into the mainstream summer heat and Ricciardi's life. It's case difficult personified. And the title is EXTREMELY core. Much a tell. AThis embeds you into the mainstream summer heat and Ricciardi's life. It's case difficult personified. And the title is EXTREMELY core. Much a tell. And I didn't see application at all until the last 20 pages. Maybe because there are so many other words. It does border on wordy.Ricciardi's personality and gift/curse of his victims' visions and last seconds? Well, it sure doesn't cast any spirit of joy upon the complex scenarios of any portion of his life. And the times are also skin and bones horrific for the majority (here starvation is as real as death and accompanied by the living horror of its desperation).The wonderful de Giovanni soliloquy come alone, as well. There is one to Sunday. One to summer plantings accompanied by drought and being served with their daily water. Several shorter to the modes of a selfish life lived with total disregard for the people under the same roof. And with 5 separate entities under that roof not having much, if anything, to do with each other.It's fate crying / moaning Italian vibe strength. It is also overlong. But the case was, IMHO, excellent. Not usual whatsoever. Complicated even upon murderer motive. And methods. And time order. Duplicitous in numbers beyond in deed. I believe there was a Columbo (TV series) with that motif once. Agatha had one. But it's rare. And rarer the outcome of solving it, as well.Well, the Ricciardi / Enrica plotting is being carried out way too long. Patience is one thing. But at 24 years of age and in this time and place? Not completely unbelievable. Yet it borders on delusional and mentally "off" for some of the focus for this duo. They lost me already. Such backward self-protection and emotional OR physical imagination without any two sided communication? Just not a fan of this means of courting whatsoever. The Duchess got what she deserved? Hmmmm?Regardless, I like the Bastards series much, much better. There is humor and savvy interchange continually there. These Commissari hold many effusion tracts but not a whole lot of human normal. Grim situations for the peasants and the land vacant from people leaving for another continent. Not much fun in aftermaths anyway you consider it. Especially in that kind of sweltering heat....more

title: Cold for the Bastards of Pizzofalcone
author: de Giovanni, Maurizio
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This was not as good as Bread or Puppies but actually had a better double murder case. And also an excellent side inquiry re a 12 year old girl's essaThis was not as good as Bread or Puppies but actually had a better double murder case. And also an excellent side inquiry re a 12 year old girl's essays. (Accusing of sex abuse?) And because I've read out of order, I know what progresses with the Bastards personal lives too. But, possibly I have more nuance overall. You probably can read out of order without much difficulty. It seems not all have been translated. This author does the "repeat chorus" in prose that some poets use well. He holds excellent locale detail nuance and also perceptions of moods. In this one, most especially at the end of a long day "going home". But in every book there is deep mired philosophy or core intent or some general state (like cold, or spring, or loneliness etc.)- some abstract that becomes a pivot for the primes or the suspects. It's skillful and he is way, way above average for a writer in this genre. Or any general fiction forms that are in any best seller realm. He especially seems to grab the emotional sides of "fate" well. Very Italian in every sense of expression for it, too. It's a specific Italian perception of irony that is not common. Other Italian authors reflect it too. But de Giovanni is expert.In this one the Bastards become fully formed under Palma with the hierarchy above being solidly set into their "get your fingers out of our pie" foundation for operation style. Now, they seem to be an entity glued to tasks and not reactive of consequences from above nearly as much. Very central to all the ploys and details of their work in Naples now. And with Romano and Aragona as a team- so much wider operational overlay. Even more so than the other 4 primes. You begin to understand how they (all of them) use the snotty Aragona snark and insult for twisting information out in reactions. Or his sympathy ploys too. Within the 12 year old's cast of characters scenario that was superb. It was best "not a murder inquiry accomplished" that I've read in decades. They didn't need social workers either. They just used Marco's mouth with a side of panache acting.Naples itself is cold here. And did I actually laugh out loud for their "sufferings". Or boiler or space heater woes. It seems in Naples a drop of 20 or 30 degrees is catastrophic. I live where it can drop in temperature easily at least 50 to 70 degrees F in one day. And then it STAYS there.When it comes to outdoor temperatures these people are sure a bunch of woosies. Strongly recommend this series. And start from #1 if at all possible. And then this one in the cold....more

title: I Will Have Vengeance: The Winter of Commissario Ricciardi        (Commissario Ricciardi #1)
author: de Giovanni, Maurizio
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This first in the Commissario series is 3.5 stars rounded up for the operatic imagination.This is a good writer within a depth of culture and place thThis first in the Commissario series is 3.5 stars rounded up for the operatic imagination.This is a good writer within a depth of culture and place that holds detail and nuance to a higher degree than most in this genre. For sure. This time the tenor is the victim. And much of the copy happens in the theatre/ opera house. The logistics get a bit repetitive and the whole becomes slow in the middle. I didn't think the pace was apt as much as the others I have read by this author. But then, this IS #1 and holds a lot in introduction to a character that is truly "odd" and within a dire time, at that. 1930's in Southern Italy holds living experience daily for memory of starvation, disease, and "missing" (all those who left for another continent who never will return) quite beyond just the politico.He sees the dead and hears their last words/thoughts. A almost identical scenario that I just happened to watch seasons for a New Zealand cored "One Lane Bridge" drama. Not an uncommon coincidence though. So many books, film, tv and cable streaming seem to be following some of the same base tenets. Especially if they have a police core or any copper procedural process as their home. Psychic cops or lawyers have been around for eons actually. I think Tony HIllerman had more than a few. But Ricciardi is immersed in graphic visions. I will read more of these for the characters, but I really like the Bastards of Pizzofalcone bunch much better. More than a handful of reasons. Some of them on the prose flow/ literary with the big L side at that. This Commissario era is so filled with starving lost and displaced beyond just the occult angle aspects. It is sad (despair sad) to miserable nearly every waking hour for the Commissario Ricciardi. Living with death. Oh yes, green eyes were mentioned WAY too often....more

title: Puppies
author: de Giovanni, Maurizio
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: These are terrific novels. But this one of the series is best read so far. All 6 bastards of Pizzofalcone and their boss come into full flower of theiThese are terrific novels. But this one of the series is best read so far. All 6 bastards of Pizzofalcone and their boss come into full flower of their essence here. Before you knew them for a couple of quirks, their nicknames (given by Aragona), their main personality related investigative techniques or descriptions. They were so overboard in most cases that they were nearly cartoonish. But NOW, you know each by the doing and what is core human. Not at all by the telling. And they are emotion and habit real, nothing like any cartoon.Baby humans, puppies, kindly and wild animals both and all- but intrinsically the most vulnerable! Our beloved pets!The soliloquy this time is to "the city" (Naples). She is female. And the old evils or new evils- curvy, manipulative, female like. These parts are all in italics in this series, hard for me to read. BUT, they are 5 star. Superb, exquisite writer. Some of his flow is close to poetry. Not just in the italics portions of "think piece" either. Naples with its sinuous curves of hills and peak and sea and bay. Most dangerous, lustful, and crafty. It is. (At one time it was the only place not at actual war zone status where the American soldier stationed near the bay got hazard pay. It is the only place I've ever been where women, two times, stopped me and motioned I could NOT carry my purse like that.)Fully formed as a team too now. Palma listens and doesn't only give orders. But when he does, he does. And as they seek the answers to one crime, they are with the "president" and "Serpico" finding quite another set.I sure hope all these books become translated. I will read all that do. And will start the other series set in 1930's Italy soon. It's not every month you find a new writer with so much material this GOOD and also this deep. The entire genre rarely gets this savvy or "eyes" this literate into a crime cityscape with superlative plots and counterpoints. Every time within the sharp perceptions of individuals. Victims are such, even more than the authority or the perps are.Immigrant who tried to do it "right" on top of it. And Romano! No words. We just had adoption in my family within the last year. What JOY!So- traffic that is the worst and most dangerous I've ever seen (not one whiff of an exaggeration- I could not even watch from a hill- no one stays in "their lane" whatsoever) in real life. And Alex Di Nardo (Calamity Jane) gets to use her shooting skill. What more could be added! 5 stars....more

review: This evaluation is savvy. Accurate. I thought the first pages were also 5 star nervy and witty (both) to posit such a tale as of the Nacirema. AbsolutThis evaluation is savvy. Accurate. I thought the first pages were also 5 star nervy and witty (both) to posit such a tale as of the Nacirema. Absolutely apt. Politics of this "correct" ideology has absolutely become just like a religion.Up is down and down has become up. And the high priests speak and tell us what language to use. This is well worth a read by all. But especially the Americans who see identity politics as core onus. Death of merit is a dead end. And we see already the outcomes of using it as a way to "better".I actually did not think he became specific enough. True victims of crime and circumstance of current "hero" manipulations are also trivialized by the current "victim" label assessments given by the mighty. Vivek's personal and family history reflects that of many brand new Americans, as well.Other excellent points that come out of this situation were made. Good writer on top of it....more

And were the flags all missed here. Every teacher I know who has been a professional for over 20 years has had to report student with observable criteria far less than Morgan's were. And that was covered VERY little in this book. Some years my daughter has had to remove 2 or 3 students out of 60 per grade that do not belong for safety in the public school classroom. Inclusion be damned. Self-harm or such observable psychosis actions are dangerous in classroom density. Yes, I do understand how most teachers have no time or background depth in mental illness windows as opposed to abnormal developments or acting out or whatever. But STILL. Many of Morgan's behaviors in group were way beyond the outlier for this to be ignored.So sorry for length, but this gets dicey. I wonder if Hale is off. She has some delusions equal to Anissa's for reality of Slenderman's powers. Hers are of the brainwashed elitist variety though. Not about a Slenderman though, but about base reality of everyday school and law juxtapositions. And the moralities involved, as well. Murder and horrific long term bodily harm (like castration, mutilation of body parts, stunting of normal hormone productions etc.) are all just fine and dandy if delusion must be served? How subjective!So take this one with a big grain of salt. Girls in this were lethal. And their outcomes extremely more advantageous than majority of mental health psychotics or felons who are left without shelter or supervisions in every geographic location on Earth. So here you do NOT get a balanced view of this particular case of terrible, terrible stabbings etc. What you DO get is an above average insight into detailing of the progression and days leading up to the horror. And the exact mindsets of the two girls who enabled it to come full circle accomplished. The voice and cognition both of the victim is nearly absent. And as for the online obsession issue- this could have happened with any pretend "entity". It has in the past with witches, or vampire tales, or goblins or 1000 other characters make mighty by imagination. Only difference is that the internet seemed to make it more easily believable to the super immature and bored. But it could have happened too and HAS with just games and talk. Many documented cases of this way before tech was even in the picture. ...more

title: Pane per i Bastardi di Pizzofalcone
author: de Giovanni, Maurizio
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Well, I certainly will be reading more from this author. The read was delightful and almost a complete departure from the current modern too. All the Well, I certainly will be reading more from this author. The read was delightful and almost a complete departure from the current modern too. All the people were far from despicable, actually. Even the perps had some redeeming qualities. And the group of cops from the district of Pizzofalcone! The ones called the Bastards. They each and every one are culturally carved in nuance, appearance, methods, and especially in voice reflecting their core emotions. Which isn't the usual for cop copy fare.Different ages and in various parts of the life stream. 2 women and 4 or 5 men (if counting the boss). And a prose flow that is also unusual. Difficult but in mood and action sense so very Italian. Kudos to the translator.The beginning is a 9 out of 10 in difficulty scale. But once you get all their nicknames, surnames and most usual means of duty proceeding- it gets easier. Not easy, but easier. This is NOT an easy read.Not cozy, but also not brutal. Logic and order and tradition are mightily served. It's quite real. The story of the MOTHER yeast and the baker with his role of centuries? Loved it.3 or 4 cases all entwined and each gets an answer. That is also unusual. And Naples and Southern Italy are HUGE core stars. Sardinia, Sicily alive. And quite authentic, not dressed up or Mafia disguised either. Regardless, this time the Mafia has nothing to do with it!He (de Giovanni) has masses not translated? But this Bastards series seems to be. His picture looks fairly young. Very good writer. This particular would make an excellent film or even a series. All I wanted was for Montalbano to show up or consult!Nearly a 5 for me. And I could put it down because the continuity did jump within the cases and the various prime Bastard's inquiry. But the timing was chronological and clear. Tons of personality quirk jokes and considerable marriage cheating here. Not with our coppers. The parts with Romano who found the infant girl in the dumpster and aftermath were 5 stars. Knowing the adoption process- I sure want to read #6.Well, there is an entire whole series I have started out of order. But I don't think it will be a big hurdle to back track. He has other series and standalones. But also the dialogue and continuity flow of a screen writer. And I did not read the Kindle, but the paperback. But as all else is in Italian, I listed this under the English trailer. Oh I want a piece of that particular bread!...more

Patterns of guess for category of crime scene information itself was excellent. But after so many repetitions, I still never contained the definitive crux for; A plus B= the most accurate guess about the C perp. Much of it is intuition to evidence patterns beyond all else. But not all. And they were completely wrong about BTK. It always surprises me that they don't list the perfectly "off" descriptions they have made.Regardless, if you watch any crime TV on Oxygen or A & E or HLN or any true life film (First 48, for example)- you will get more out of real technique and interview as it plays out in 2020 plus.Most of his career was before DNA or high degree evidence testing. So what he did accomplish was mighty. But he sure knows it too. An extremely nervy, pushy and high identity "me" person is John E. Douglas. But that's what it takes. Kudos.Be aware that stranger murder is and has been increasing. And know the other or had a connection murder has decreased. title: License to Pawn: Deals, Steals, and My Life at the Gold & Silver
author: Harrison, Rick
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This gets 5 stars for teaching me the reality of pawning and selling. I thought I knew but I truly didn't.That's what I love about non-fiction. It teaThis gets 5 stars for teaching me the reality of pawning and selling. I thought I knew but I truly didn't.That's what I love about non-fiction. It teaches you. What you see on TV is not the pawning, but the buying/selling aspects. Pawning is entirely different. And storage needed to do this is multiple, multiples beyond the sizes and spaces of the pawnshop or front desk or displays etc. It's massive. Pawned OR bought items have to be listed and police searched item by item for 1 month before they are even "stored" for the next part of the resale or 6 month wait to see if the pawn customer comes back to pay his bill/interest and/or retrieve her/his items. It's complicated. And very, very register and legal aspects heavy. EVERY item has to be searched for the multiple reasons of being stolen or illegal or whatever else the police decide makes it "theirs". (Patriot Act made this even more lengthy and invasive a process.) He is the credit source for all the people who cannot afford a bank account or have zero credit available to them. Banks and money available for the bankless. And are there RULES. You do need to have a good number ability in your head to even begin this process. Costs are mighty for all that storage. In Vegas it is not air conditioned either- huge warehouse. And he doesn't make Chumlee go back to work there either- that's just a joke used on the program. Although both younger members you see have worked all the hard jobs. Over night window duty for years too each. Which is tricky and alone. You are behind a huge glass enclosed bullet proof extension with one slot to get things through. ALL NIGHT from closing to 6 am in the morning. And that wasn't the hardest jobs. Not easy work.Rick is a superb writer for memory and for exchanges. He also has HUGE historic or manufacturing history knowledge. He knows more about power tools or grinders than he does about jewelry. And about jewelry he knows a TON. The book and kindle contains some 6 star photos of his "keepers". Strange choices, very interesting. I had no idea that they saw all types of humans and in every condition you could imagine or begin to describe. Or that the 4 main people you see on tv can no longer work any front desk (not since show 1 either) because pawning is a "privacy protected" action by law. What you see is sales. Very different. And they are staged with the shop being closed and just a few random customers allowed to roam and look. This was written in 2011 and his Dad has passed since then. There is a short section written by his Dad and two others by Corey and Chumlee. They both have harrowing tales to tell too, as their lives were NOT the silver spoon variety. Not at all. Both had biological mothers who left with no forwarding address. Their sections were as interesting as Rick's was. Corey spent 5 "lost" years- you have to hear this tale.Great stories. Rick proves the old adage that the worst childhoods often insure the most incredible success outcomes. I've seen this in at least 10 people personally. Terrible at school, filled with sickness and disability- you name it. Parents that are workaholics and don't much supervise is also a huge plus for some people who know what they want and how to do it young. No stoppers. Rick had grand mal seizures and temporary (but he didn't know that at all) blindness repeatedly at 16. He spent days a month at doctors (from 8 to 17) waiting in Armed Services (Navy, his dad) lines for different blood tests or whatever else they were going to try or evaluate. He missed at least 1 week a month from school. Usually 2. And he didn't finish h.s. And yet he read constantly. Do the people of Goodreads, understand THAT. Don't even talk to him about government medicine systems.Strongly recommend reading this book. His people tales are IMMENSE lessons for how people live their lives the way they WANT TO LIVE THEIR lives. And all the roads to happy are NOT the safe, nor the fully responsible either. Gambling itself is a tremendous middle part here of this book. It made me think very differently than what I assumed about gamblers. Or even the ones I've known who seldom stop. Very informative.Could I drop all sentimentality as this family has with "stuff"? I doubt it. But I love to watch the show (and History channel in general too) and especially historic antiques. I just had no idea how many power saws you can get during a building recession or complete housing collapse market. Or what you have to "eat" when 2000 grinders or tile cutters are cleared by everyone and then 2 years later you find they were employee stolen but never reported. And now you have to pay for all of them sold and return the rest.And you got to watch all of yours too. MANY employees now, and for 15 years at least. Closely. There are just as many cameras and security at Gold & Silver than there are in the casinos. Some days, even more.Great read. And I always have known those permits (even the lottery ones) that cities supposedly give fairly for licensing are 90% fixed. You donate to the politician is the first step. Rick had to call every week for years and years first thing in the morning to get the first one that came up with residency counts changing constantly because for decades there was status quo limit. And it took a court case to get it made official after the first issue too, on top of it. The big pawn chains were in the fix. And the shop is in a bad neighborhood. Visitors are always shocked at what's next door....more

title: Rouge Street: Three Novellas
author: Xuetao, Shuang
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Fabulous. Witty. Savvy. Best fiction I have read for a modern Chinese writer. Review tomorrow. Translator did quite a job. Kudos.This work does not suFabulous. Witty. Savvy. Best fiction I have read for a modern Chinese writer. Review tomorrow. Translator did quite a job. Kudos.This work does not suffer fools. The author entwines and embeds but at the same time many elemental factors are widely scattered. In time elements, in generational directions, within tremendous authority upheavals. You name it for historic or abstract bents (either) and you will get it all dished out pell-mell mixed. And it's also succinct amid language flow which I find, I did myself, unique for anything Chinese I've ever read. Order and wit are also different. Everything is like turned inside out and the matter and seams "inside" are exposed. Not being a fan of magic realism much at all, there are elements here that also become mystical or almost Greek gods or "other world" drifting. Especially within the dance related novella which also bridge crossed Christianity.See, it's complex. I would give the first two novellas a full five. The third one? 4.5 stars and I still really don't understand most of it. But I will reread it at a much later date and see what I "pick out" then. Because that's what is true for all of these. Masterful writing, filled with reality and yet tragic and then yet inspirational and then yet despair. It's a viscous mix. And also many points are gorgeous and cyclical both.When I think of the 400 to 700 pagers I've read that say next to nothing. Especially about China and its experiences of the last 100 years! STRONGLY recommend this book. A gem and almost completely unsung in any book listing publications I've read re recent publishing. Put your true thinking caps on and read of these journeys. Some looking for mothers or livelihoods. Others looking merely for warmth. Or for food. Or for trust. Or for creative muses. Brutality times ten but it isn't demonstrated or exposed or described like it would be in any Western sense much at all. Especially within language of anger or acts. That's what I LOVED the most about these. Their complete Chinese cognition is showing. Over and over. And the expressions! What a translator. Here I want to put about 30 phrases with ultimate nuances in short quirk which I'm sure have absolutely accurate meanings for Chinese now and then. But no, you find them. But be aware too that the punctuation is not "norm" or English slanted whatsoever. And that voice and thoughts and times not only switch but there are voids to cross, as well.This author is described in trailers as frank. Oh yes! As soon as his other masses of stuff get translated, I'll be reading it. Just a master with the big L for literary or lyrical or love. Quite beyond all the other Chinese fiction nuance I've read. Which is probably at least 60 to 100 of them over the years.So come to the frigid Northeast which isn't that far from the North Korean border. To Shenyang and into Shuang Xuetao's old neighborhood. And over the mighty hills of revolution, Communism, and into the ditches or culverts scattered with array of social ills from market economies. Gritty and yet absolutely funny as well. So glad I picked it up just from the cover. And when I had WAY too many modern YA level sense in the pile that are currently billed thriller or psychological novels.As these characters actually say once in the last novella- "he has a high class disease." (It's depression which no one else could ever afford in the past or memory.)...more

title: Remember: The Science of Memory and the Art of Forgetting
author: Genova, Lisa*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This is a worthwhile read for a majority. More so if you are over 50 years old. But everyone could benefit to learn how and why and in what linkings oThis is a worthwhile read for a majority. More so if you are over 50 years old. But everyone could benefit to learn how and why and in what linkings of ingredients will enable better memory. But I am not the target audience of this book. She writes clearly but at a very elemental/ base level of cognitive introduction and knowledge. It is a HUGE and to me enthralling area of both medical and psychological inquiry. And here she takes more medical or total novice material. An almost amateur track to both defining and explaining process. And because I worked in cognition studies during graduate schools over decades of changes in the field- plus all my tracking experience- this wasn't at all "my bag". Also some of the book re diet and habits etc. It's mainly opinion. And very little science. Some science but only of the most inexact types of research.Memory is an intriguing (core central) feature of living CONSCIOUSLY. Emotionally positive methods for forgetting the negative and memory enhancement techniques for bolstering positive detail and an innovative overview! Well, they are a learned behavior that can be taught with written material and real life exercise practice methods which are far more exact that this was. Cognitive psychology is more than fascinating. Enough so to be a ten times length of one lifetime enterprise for inquiry. Making a real effort to listen and ATTEND is the key. How to attend and when attention can be enhanced/ increased? Practice make improvement. I don't think that was emphasized half enough here....more

title: Killing the Legends: The Lethal Danger of Celebrity
author: O'Reilly, Bill*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This is a better read than 3 stars, IMHO, for those who have not lived through these eras' lifetimes.Three men who had charisma and talent. And who alThis is a better read than 3 stars, IMHO, for those who have not lived through these eras' lifetimes.Three men who had charisma and talent. And who also had flaws. The largest common denominator being dependent personality which was massively used by others for profit. Generally NOT for the better well being of the three men either, in any sense.Honestly there was nothing new that Elvis or John Lennon information imparted to me here in this book. Elvis I've read probably 10 to 15 books back in the day and for Lennon about 1/2 of that. I also have read non-fiction on Mohammed Ali, but this book was much more specific and interested me far more than the others of decades past. This gave me greater insight into the decision making to do those fights after he was 32. The Mohammed Ali section was close to a 5. He was a smart and savvy individual who knew what he believed and tried to live it. But like many of us, his financial and personal lives were hugely detrimental to him as a person- both physically and mentally. And for pure greed he was physically manipulated and destroyed without much quibbling about it, as well. Because the Nation of Islam and much else of his manager and financial guru's life was in Chicago, I have witnessed some of the criminal behaviors involved myself. But putting him through that much harm after terrible injury, again and again with so much slanted money going to nearly everybody by Ali? Oh the people who gained over his misery! Terrible. I do remember the torch lighting ceremony at the Olympics. Touching plus.All three tales were researched to the max. But each life had so many horrific negatives based within the characters and habits of the 3 themselves? Well, it is hard to tell stories of addicts in any sense. Or in most any addictions, as well. Heroin and opiods or attention. But still addiction plus. But especially within the spheres of great celebrity. But all three lived within huge dependencies to stronger personalities and whims and were manipulated far, far more than it looked from the outside. Lastly, Ono was continually made the bad guy in nearly ever sense of talent use or lifestyle or break up choices etc. It's not true. I always knew that too. People on the "outside" so seldom see the depths of flaws within their idols. Overall that is accurate. They would rather see the perfections and the image (and the replays of their talent) rather than the person anyway even unto long memory....more

title: The Couple at No. 9
