my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: The raving s made this more anticipated by me as I was on a Kindle loan wait and read a few before I read the book? That's unusual for me. Yes, The raving s made this more anticipated by me as I was on a Kindle loan wait and read a few before I read the book? That's unusual for me. Yes, I thought it would be more enthralling, or exciting, or convoluted or mysterious. But it was merely good and also long. It actually patterned a speed by which such scenarios are investigated in real life present 2022. DNA helps but at times it just opens the door for 50 more questionings. As it did here. All takes time and is hours and hours of inquiry.After Rose in the care home kept mentioning Jean hit "someone" - I had huge inkling where this was going. So I guess, I read too many of these English who-dun-its. My surmise was not exactly right but quite close. It's the particular speed and connotation style that made me round this down 1 whole star. Very word repeating, and also extremely clothing related. Not only in descriptive moxie of first introduction, but in the constantly taking off or putting on coats, jackets, tams, sweaters, different heeled shoes etc. etc. Having read about 10 Italian translated fiction pieces in the last month, I recognize that over abundance in several different Italian authors, as well. I'm patient. But I wish a better edit was done so that this or some "bush tea" detail is not ever again and again presented. It never helps a book. In this one it was so heavy that it almost buried the huge intrigues of sneaky subterfuge. Overall though, the author has hit a core issue that is seldom crux any longer. In another age, it was far more common. Too much individual forensics to nail in this present day to format or even initiate this plot scenario easily. Now, this ploy gets caught faster than 40 years later. Not always, but close to always. Very rare to win this game while staying in the same country.You know there is another factor that truly took my enjoyment of this book down a peg. It was hard to return to and took me nearly a week. It was Saffy. Introvert is one thing, but she was also rather a huge pill. I felt sorry for Tom. Her needs exhausted me just reading about them. Lorna actually made this book worth the 400 pages. A little nutty, but she was worth the read. I might look to others of hers. But I think I will seek out the page count first.For those of you that get terribly confused by names or nicknames or surname specifics. This is probably not the book for you....more

title: Mid-Air: Two Novellas
author: Shorr, Victoria
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: My serendipity read for the month turned out to be nearly a 5 star. Mid-Air was an apt title too. One family is swirling down and the other going up. My serendipity read for the month turned out to be nearly a 5 star. Mid-Air was an apt title too. One family is swirling down and the other going up. Both are in mid flights over the course of a century or two in economic and cultural senses. Do I agree with the nuance and voices which do the telling and the showing? In some cases, not at all. But her characters and forms are way above average for fiction presently. She does a type of bordering run-on sentence which leaves the speaker or descriptive mode almost breathless. And yet somehow this cuts to the essence quick. Her context for nearly everything involved for the entire scenario also embedded. Not creating voids of "mystery" instead (real holes in information) as is the habit in this family epic telling that has become endemic in large majority of publications this last decade. Almost as much as the switch, switch, switch craze.Knowing nothing at all beforehand was also something that made the experience enhanced. The less you know the better.She also holds a considerable "snob" cornered distinctions within herself, I think. That's why, IMHO, the first novel was better because she knows FAR MORE about that course. I would have given it a 5 star if standalone. The other (Cleveland Wrecking Company) was almost exactly a 4 star. Wonderful carved characters but she doesn't know enough about small business growing and it showed. I do. In very similar fields, at that. Under worse "government is here to help" nasty too. And she puts much more emphasis on brothers' women's "side of the tracks" or drink choices etc. Rarely does that matter to that degree as assumed here. Nor in outcomes as much as pure time inputs and hunger for "more". Third generation is the crux point of that need and effort. But it was well written. And I'd bet the readership here likes it more than Great Uncle Edward.I definitely would read her again. Gifted and a true wordsmith. Lots of narrating and fewer dialogues is usually not a favorite for me. But her writing style itself is very good with an excellent and different flow. Almost unique....more

title: Lucy by the Sea        (Amgash, #4)
author: Strout, Elizabeth*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Amgash #4 was so anticipated. I gave #3 a 5 star rating. Oh William! was a top five read of the year. This one disappointed. It's mundane, sad and neaAmgash #4 was so anticipated. I gave #3 a 5 star rating. Oh William! was a top five read of the year. This one disappointed. It's mundane, sad and nearly petty. Like gossip in comparison to a witty or savvy observation reveal conversation. There is a difference. This was old news rehashed for more reaction but all the freshness of the earlier Lucy was, for me, completely gone. The vibe is cranky. And elitist cranky on top of it. And the entire tale as a whole, just depressing. Every aspect you could easily name/ describe in Lucy for this Covid and after period is reactive behaviors. Who would guess that someone with SO many dislikes would take the path of least resistance and become closer to dependent turgid. Fear coupled with drama of angst is and never will be my favorite core topics. UGH! And I don't even begin to like William, on top of it. Nor his dominant bullying habits. But I did say, way back in the day despite her being a favorite writer, that Lucy (Elizabeth of course) is exactly the woman I tend to avoid. Friends of short or long life times always being women of action and not reaction. Doers and hardly any observers that hold past baggage pretention scales. And Elizabeth Strout should ABSOLUTELY take a page from Dolly Parton's philosophy of not dishing her politics either. In this book! Well, bless her heart.But that was not the prime reason for barely a three star either. This one was also moody in a juvenile mode, judgmental about strangers of every ilk and just below her writing bar and continuity forms. More Olive than Lucy. 3 stars for the first half which showed at least a bit of spunk. And for her honesty. What can you expect from a person who doesn't care about food....more

author: Davis, Lindsey
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Oh is this one a departure! Not much from the flip, tongue in cheek humor tone, but from substance.A few have been dark but this one is History ChanneOh is this one a departure! Not much from the flip, tongue in cheek humor tone, but from substance.A few have been dark but this one is History Channel Colosseum TV show dark. Brutal, nasty. Torture, mayhem, death as entertainment.But that's not primarily why I gave it a 2. First ever 2 star that I ever awarded a Lindsey Davis. In fact, the last few Albia's were 4 star. Very good.This one is overlong. And as crass and horror filled the crimes, the day to day is dozens of multi characters introduced back and forth going up the the hills or down the hills. In 90% blatant misinformation or nil interchanges for any progression. Tiberius was even boring. Way, way too much like real detective work. Not inspiring, not connected much etc. After 3 or 4 departures it was hard for me to return to this book after page 100. In fact, this is the ONLY Falco or Albia book I've ever read which I considered a DNF. Well, this author can only go upwards from here. The laugh track on this book and with Albia generally is getting rancid. Not only not funny, but also almost interfering with the book flow entirely. This one needed a massive, massive edit. The bull was the best character in the book.The bottom line human heart and ambition that was in the earlier Falco is entirely missing. Plus Albia personality seems set in concrete at the age of about 22, not in her 30's as supposed. Her heart especially seems to have gotten lost. Admiring her husband isn't the same as being a fully engaged partner etc. There is nearly nothing "there".Oh well. I really liked the last one. Hopefully two duds in a row won't happen.Lastly, the banter of ridicule, sarcasm etc.? It has gotten entirely over the top of too too here. And it ruined the dialogue. You couldn't even tell which of dozens of characters were saying which cut or quip of snark after 10 different interchanges of the same for each page. UGH! If she keeps that habit up, I am probably done with Albia. Or her minions....more

title: Exiles        (Aaron Falk, #3)
author: Harper, Jane*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: 3.5 stars. Review tomorrow. Need a keyboard and some pondering. Both. I wanted to give 4 stars for the last quarter but just cannot. This needed a muc3.5 stars. Review tomorrow. Need a keyboard and some pondering. Both. I wanted to give 4 stars for the last quarter but just cannot. This needed a much better edit. Specifics quite beyond the levels of character building need to be addressed for this novel's prose form and pace. Coming soon to this spot. I very much like her earlier work and I am glad I stuck with this one. Although it was super close to being a DNF at page 245.Addressing the issues follows. Very much needed because she is not getting better at her writing. Quite the opposite.FORMS and pace here! Not even a 2 star for 10 or 30 pages at a time during the first half of this book. And you cannot, if you are an English author- even one who attempts dialect, you CANNOT use the same words and exact phrasing over and over and over again. Seriously, I started to count. It was a joke. 10 people of relative same ages and also VERY few, if any, of the generation older than they. But the WORDING and circular repetition of "facts". Both are atrocious. Off to uni, back to uni, not needing uni, bored with uni, and the footy too. And mate! Do I call someone mate 30 times an evening? People do not TALK in this mode. Nope. Australian or not. Watch Australian telly (here we go again) series. They do not. Nor do they speak about themselves in adjective phrasing. This was TERRIBLE writing. Beyond filler copy in repetitions too, it also could have been edited by at least half of the count in the first 245 pages. And no one notices in these s? I only see one post who understands that the character building, though attempted deep, in pacing and in emphasis for the same exact traits and feelings was off. Pace failure dropped all tension in this book. There was NO tension in this book until the Gemma/Aaron assumptions/conclusion decisions at the ending. Aaron, himself, and his eventual decision- that was even stymied flat.A slow and tedious character building can almost always be somewhat necessary. But not done this way and for these many comrades. Circular timing with flashback of 20 years too for the Festival weekend when Kim went blanko? Plus telling the same facts over and over again. And how about Shane? Was he detailed at his soccer and being the far past sports hero enough? Ridiculous how these few friends were posited over and over and over. And yet some of them STILL remained just shallow stereotype. And the finale STILL had to be told in flashback on top of it. UGH!This is an author I liked and who had two first published that were head and shoulders writing over these last two novel samples of hers. Very disappointed. Is someone editing these at all? What direction of publisher is she at all getting?Also, there is a HUGE outlier feature that made the middle 300 pages hard to read. Why are the Raco brothers hosting a christening for a baby or toddler (repeat after 1 year because of tragedy) Zoe. Zoe is a child that is NOT related to them and an offspring of their ex-sister-in-law's 2nd marriage. If I had tried to pull that off- it would have caused more than a missing person at a festival, let me tell you. Note that Zara is the ONLY person related to all these Zoe's christening party folk. And she is only 17. Is she hosting a party at a vineyard of this type? Does anyone who reads this not understand what a stretch this one was. COME ON! And yet all the older people (above 40) are footnotes of far away or rare conversation? And the people who are waiting for the star baby to arrive, they don't even have anyone at the house to do appropriations? And even if Aaron is a best buddy life long friend? He gets the cabin etc. as god father- right? BUT it isn't their niece, nor is it their closest friend's kid. So many features here that were like The Breakfast Club gone wonky. Are these people 38 or 16? Often they speak like the latter.There are MORE criticisms I could specify. Australia nature itself was not given its due. Only because of the last fifth of this book did I give it the 3rd star. The ratings on this one are overblown ridiculous. And I knew the crux of the missing Kim question from about page 40 too. They could not have been that dense- all these people. All those people who have been trying to get "in touch" too for over a year or two? And the paint color aspect that was given many paragraphs in police headquarters description! Dead giveaway. I knew before page 245 who had altered that situation also. The only reason I kept reading this novel was because it was -5 degrees F out and I didn't want to get into the elements to pick up my other books waiting. Please publishers, editors. Come back to work....more

title: The Kissing Bug: A True Story of a Family, an Insect, and a Nation's Neglect of a Deadly Disease
author: Hernández, Daisy
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This is a very uneven report. Part memoir and if you take in the title? Not accurate either.And I thought it lost an entire 1.5 stars for not having aThis is a very uneven report. Part memoir and if you take in the title? Not accurate either.And I thought it lost an entire 1.5 stars for not having any graphics or identity to what the reality of this insect has in appearance.https://www.cdc.gov/parasites/chagas/She has editorialized about 2/3rds of this report/memoir mainly in juxtaposition to her aunt's terrible ordeals with Chagas disease in all its long term worst. It has not been "neglected" so much, as rare in the USA. It still is rare. It is a American Subtropical parasitic insect and other vectors (bed bugs seem to be able to pass it from infected carriers is just now being determined) disease. But it is only one of many dozens of subtropical parasitic disease. No, 100's. The book itself is all over the place and more a journal of her family's up and back to Colombia/ New Jersey or USA locations, her own cultural blitzes for her relationships with them re her sexuality and other family truth or explanation issues- and about 10% editorializing her bitterness upon colonist theory of blame game. Very ironic in title too since the treatments her own family have experienced! Her aunt and numerous others coming in and out of aftermaths- received huge surgeries (even heart transplant in a case or two) without humongous costs or any non-availability they would have gotten or experienced in any of their home nations. She is bitter and she luckily isn't even positive within Chagas testing of herself. Many more books are out there or information online re chagas disease. Vectors exist beyond the insects. Dogs and other mammals carry chagas. It has been one of many insect related horrifics for humans of ancient, millennia past, recent, or present day history. Other diseases like Malaria are still devastating entire continents at the rate of killing and minimum debilitation of over 241 million people a year (2020 stat). So having about 500 or 600 people in the entire USA treated for this in comparison? Like 100 other diseases borne from insects and poverty- most of the prevention is not getting bit. But there are facilities to test for chagas in anyone's blood (nearly all countries and USA or Europe absolutely), just as there are for AIDS or many other factors of disease aftermath or parasitic infection. This report overall- would lead you to believe that chagas is not addressed in testing nor in attempted treatments throughout most of North America. That's untrue.This actually got my ire up a bit since I spent my first 7 or 8 years exactly as she did in the bed/family/housing etc. situation. Poverty spreads disease. It isn't only chagas. Density living arrangements in a subtropical climate pass worms and dozens of other parasitic or infectious conditions. Do I know. Other climates have other bugs and other parasites (even fresh water lakes do). Like cockroaches or various stingers or suckers (bed bugs) which pass filths of other terrible end stage conditions. So in comparison and in prospective of counter actions, this book was hugely off in "neglect" perspective. And yet once or twice she got some worthwhile information in there. Barely.There is one morsel I learned here that I didn't know. And that is that chagas can be passed in utero....more

review: Very much a procedural study of the combinations of police forces for the murders at sea in the Channel. You will like this one most if you LOVE deducVery much a procedural study of the combinations of police forces for the murders at sea in the Channel. You will like this one most if you LOVE deduction exercises of great length. Detailed all.One of the more interesting aspects to me was the level of colloquial language and phrasings that hold some meanings which have been lost since this was written. "Calling back the dogs" and quite a few others that I had never heard at all being cliched during this period. Some had to be defined later in the conversations. I was grateful. I always think the 1925-35 period in particular is also good for intrigue re class differences or consciousness. Not only in England but especially so. It is one of my favorite times of all for not only fiction reads.Stereotypes of ethnic or country of origin or vast generalizations to class are made repeatedly upon languages or ancestries. To points that are not at all PC in fiction any longer. All the characters here seemed not to care in the least. In fact, some of the foreign consider it welcome or almost funny.I enjoyed it overall and the double twist. The long passages upon ships, boats and their speeds will put some eyes to glace. It gets very mechanical/ technical....more

title: The Boys of My Youth
author: Beard, Jo Ann
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: The story with the title name blew the air right out of your body. That's what it feels like. I have lived through those kinds of times too, events ofThe story with the title name blew the air right out of your body. That's what it feels like. I have lived through those kinds of times too, events of violence/ death. And I was younger and witness. Pictures never leave your psyche. Details of similarity always bring it back up too. And Jo Ann described her guessing scenarios for the "real news" exactly right. That was a 5 star reveal. No little thing to do..She puts her childhood memories to a 5 star degree of detail. That was intense. And exceptionally delightful to read. That's exactly how it was. I could have been twins with her big sister. And Jo Ann was always Miss Sensitivity. NO change whatsoever. LOL!I actually liked her later Festival Days better. It is probably because most of her memories are a "been there, done that" to me in this one. But her mind games within herself of thinking what she thought during her escapades when young- they were 5 stars in both expressive forms and also in the voids. You seldom find that any longer. And I miss it. No porno scenes, far more emotional roller coasters. As that age actually is in reality for the majority of us.Why the heck didn't she just kick Eric out and never answer the calls? Probably for the same reason she never had kids? She can't go all the way in faith or karma of the future's open path? I thought she skirted that issue far more in her other autobiographical stories. In this one, she was still half baked about her own knowledge of herself. Always, always noting every detail to the max around her though. Extremely outlier and very lasting visual memory.She gets hurt by the least inconsequence of comments. She still can't get by any minor perceived dis- almost enshrining them on a scoreboard count. And yet she is definitely fun. I hope she always has her dogs and some trusted friends. But I was surprised at the content of these because I didn't get what I read in s. I got the average story of an Illinois girl of my time. Moline, Peoria, Oak Lawn, Manteno or Chicago Ridge. Kids in Aurora or Effingham hardly varied either. All of us girls knew about "corn snakes" as well. And played in corn. I did even in Chicago. It still is everywhere there is a lot or empty space in suburbia. Kids had such freedom that is beyond the believable to convey in this century. But she sure got close here in this book. review: This is not a full 4 star read but was 3.5 stars for me. I only rounded it up for the premise which has quite a different slant than any Japanese cultThis is not a full 4 star read but was 3.5 stars for me. I only rounded it up for the premise which has quite a different slant than any Japanese culture set fiction I've read. It's time warp posit and that's not being done much by any fiction works in the last 10 to 20 years at all. Time travel is very different than a warp. The first half of the book was a quick, convoluted but interesting set of stories that interlocked. The form was a bit jumpy but done fairly well to nuance and moods, especially those. Then at almost exactly half way the jumps between the dozens of characters became greater and more forced. By the last 1/3rd of the book, the remnants were of the "pick up" variety. In other words, the links were so contrived and time related flyaway in core- that you were guessing more than half the time. Without the cultural road markers of timely entertainment or sequence of Beatles popularity or some other event like the Expo? The connections became far more tenuous. Karma and the good intent principle was still center, but not as it was during the first half of the book.And I just don't get how all of these law breakers just turn over to be good and gentile advice givers by a process of talk and teach. It's not just in this novel either but in majority Japanese tales. It's almost like foul play or violence or terrible theft or any criminal can be easily reformed by kindness and concern of the preach and teach. OH would it be so true in any real world! Anywhere.Also I loved some of the people exchanges but still don't feel the emotional core here. People are dying of cancer, or drowning, or leaving their family forever etc. VERY DIRE real. And the reaction? It's an almost "oh, well"- on to the next thing. Sad but almost undiminished. Cultural mores but still? And suicide is always an option and seems nearly universal in thought patterns as an answer. To me it does.So the balance of conscience within the problem or General Store's advice in answer to the problem I "get" that depth. But I don't get the depth of reaction and play out of outcomes much at all in this quirky yarn. And I was pleasantly surprised at the crux here because it is much better than his detectives and their dialogues in his other books.This has a Hallmark worldview and conclusion. Others think it very heart warming. I did for the first half. After some of the sections, I felt nearly the opposite. Like putting a bandage upon an amputated stump. Not a kind thing at all. Way too simplistic and didn't reflect the depth of aftermath that humans DO experience. Magic or not....more

review: Fully 3.5 stars and rounded up for the usual verve. Before I do a reaction, you should know something. I have only read 3 of these Montalbano books. BFully 3.5 stars and rounded up for the usual verve. Before I do a reaction, you should know something. I have only read 3 of these Montalbano books. But I saw all of the film from Sicily played on European television. That series is phenomenal. Perfect actors. Livia is beyond perfect (both were but especially the older version Sonia Bergamasco). Montalbano, Enzo, Mimi and Fazio are 6 stars. I'm not kidding. Angelo Russo who plays Caterella? OMG, he is 7 stars. But reading Caterella's speech patterns (screaming and entreating directions too), trying to decipher them in print with these approximate sound spellings and accents? It's difficult. Very. Much easier to view visuals than read the print versions of this excellent material.Regardless, see the series filmed in Sicily if you can access them. My view was from library CD's. There are something like 37 or 38 episodes ending in 1921. They started in the last 1990's. So they DO age. Everyone does as they do in the print, as well. And the Montalbano's meals are just as delicious. OMG, the rice balls episodes! Adelina's supreme. Vigata in the books is a fictional town, but filming is in Ragusa, Scicli (police station street) and in Punta Secca (Montalbano's house on the beach)- all done in Sicily. GORGEOUS.This particular book is a good pursuit of the local and strongest Mafia family embedded mess. And there are innocents swallowed up in the carnage. Fazio was especially tongue in cheek here too. EXCELLENT reaction for being criticized about the paper in his pocket with birth dates, status, address etc. Good one, Fazio.But as good as these books are in humor, the film is better. Mimi is in particular. You never get his always on the lookout for another girlfriend on the side vs his wife's schedule for him here as you do in the visuals. What an actor. No one can ever look that repentant so often ever again.I'll read a few more of these in the latter variety. No one tells the truth. In Sicily, you just can't. Most of the the first 3 centuries' highlights on Scripture origins and movements of influence geographically, those exact detailing measures of places/ people etc., I had more than 60 years ago in grammar school. Believe it or not, that is true. In my Catholic schooling we were never taught Bible without the historical aspects of high detail. For instance that it was never written in Aramaic (Jesus's language) but in Greek and other much later translated copy language from an ORAL tradition or very old former language sources. And that for centuries as in Christ's time, it was used as an ORAL form and purpose for parables of teaching and example. Not meant to be people common read. Just wasn't until nearly a 1000 years later.This book is the historic without any intrinsic faith element other than the surmised of historic record. Which is appreciated, but absolutely not the entire onus of later heresy and faction fighting etc. And I thought the last couple centuries were not done as well as the first 3 at all.Fair and detailed historic record and some good suppositions in a non-faith sense of "getting" the gist of the power of influences. title: The Saint's Mistress
author: Bashaar, Kathryn*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: It's 382 AD in Northern Africa, near Carthage and several other towns. In Hippo too. And later in the book, the Suburra in Rome. The barbarians, especIt's 382 AD in Northern Africa, near Carthage and several other towns. In Hippo too. And later in the book, the Suburra in Rome. The barbarians, especially the Vandals are pouring across the Southern border, foodstuffs to living necessities (water, viaducts blocked etc.) are becoming scarcer daily. For all humans, those who are Roman citizens or not, it has become dire deadly. Sickness abounds. Inflation in costs for bread or oil have doubled and no one can afford what is there. (Does this begin to sound familiar?) Rioting mobs are killing shop owners with empty shelves. (More familiar.)This is the story of Leona, the partner to Aurelius (Augustine). Detailed and graphic to the world I have described briefly above. She is not his noble class, in fact as a teen ager she helps making cheese for most of her hours. That and home work with her sister, Numa. The first half of this book was a full 4 stars. I was embedded and the personalities were just carved. Although I must add that the writing form was so simple it did remind me at large lengths to a basic YA level of sentencing structure. They walked, they saw, they met etc. Very simple to the people in the couple's life. It's their love story and their life's story. Both.The second half of the book was barely 3 stars. 2.5 stars fairly. So I could not round this 3 star up as a total rating. Fevers, plagues, class laws, legionnaires who no longer speak Latin. Yet all groups are changing or have changed their religions too. For succor or for logical determinations, regardless. Sects of Christianity battling less too as the real migrations decimate the locals and the cultures that they have lived solidly and happily within for generations. And the separations are decades long. Leona and Augustine's son is the core pivot for great portions of the book. No spoilers. It puts you into another time and place. I so enjoyed hearing about the various foods, structures, and the Carthage Circus. Sad, sad, sad. But reflecting the reality of the real people who lived in this era. This is fiction, but not at all dissimilar than the majority for short lives of even a thousand years later. Before modern advantages, like electricity, mobility of later transportation forms or any medical knowledge of tools like penicillin that actually worked for curing in majority proportions. Philosophers turned holy bishops. Cheese girl turned leader of women's societal structure that later became working refuge of nunnery. Leona was savvy throughout the book. She made the entire storyline for me. No fool. It's her voice and eyes that form this story.I am glad I read it. The worst aspect was that their middle age was rather condensed and the pacing felt off (almost in total) by their lives' second halves. They were both long-lived in a time where to reach 70 was almost impossible. And often also unseen by the majority of other people (contemporaries) of theirs who were alive at any one point. 50 was VERY old during this period. Women of 46 considered almost like hag throwaways.If you have interest in different Christian sects (I did), this helped with some definitive information but didn't get into the depths I envisioned it would. Plato or Cicero held larger sway....more

title: The Marriage Portrait
author: O'Farrell, Maggie*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: The writing style is literary with the big L. And precise regardless of the exploding quality of word count. Which is large and totally cored on the 1The writing style is literary with the big L. And precise regardless of the exploding quality of word count. Which is large and totally cored on the 15 year life of the newly married Duchess of Ferrara. The life story totally through the eyes of Lucrezia, fifth offspring of the Duke and Duchess of Tuscany. Raised within the city of Florence, married away to Ferrara by contract at 13 but not "delivered" until 15. The words are as embroidered and opulence crusted as the time and place within her noble's world. 1500's upheavals of treachery and hierarchy yet. And the more that you know about this period for Europe in general, and Italy in particular, the better. You'll get more nuance to the fixtures and paths of reality. Not only for the general knowledge level of humans but for women's lives in this social structure. Infant and childhood death being about 50% or more common. And 50 something years old being ancient. This isn't emphasized but it will help to remember the reality of sickness and infection amongst dozens of other common "accidents". It's long and exact as much as it is effusive and natural world embedded. But the subject is going to be too narrow for most readers. Soul-wise, identity wise, manners wise or in sphere of relationship too- this will not be an easy modern read for most to fully dissolve themselves within such length and depths comprehension. I could be wrong, but much doubt it. You need to be extremely patient. And be more than tolerant for the flowery and effusive.There were exquisite 5 star portions- most near the beginning of the book in Lucrezia's early childhood. Most spectacularly with the tiger meeting. But on the long travels and in most of the mid-section half, it was not above 4 star. Certainly for me, not as immersive or throbbing as Hamnet. Still my favorite of hers.Well, this tells you the most dire in the very opening. So a lot of this will play for most readers backwards. title: Dirty Work: Essential Jobs and the Hidden Toll of Inequality in America
author: Press, Eyal
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Specific reaction and  tomorrow. This has a 13 page Introduction alone. Dirty work being redefined here from what dirty work meant in the last cSpecific reaction and  tomorrow. This has a 13 page Introduction alone. Dirty work being redefined here from what dirty work meant in the last century. Extremely padded survey of social by products for 5 individuals in their jobs.I need to think about this for a day. That’s how generalized and stereotyped are the fallouts of his work context sensibilities.Later: I want to let you know what his definition of "dirty work" is here. For 3/4ths of my life, "dirty work" was the following: If you took a shower before work and went to work, it wasn't. If you took a shower AFTER work (often at work) and then went home that was "dirty work". And all of us did it too at some point. My Dad and most of the men in my long life did it for decade after decade. Factory, streets and sans., labor construction etc. High rise plastering, working 22nd floor grids etc. You name it, we did it.This is not that "dirty work". This is "dirty work" in the sense of it causing PTSD or some mental incapacity impacted by its tasks. Something entirely different. So working on an off shore rig would be dangerous and lethal mentally, emotionally etc. Or guarding prisoners, or working the chicken line etc. Or drone pathing.The 5 categories chosen made my jaw drop. In reality. I had to resemble the emoji for that SHOCK to this author's equations of comparisons. So eating chickens becomes equivocated to the Germans' ignoring or allowing camps etc. (Introduction gives you the bottom line of the collective guilt core property examples.) That's the type of category generalizing for guilt laden in repetitive accusatory declarations here. We should all be hanging our heads and taking mood meds for the guilt of appropriating collective or individual warmth or food? These supposedly hidden misery jobs he posits on scales of guilt the rest of us should assume because they exist. On theory par for his German examples of knowledge about human death camps serious.Ironically the two jobs I can think of off the top of my head that ARE giving PTSD routinely, he never mentioned once. Being a soldier (on the front lines and not in front of a computer) or an abortionist.When I was a child we traipsed through the abattoirs at the Chicago Stockyards. I did, three times at least with Girl Scouts or some school trip. I also talked to workers there while they worked -not on a break. My Grandpa worked for Swift. Eyal Press is a name you should remember- it's going to be a "warning" label for me. What absurd eyes! And these jobs are "hidden"? Nope. How would an author or outfit (Eyal Press) judge any life on a farm or anywhere before 1800 by these criteria? Even on this highly subjective level. Irony indeed. A full reaction to this book could have been much longer. My mouth dropped open more with each chapter. La-la land. I refrain with any further specifics....more

title: Talking to My Daughter About the Economy: or, How Capitalism Works—and How It Fails
author: Varoufakis, Yanis
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: It was worth the read. Historically and by definitions of full overview of operating aspects he is making quite a few "some are all" fallacy inclusionIt was worth the read. Historically and by definitions of full overview of operating aspects he is making quite a few "some are all" fallacy inclusions. Not that the total oversight is "wrong" but it isn't at all exact enough to make such outcome suppositions as he does. Economies have too many moving parts for these simple / basic summations towards operation and inclusions. This isn't the forum to list all those over simplified tenets here. But one is unemployment as he defines and redefines. There are individuals who chose/choose NOT to work and also some who refuse to work in every living "gain" or ownerships definition. There are takers as much as there are surplus hoarders or super wealth "goods" aficionados. Even now. And this doesn't deny that greedy gorgers exist either. And he sees only the heavy goods end of consumption.He also almost universally leaves out longevity outcomes. Especially within populations which have always remained small and do their "proper fit" into their natural world. Like the aborigine of Australian continent he consistently mentions. My lifespan is twice their historic average now.He also gives very short shrift to the serf life. The millennia when the owner of land also owned the serf who resided on it. His overall picture gives government itself a much, more altruistic end result that I've ever seen anywhere or even read history concerning. Owners of surplus = bad? Operators of in class government= worse? My observation and history sense- this is often true.Democracy as the answer? Homo sapiens own human nature. His optimal cases give almost no room for the "elephant" in the room. That human nature. And as I have seen in my 74 years the very observable decline of knowledge for nearly all aspects of word or symbol or critical thinking learning and common sense survival skills? Both, absolutely both. People are easily fooled beyond the avarice features of getting too. And the inclusion here of movie / fiction or whatever plotting as an example of a posit? I thought that was 2 star habit for this read. I know he is talking to his daughter but too simple is too simple. And fantasy IS fantasy. My grandmother and grandfather were serfs. They lived short lives escaping from the system. No one in any of their backgrounds ever got beyond an old age of 55. Until the generations that were born "out" of that system. Present day stats for longevity should be included in this cause /effect historically re Capitalism out effectsDisease, geography, climate- they matter first. The cognitive history, their 1000's of years of reality in any one place etc. In that he DOES hold the right proportion of importance here. Overall this book is a good learning tool. But also not at all exact. Nor impartial. Nor definitively on the nail. It also might help you to understand objects and systems like bitcoin. He's Eddie Haskell (for all you Leave It to Beaver generations) but not as obvious disingenuous in mouthing overtly. Almost as duplicitous, but not quite. "How ARE you, Mrs. Cleaver!"Each story is basically core different. That I truly appreciate. I wouldn't put them all in the same genre. Fiction with a rather big F. Don't take that the wrong way, but he's often colloquial. Yet his know better is just more sublimely layered into human nature and universal male style probabilities than Eddie. Although he is still playing upon those very odds. Stronger common sense in Jess Walter characters though.The Angel of Rome was a 5 star tale and one of the longer word count copy of this collection. It's filled with humor and "fellows well met" and stars Rome itself as a marvelous frame placement. EXCELLENT all around. I could picture that actress and the glass window hands. And the Monsignor. And the other tales were at least 4 stars. No losers. One I didn't care for opinions within in but it was still a 4 star tale. The attitude in several of these reminded me of end stage bitter George Carlin. Do not forget that he is NOT 21 years old writing these. He's born within a year of my oldest son. I know his generation VERY well. They are 50 to 55 right now. Fewer of them and individually quite coddled in general because the birth control pill became common in 1966-68 and after that the classrooms fell from 40 kids to 25 in one year. Even IN the Catholic neighborhoods. His Spokane one sounds mighty similar.Enjoy these. As I said about Horowitz too. You sure can tell the screen writer living full boat in the novelist or poet or fiction writer. Any form- you can tell. Dialogue gets snappy and sit com like. "Here's trouble." Indeed. Humor with a large side of condescending arrogance. Half laughing with and at least a quarter laughing AT the "other".Not overlong and very worth the perusal. I feel deeply for his Catholic Mother. And that's not entirely facetious....more

More apt to the type of scenario builds that fit into Horror genre. I didn't see it coming. Although I absolutely much earlier foresaw the future of Maria's and Leonard's outcome as a couple. Correctly.It seems I liked this more than most readers. It was an excellent tale quite beyond just the erotic and burgeoning physical or mental. McEwan also truly encapsulated the precise quandary of English, American, Russian "allies" perceptions during this period. Best I have ever read about the American "shock" when the Russians turned like the autocrat thugs they can be quite naturally during the Eastern Europe afterwar occupations. It was still like that in 1983 when I went through Berlin into the DDR and eastwards. Americans are STILL surprised or shocked at the quick change in character generally, plus the eventual consequences. Partners or comrades? Not.Well done novel! Loved the time period for ethnic base generalized or specific reality. Blunt, no apology dialogue included. This trait is nearly invisible now unless it is racially cored. Right now they are nil.Too many details and too long overall, IMHO, this memoir. The insider cabals never interest me as they do all these communications or PR lawyer types. It seems to be their very meat. Others love to read about the groups always plying for access. I just don't. Kellyanne is honest and forthright with extra information. Here she gets repetitive at points. She doesn't do the generalized non-answer very often. Unlike what we presently hear daily. For the length of the copy, I felt I knew Kellyanne. But I don't find I would be at all apt to be so filled with peppy superlatives after being such a target for nasties. The personal attacks even here on Goodreads are just not deserved. While living there for decades raising more than the bunch. But its far more than about just Rebecca and her own family. Which, in itself, is more numerous than what I have just described. And with her compatriots inside the "Open Arms" the whole is quite a vintage late (last three decades in predominance) 20th century tale. I felt completely at home. Multi-generational. Elderly right here daily. Various friends or cousins, or uncles, or brothers-in-laws, or long lost ex-wives. Hardly any "nothing going on" days. Cousins upon cousins KNOW each other. Also my norm.I really was embedded in this one. Rebecca is half the people I have known and lived among. Busy taking care of all. Practical manager by default. Many humans are smack in her box. And not a few are also singles.Like other Tyler's, none of these people are rocket scientists or superlative brains. But they sure, in this one, do "most of it". And find family and a nurture of kinds core. Very good read. And holds too, the fork in the road within 50 something thoughts. All of us had them or think about them later. I had two different grammar and high school friends who married first or second boyfriends in later life. Nearly 40 years later in one case. Sometimes forks can lead back to original bases. title: The Stone Garden: The Epic Life of Billy the Kid

review: Well, give this one the most oddball outlier 5 star I've read this year so far. And also in Large Print copy on top of it. It was the only one availabWell, give this one the most oddball outlier 5 star I've read this year so far. And also in Large Print copy on top of it. It was the only one available and I got full attention by the hardcover design.This is a book I could easily put into the Literature with the big L category. The poetry, the leading to each chapter quotes from antiquity to nearly modern times! That with adding the juxtaposition for all of Billy's (Henry's) different ages and periods of time in that Southwest territory or Mexico! (All scrambled for/ in priority to their overall long term fallouts?) Just a stupendous setting for the surrounds of "the Kid" in all of his various aspects. And in this presentation "the Kid" was mighty. Nearly everyman. Lover, killer, book reader, composer, thief, dancer, animal owner and protector of and for all things corporal or loved/desired. All things.This is fiction. But what an "if Garrett again blasted the wrong man" composite for imagination. Which reality or which legend? Oh the legends!And the women in this cut to their core emotional and physical treatises. Because that is what this is. Life or death in the minute or the month or that year core to survive and BE human. Manuela, Cesla, Isabella, Susanne- all the loves and lovers of years or moments were characterized down to their areola tints. But beyond all that of Henry (Billy the Kid's real name) - there is the stinging Garden of Stones cemetery of the Wild West. Read the crooked sticks of carved names which tell the story. Tom, Charlie, infant, infant, infant. Dozens lying on the bend of the Pecos.Really, really opens your eyes to the when the West was not only lawless but what friendship entailed in that period. Or even structures of town or mound.This reads like poetry. I seldom appreciate poetry. But I do appreciation when speechifying or tales get the flow and sounds of a Shakespeare adventure. (And some of these quotes are aptly his.)Very much recommend. Yes, it is brutal. And I can picture Henry in great age very easily.OMG, can this guy write. I will read more of his for sure.Too many excellent quotes to list but just a few:"Kingly confines stern and cold where blood and guilt is bought and sold" - Shelley"I do not see them here; but after death God knows I know the faces I shall see. Each one a murdered self, with low last breath."- Dante Rossetti"To withdraw is not to run away, and to stay is no wise action. When there's more reason to fear than to hope." - Cervantes"For you and I are past our dancing days."- ShakespeareSo glad I picked this one serendipity. Lastly, never borrow or take as a gift another's well known hat. Or scarf, or horse. Or boots....more

review: So hopeless and sorrowful. The writing tries for chronological reporting of decades searching for her daughter. 13 years old when kidnapped by total sSo hopeless and sorrowful. The writing tries for chronological reporting of decades searching for her daughter. 13 years old when kidnapped by total strangers from her Japanese seafront home's street to North Korea in a ship's hold. They though she witnessed a boat pick up of 2 infiltrators. She has never returned. Contact or visits? Nope. Information inquiry may further threaten her survival on top of it. And definitely she was used to teach spies and infiltrators native Japanese mores and language. She became just a tool.Translation of the Mother's tale may be partly faulty for sequence understanding. Yet various governmental agencies, petitions, avenues to / for any return? It is hard to follow over so many years of repeat organizational refrains. 22 years at one point until they knew for sure that she was even alive. Then (1997). Grandchild possible too. One. Defectors have given very few details but enough specifics to know it was her.It seems both Japan and South Korea are fairly helpless in assisting dozens of returns. Some kidnapped from Japan. Some from South Korea. Not only her daughter's kidnapping. Other dozens are listed. Especially numerous during the late 1970's. Such a terribly sorrowful life of searching and in 1997 just enough detail after decades to make it even worse.Very Japanese in the writing form/ manner for address here. Always thanking and thanking for any returnee's hearsay or witness. She should be past 50 now. What a life pattern catastrophe for that young girl! One defector said she had a mental breakdown in her early 20's....more

Nuclear power is one of the keys that some people will not accept as approaching green "standards". Some countries use nuclear power for a great predominance of their needs. Nuclear is absolutely a factor. Europe on the whole successfully.This book made me remember that two poor souls who were trying to keep the Venezuela grids up all by themselves during the collapse of those systems in that country. As soon as floating power outages begin in major cities- you will hear more about this subject.Good book, but also hard to digest. Most of the humans alive now in industrialized societies could not live where they live and how they live without electricity. Especially in very hot or cold climates. But also re work, goods production or 1000's of other factors. Longevity will/would shrink immensely regardless. We can't all just use less of everything and return to pre-electric livability. title: The Man Who Sold Air in the Holy Land

review: This is quite extraordinary. Poignant, savvy humor, although at times more than heart breaking. Tragic complex. Parts of the majority copy would reminThis is quite extraordinary. Poignant, savvy humor, although at times more than heart breaking. Tragic complex. Parts of the majority copy would remind you of a MUCH more erudite and whip smart version of the TV show MASH. War comedy. Dark and brilliant laughter moaned in tears, while accompanied too in depths although often at frenetic pace.But, and it's a big BUT. Think massive cruelty along with heartbreak of war situations as asides for daily attachment to such human companionships and life tasks in general. War within common jobs, war within terrible past legacies and even more disillusioned futures. If a future is posited! And some coming of age with every down aspect of the Romeo and Juliet scenario packed in there too beyond just religion or politico differences.I considered giving this 5 stars. That is how excellent the writing and the grooves into current trends/mods/mores/tech etc. is within this. I would have if I stopped reading by the end of the middle portions. BUT. THAT BUT again. So spirit ripping. Emotionally insane juxtapositions! No, I could not give a 5. That would include enjoyment. Some of these I did not enjoy.Checkpoint and the one Scheherazade and the Radio Station, those two especially. After I got past those two almost all my enjoyment laughs were totally over.He is a pure 5 star writer. Superb talent. This collection is superlative. 4.5 stars plus for all 11 stories. His tale telling combos are "eyes" superb.What this taught me about the Middle East, Israel and Palestine in particulars was 6 stars. Much more than any history book or observations I made in my own life. I was born the same year as Israel actually, 1948. I cried reading some of this. It was hard for me to read the last two stories. What came before was too depleting. I actually took a break for a few days over a very busy weekend. That did help. The story about climbing the work Cranes made me even sadder after the time lapse though. Young have got to have this type of nihilist attitude? Streak of suicidal in all outlooks?Do not take this body of work (stories) as a pro-Israel politico or the reverse/opposite position. Either. This is reality which is much more complex. And MORE fractional on top of it. One story DID make me laugh out loud. The one where the brothers are finding a Holocaust survivor to take to school for show and tell. Every slant of that story sounds exactly like myself on the fiction s of these last few years re WWII fodder that is out there in droves. So called historical fiction which is soap opera, melodrama absurd sentimentality. That entire story was one of the full 5 star reads in this collection.A+ Strongly recommend this series of superbly written current Middle Eastern LIFE. Many different sections of Israel and border lands are included to some massive reveals....more

title: Learning to Talk
author: Mantel, Hilary
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This is a HUGE window into Hilary Mantel. It's her self-reveal. Part memoir, part imagination, part autobiography- but all her ERUDITE word placementsThis is a HUGE window into Hilary Mantel. It's her self-reveal. Part memoir, part imagination, part autobiography- but all her ERUDITE word placements and flow.For me this series of short works was a 4.5 star read. None of them were bad, under a 3 star. "King Billy Is A Gentleman" (the first short of the book) was a 3 star for me. That and the last one in the book were the only two which didn't rise to nearly or at a 5 star level. You could tell that King Billy story was one (story) started in her youth, IMHO. It holds the habit of writers writing too "hard" that beginners who rise to great usually exhibit in their early days. I have noticed. It's when the metaphor or descriptive or phrasing get over the top for depth of difference. Hard to describe but I sure can recognize it. Writers "trying to be Faulkner" I call it.The last one was her summation reveal. It's emotional. She is best without emotion reigning, IMHO. Like showing or doing instead of telling. "Destroyed" or "Curved Is the Line of Beauty" perfect 4 star examples.Regardless the book was a gem, a treat, a lovely interlude. I scarfed it down in one sitting. And then reread one or two. "Learning to Talk" is a 5 plus. Most of the middle ones are 5 stars. Her pure deep knowledge of English words (get your dictionary out- they are mighty and don't assume the internet has some of these either) with particular crux placements! Hilary Mantel is the only writer I can think of off the top of my head that forces me to look up words. Some almost lost, others rarely used. But precise and which put the feeling / identity core of Hilary herself smack dab central. Almost. There is pickaboo hiding Hilary also when it stops just short. What a unique original she is. With whatever English accent she uses. I would LOVE to hear her speak. There are only 2 or 3 writers I would LOVE to know and be friends with to trusting. Hilary is one.And this book exposes herself to the world to a 5 star degree. Even with the pickaboo trait inclusive. What an UNUSUAL childhood family situation for that placement/time. Her Mother must have been as mighty and as central HIGH self identity as Hilary is herself. To do that switching so visibly in that era and PLACE! Don't forget we are early mid-twentieth century. Hilary and I are nearly the same age. I do know.And having both men living in the house at the same time for a couple of years? No wonder that she and her Mom had the situation so evident in the story "Third Floor Rising". Read this one. Hilary AND her mother are after my heart. Sisters under the skin. But my vocabulary is not in the same universe. Not in English or any human language.Almost forgot! Read the Preface for sure. Oftentimes I skip those to take material head on without influences. But this time it starts to open the window a bit to understand all the air....more

Not This is a debut novel translation from Italian. Extremely chewy/gritty. If you are a cozy reader, avoid this one. It's rather a cross over genre. Not as much a mystery or whodunit as the trailer might imply. More cultural or societal horror. Evil in aspects, as well. Evil intellect rather examined when you get down to the posit tales. The beginning almost up to the half for me was 4 stars. Very Italian in the prime's insult demeanor and also creepy to creepiest. Truly early Stephen King creepy. Not only creepy but devious and sinister also.Then the switching got too too. And after the half way point the actual detail and sequences got more than unrealistic, almost absurd. Children to authority to the perp and the past? Every part of it was way over my time and placements believability fences. Beyond that, I figured out the connection between the time periods very early in the book. And the condition of Teresa all by itself was ALMOST up to the bar of being impossible for that time and place, as well.Not even in a remote Alpine town could such a physical and mental state WOMAN in Italian hierarchies be so enabled to continue the job the way she did. Not happening. Probably not for a man either. Police cannot risk the danger to all the other officers with fainting and voids going on like that. Not even for loyalty or any other quantity of "go ahead". You need to have a fiction mindset way above mine to swallow all the logistics this novel places as givens.The village as a unit block was done very well. As was the descriptive writing. I would absolutely give it a 4 star for chewiness of gruesome and also mood setting for the macabre. And also in a weird, weird style that is currently not abounding.But overall- not more than a 3 star. The ending itself was so melodramatic that I was not only disappointed at the events but at the so called tie ups. Teresa is a unique character. Old, heavy, sick, mean etc. And that's just some of the more easily described attributes. Also rather a boss from hell. I didn't get the new guy being so understanding almost at the get go either. It is extremely Italian in the speaking style and duplicity for information. Intuitive silence when it comes to authority absolutely.This author has potential. I read a  that said this was garbage. No. It's not honed by any means and it does get over the top very often. But if you read Shelley's "Frankenstein"? They are closely related, IMHO. Nor take on so many tangent topics which ruined any pacing that the tale should have held. But didn't.The time period of ending days of WWII? For the location it seems poignant but SO wonder on the accuracy to be honest. It was interesting to read of the beeswax efforts. But the crime aspect of men disappearing seemed no mystery at all to me. There was quite an overload of naivety overall that became super hard to swallow. Not only in the narrators at all, either....more

title: Upgrade
author: Crouch, Blake*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This is for me an exact 3.5 star read. But I rounded it up for the detail included. For instance, the "loop" system window description on the trip bacThis is for me an exact 3.5 star read. But I rounded it up for the detail included. For instance, the "loop" system window description on the trip back to NYC with Nadine. There were surround or component pieces just like that which were added, not essential, but rather entertaining to imagine. And they occurred throughout this novel. Seldom do I read any s before I read a book. This was one of the exceptions. Primarily because I anticipated PLENTY and also because I had to wait for some time after others had already read it. OK, it wasn't as good as Dark Matter. But this one held more actual chemistry, biology, other sciences of math etc. Some of the posits HIGHLY interesting too. Homo sapiens' knowledge or emotional components not the least. And the tales humans told/tell or succor systems voiced to encompass our own temporary states or suffering or fears. But it brought to mind over and over again the basic "disobedience" as a whole when too much knowledge is accessed by any "tree of knowledge" so to speak. And I did think this entire plot, premise etc. did take a major cop out on that bigger picture entirely. Compassion and empathy is feeling. It rarely solves and almost definitely doesn't help because it far more often enables instead. It's a recipe for dependency. Not the good kind either. Well, the ending was immensely flawed. Not our species or reality of human outcomes. Neither. Crocodile tears! Starving, death, suffering would continue. Possibly increased. Still the ride along with our altered hero was worth taking. So much sped up action that a good movie (expensive sets) would be doable. And the placements were excellent too. Montana and Colorado especially apt. Others complain of a lesser last third. And liked the first half much better. That wasn't my take on this one much. And other than the DNA helix imbedded code (code breaking skills gone superlative) that their mother Miriam used- I didn't think that the science was difficult to comprehend at all after the 50% mark. Just less easy read interpersonal as with the Ava chess or wife or coworker etc. first half scenes. All the science measurements and testing values named will also make some peoples' eyes glace over. As will his Logan's intense thinking knowledge of muscle groups or injury descriptions etc. Ok, Logan knows all that. Most readers won't want to. And it definitely does not make him altruistic or "good" at core in that KNOWLEGE either.Well, Crouch does have imagination. But also inaccurate and huge jumps in logic were demonstrated in this book. No system of vastly upgraded human around the Earth as it was before, is now or will be in the future- would "solve" at all, IMHO. Instead all the perceptions expanded as would be all the crimes, faults, short cuts etc.? Not a fan of any result that would or could occur. The upgrades already established certainly did not make them saints in deaths or in any of the outcomes. Quite the opposite. Government and elites would decimate MORE, not less. Work, production of any type? Think about it. Robots or machines would never fill the gaps. A recipe for a faster homo end, IMHO. Not a saving of one.Overall, this was not the top rung premise that most readers express or react to here. There were all kinds of sidecar issues never fully approached within this book for making these evolutionary changes so instantly. Emotional aspects of 1000 degrees too I could list. Loyalty, trust, love. They all don't depend at all on supreme knowledge or sensory inputs of maximum degree nor component physicality. Nor would this upgrade improve capacity for "goodness", IMHO. Some of the science seemed off to me too. But it still made a good bunch of interaction sequences regardless. Like in those stairwells to the 36th floor.So an extra half star for composite of some HUGE human components. Not on much other than the brain or physical outlays. Which should actually be minus 2 stars if I was purely honest and wasn't so entertained by his imaginative nasties. Because the human homo sapiens or homo deux or whatever would STILL be flawed. And MORE dangerous. Not less....more

title: When the Moon Turns to Blood: Lori Vallow, Chad Daybell, and a Story of Murder, Wild Faith, and End Times
author: Sottile, Leah

review: The context of chronology and placements were hard to follow here. This was a case I watched closer to its real time outcomes on 48 Hours or another oThe context of chronology and placements were hard to follow here. This was a case I watched closer to its real time outcomes on 48 Hours or another of those crime shows. I think Dateline too had one on this crew, I may be wrong.I did not recognize the names in the title or I would probably not have brought it home from the library. But I did, so I read it. Hard to describe the experience, actually. It's hard to fully designate, describe, categorize insane "group think" so maybe that is the problem.Regardless, this was far more than just 2 or 4 people or a "club" for "religious" instruction / discussion. This was just as delusional as Branch Davidians or Jim Jones or any of the "we are not just our body that you can see" folks. Lori Vallow (or any of the other 4 or 5 last names from all her marriages) was psychotic plus. For years at least. Chad Daybell at the very least, murderous delusional. The book didn't do full service to Mormon LDS dogma, I didn't think. In some ways only registering the very fringe movements and not the core belief system which is usually followed by the majority. It is quite patriarchal and does have a huge core of Faith in prophecies.But overall the telling of all this was just about 3 stars. Having all that published material listed by these "special" folks was good. Yet I never "got" how prevalent it had spread from the core dozen or so by that publishing. Nor how so many others not at all involved in their shared delusions were taken in for SO long by Lori's "kindness". And she was, seemed to be. Kind.But she saw the killing of her own children as worthy because they were "zombies". Not filled with the light....more

title: A Spool of Blue Thread
author: Tyler, Anne*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Some of Anne Tyler's books I enjoy immensely and love to return to the read. No matter how large the pile calling away. But this one I loved. ProbablySome of Anne Tyler's books I enjoy immensely and love to return to the read. No matter how large the pile calling away. But this one I loved. Probably in her top three I've enjoyed, despite having read about half of her output. Which is considerable.Abby is a typical Tyler character. She's unusual, if not eccentric, and has much in common with several other Tyler women in other books. A wife and a mother being her life, but not really. An essential type of individualism in disconnection which overlooks and embeds without getting either blame or praise attached. Rather rare. Not smart as a whip, and also not deep. Very much in the minute without any owning angst to outcomes. Love Tyler women. Have known a few like that, and yet in this age- NONE. Abby here forgives and forgets immediately. But registers. Not anything like the ancient history payback people or suspicious or selfish manipulators. Quite the opposite in both aspects.The form of the book was not a favorite though. It was nearly in reverse order. Part I was nearly half the book and my favorite by far. Abby's family. The Beach week segment was priceless. But Part II and Part III and follow ups became shorter in each sequence and were mostly flashback and many years prior to Part I. You heard the ancestor, youth, past birth family tales all centered upon the Brill House. Which in great decades of time became the Whitshanks' home.Now after these many Tyler books I am beginning to see a real pattern. She almost in every case has a man, a son usually- who is a never do well. Spiteful, sensitive to every life hurt possible, unwilling to develop maturity in work or in most normal life courses etc. Usually he is a good person to her, the Mom. Not always. But usually too a pain in the ass to everyone else in the family. Or a user- a guest that comes and goes but always in some kind of fugue to everyone else's wants/needs except to where he, himself, stands. And he is almost always a huge manipulator too. Economically and mentally. Tyler must really have had massive personal life context with this real deal. She had two daughters and no son, but there was someone in the picture. Grandson, nephew or whatever. She lived experience.She also gets women as individuals. Her marriage savvy non-withstanding. But her core women are nearly always not smart but at the edge of naivety. Open handed to the extreme while even putting themselves at risk. She makes some eccentric. Detached too. Almost ethereal. With their attentions in the clouds. She makes some of her men like that to SOME extent too. The mild ones she does. But most of her books have true oddballs in at least 1/2 the chapters. Surrounded by the "normal" who almost always pick up all the slack. Anne Tyler does notice.These are Baltimore working class everyday people. Ordinary. Just exactly like the world I knew for the first half of my life, maybe more. At least 35-40 years. Land lines are still ringing (and you know who it might be and need to get to it fast) and men are everywhere who know how to fix nearly everything. Neighborhood doors are almost always open to more than just 10 or 20 people too. And do you know it. Also never unusual to have 2 or 3 extra for dinner. It's almost gone in 2022. I liked the funeral service in this book immensely too. I have been to at least 5 to 10 of these in the last 4 years alone. People who didn't really go to Church. Let me tell you, their funerals can truly be a window. Here the Whitshanks did well. No religion at all funeral memorials are absolutely the most pathetic gatherings I've ever witnessed. Here Amanda, Jeannie, Stem, and Denny managed very well considering the circumstances and the fervor of the deceased.Some of the descriptions in this book are in her best ever category. I love the Swedish Blue context and also "stuff" like a clothes quip that it was the blue of the Noxzema jar. She has tons of those excellent USA colloquialisms in there.Most readers without any age on them will probably think this book boring. I nearly gave it a 5 stars. Great family perusal. The house itself was also a star. Love those wraparound porches!...more

title: Elizabeth Finch
author: Barnes, Julian
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Review tomorrow. This book is for the most philosophy minded with a baseline PhD History context for the last Roman empire times as a core focus. And Review tomorrow. This book is for the most philosophy minded with a baseline PhD History context for the last Roman empire times as a core focus. And in context with the earliest Christian growth and assimilation periods.Later:This is Julian Barnes showing off. And he does it splendidly. The book is divided into 3 Parts which are entirely different from each other. Seriously, they could be different genre the way current readers judge "category". Book 1 is the person Elizabeth Finch. Superlative and this is entirely a 5 star experience of character, influence, mode of behaviors, personality persona exhibited, and the HUGE influence she made as teacher and mentor to the mid-30's of age Julian Barnes. He LOVES her mind beyond even his own ability to form prose of flow and consequence.Part 2 is the treatise of belief posited. It plays out within the arguments from all these names of authors and lives (dozens and dozens of quotes superior) of antiquity and historic past which Elizabeth left him (willed by designation) in her notes/ papers. This received years later after Elizabeth suffered an earlier than expected cancer death. This part will make most readers eyes roll up in their head. It IS a treatise for a solid argument that Julian the Apostate's victory would have changed the entire course of homo sapiens history for the predominance of Christianity in monotheistic dominate power for the next millenia. For me, it was also 5 star perfect plus. Nothing I have read or heard better since the day I got 4 Psychology, Philosophy, Theology doctorates all in the same room for a dinner. It's something you don't do twice either. I sure learned. I could go very long here but I won't. Most of you will not understand the first, second or third pros and cons of any one of 5 or 6 Julian the Apostate's core tenets. Not even the ones where joy or happiness are anywhere near the top "to be attained" prizes for men and women humans. And I disagree about Elizabeth too here though. Julian deemed her optimist side. To me she was more a Stoic-pessimist than a Stoic-optimist.Then there is Part 3 (yes, and the book is quite short but says a WHOLE LOT for its length). And this is where it lost the star for me. This part should have been even shorter. He goes too far into the Julian Barnes self-adoration side sanctuary instead of staying in the body of the cathedral, so to speak. He adores himself. He is brilliant. And does he know it. Part 3 is a later in life (Julian Barnes life) summation of the "worths" from his incredible Elizabeth Finch friendship and example memory. (I do know worths is not a word but it should be.) And also FURTHER proofs for Julian the Apostate being in the right channel within the human species river stream. Having "the know" far more correctly than religious faith or any other human "mindset" baseline since. (But he fails to finish this argument, IMHO. Because Julian the Emperor was sober, not a glutton, not addicted to power or clothes or lodgings of wealth etc. etc. etc.- in fact nearly a unshaven peasant in appearance and habits.) Here I could go long. Most men do not have the aptitudes, IQ or temperament base of a Julian our last Emperor.This is for the philosophers among you. I thought it a 5 star completely until the last 15 pages. But more than 4.5 stars in total. If you have ever read treatises for part of your living, you MIGHT begin to appreciate what he did here. Most people will give this 2 stars or a bit more for the Part 1.But most people have almost no understanding of the human mind or the soul. And have not been exposed to these TRULY FREE SPEECH means to acquire an individual belief or action or speech mode that is made of well thought purpose for individual seeking. If they did outcomes would be different than they are in 2022. Nearly everywhere. Hedonism's opposite is principled thinking as this was. We have mere squabbles of humans never taught to think amid living hedonism now. And that chaos is getting worse.This is Julian Barnes' love letter to the teachers and people who taught us "how to think" and not "what to think". Most people today don't even have an inkling for the difference.-"To be a stoic in an age of self-pity is to be judged standoffish, worse, unfeeling."-"And there are many others who confuse feeling guilty with being absolved. They are less aware that there are stages in between." -"A woman described herself recently as 'preternaturally truthful'. Which is melodramatic nonsense. There are not degrees of truthfulness. There are degrees of lying, but that is another matter."Elizabeth Finch ALWAYS warns about pity. There are many pity cored quotes. BEWARE which fits 2000 plus eras PERFECTLY. Empathy and pity have viscous backsides. And useless faces....more

title: The Officers' Wives
author: Fleming, Thomas
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Completely character driven very long novel for a group of West Point grads circa 1950 and their wives. The story covers the next couple of decades plCompletely character driven very long novel for a group of West Point grads circa 1950 and their wives. The story covers the next couple of decades plus.Detail was extensive for the periods and most of the historical aspect of copy. And without any exceptions the entire novel is also very representative for the woman's read supreme of the time. In many aspects it remained me of The Group. Or other sexual couplings effusive tracts mixed with attempts at literary or arts appreciation that was a HUGE percentage of paperback fodder of the period between 1965-1990 especially. I read so many of these.Even when young or middle aged and this was "new"- I would never have given it more than 3 stars.Knowing so many Vietnam soldiers, officers too. One very well, in fact. Well, this didn't truly do the Army itself or the Vietnam crux situations to any extent beyond the soap opera angles. Joanna especially. Not a norm. How many other officers did she end up sleeping with? And Adam?He would have never made it out of West Point. Attitudes and voicing DO matter.But it was a melodramatic and extremely poignant tale told. And exactly what women would read. It was like an elongated version of Redbook stories. If you read Redbook back in the day- you know what I mean. Romance like the Joanna/Adam mix of star crossed lovers was always at some point in the postures there. Or being "modern" and eventually falling into illicit love affairs regardless of the conscience posit. Joanna's Catholic thought patterns and daily Mass etc. etc. etc. That was so overdone and virtually ridiculous. Women who I knew as close friends who become nuns and 200 others in some of my huge h.S. classes? Never that close minded, restricted, or in anyway that naive before marriage most especially. But the mix was truly retro for the period. And the characters were absolutely individual and their paths status quo for their era. These women would be only about 10 years older than I. Or less. Korea, Vietnam was handled at just about a 3 star level, as well.Added later as I forgot to note this fairly core point. I did read this when it was "new". And I did remember the Joanna character but almost nothing else. But knowing so many long married Army or Armed Forces people in real life situations, I didn't at all relate that much as others say they did when they were young to this read. I knew then as I know now, being married for 40 or 50 years does NOT imply that the people are happy people. Or well suited either. In the density of my neighborhood and society when young I had dozens of examples. Almost no one got divorced. In fact, I don't remember more than 1 out of 100's of marriages where I grew up....more
